review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2021
review.title: Worked fine for a year, but starting to fail, cheaper quality than I expected
review.review: I like the overall feel of this keyboard, and it worked well for a year. The keyboard feels heavy and solid, so I had confidence in it working well and being reliable. However, lately the space bar has been acting up. It 'duds' sometimes causing the space bar to not travel straight down, especially when hitting it off center towards the right side.This is very annoying as space bar strokes are almost by definition (two hand typing) off-center. This is definitely something with the underlying mechanics in the keyboard or the stabilizing mounts.This has become a real nuisance, I am with some regularity missing entire space bar strokes, which is sadness, I liked this keyboard otherwise, but I am afraid I will have to junk it, missing 1 out of N key strokes is simply unacceptable.POST EDIT: I contacted the seller who advised to remove the space bar and clean the stabilizers, which didn't really help much, but now I have a 2nd problem that the Caps Lock and ESC keys sometimes output garbage which could either be indicators of dirt or short on the circuit, or a break in the circuit?It looks impossible to clean this keyboard internally without desoldering the whole thing, remvoing the external housing doesn't do much other than concluding that the board and is inaccessible, so if there were an issue that can be fixed, there is no way to get there
product.title: iKBC CD108 V2 Ergonomic Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Clear Switch for Windows and Mac, Full Size Keyboard Upgraded w...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2021
review.title: Great no-frills keyboard
review.review: My job went to permanent work from home, so it was time to up my game and get a really decent keyboard.This was surprisingly hard to find.I knew I wanted something like the IBM Model M.It had to be wired because my work PC doesn't play well with wireless devices.I didn't need or want rainbow backlighting.I just wanted a keyboard with a traditional layout that I could get some typing speed on.This fits the bill nicely.The keys don't snap quite like the Model M but I'm going to be on the phone a lot so it's a good compromise.It's good and heavy, it's not going anywhere.I read the other reviews but I had no problem with loose keys, it was packed well enough.I think maybe down the road I may wish there were more palm support but I can add something for that.If you want a keyboard that means business, if you are going to be on it 40 hours a week, and you like the old Model M, this could be a good choice.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 7, 2021
review.title: Excellent quality and had the "sound" I was looking for
review.review: I bought this keyboard to replace another that supposedly had anti-ghosting and key rollover; it did not (or it functioned poorly, one or the other). That is not the case with this keyboard. I do a lot of typing and I haven't had a single issue with missed keystrokes since I began using it.The quality of material is apparent out of the box. First, this is a hefty keyboard; while not a perfect indicator of quality, it's a sign that the manufacturer did not skimp on materials. The keycaps have a comfortable contour but are strong and secure enough to withstand the strokes I'm pounding out while composing the angriest of email replies.The best thing about the keyboard, in my opinion, is the sound. If you are buying Cherry MX Blue Switches, you should expect loud "click" with each keystrokes. If like me, you find that both audibly and tactilely pleasing, you will probably enjoy this keyboard.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2021
review.title: Seems good so far
review.review: + Keycaps seem solid/sturdy - Matt type material+ Gateron brown feels similar to MX Brown with very slight difference in actuation force+ No technical problems .. Keyboard is not defective+ Enjoying the 75% size for FPS gaming- There is a slight curve on keyboard. It's not a straight incline plane from the F keys to spacebar. There's a slight curve in the middle. I prefer the straight inclined. It's not super pronounced so it doesn't bother me that much.Keyboard stand at bottom is not necessary. Makes the already thick keyboard even taller off the ground, hard to type because of the curve plus the extra angle.Keyboard already raised at the back near the F keys by design of its case. Adding the stand makes it even more raised at the back.Overall decent gaming and compact keyboard style. Keycaps are smaller than fullsize keyboard. I don't know if they make a 75% that has full sized keycaps but these smaller keycaps are pretty easy to type on.

Ultimately I returned it for another brand with those features, that only cost 5 more dollars.

The keys feel fine and are nice and quiet.I saw some reviews stating that the translucent plastic flexes as you type, this is just simply not the case. The keyboard feels solid with minimal flex, you have to really put in effort to make it flex.I also see many complaints about the software. While I wish it offered some more customization options, it's easy to use and serves it's purpose fine.I like this keyboard a lot and may purchase a second one for my work setup.

review.title: Missing keys
review.review: Wow, a really solid board for a very affordable price. I ordered a V2 Black/MX Black and received the switches I had ordered. Nothing on the box designated that it is V2, so it’s possible I have an older board.However, more concerning to me was the fact that I received this beautifully simple board with...missing keycaps. How? Out of the box, four keys simply did not have any keycaps and several were lose on arrival. So now I have a mix match of the crappy colored keys included in the box (far below the quality of the rest of the keycaps).Really wish I could’ve just used the board all black/white as advertised, now I have random blue/red/green keys. Annoying.

review.title: Good keyboard overall with some quirks.
review.review: This is a sturdy keyboard with some good heft to it. Cherry MX switches perform as expected and with some decent quality caps. However, I have some qualms with the fit and finish. The pcb seems to be off-center inside the case, making the cutouts closer to one side. The escape key is almost rubbing the case on the right side. The usb C port has a loose fit that feels like it will wear out quickly, and the firmware built in is very confusing and unintuitive. However, at roughly half the cost of a WASD brand equivalent, I would say this is a good buy.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2020
review.title: On another level
review.review: This keyboard is just incredible.You really have to have all of its ~5.5 lbs in front of you and under your fingers to really appreciate just how impressive and well-built it is, and how solid it feels.Once on your desk, it does NOT move.Unintended bonus in that regard is that in a pinch you could legitimately use it to fend off an attacker, or perhaps anchor a small-to-medium-sized yacht after a long day of offshore hacking.Got mine with MX Browns, and the typing experience is just about perfect, provided of course tactile switches are your jam.Height is not adjustable, but I did not find this to be an issue, and found it extremely pleasing to type on both as-is, as well as with a Glorious wooden wrist rest.I have medium to large-ish hands, FWIW.RGB is not insanely bright, but easily bright enough to do the job, and the effects are particularly wonderful.Doubleshot PBT backlit keycaps are a nice touch, and if you wanted to up your game in that regard, it is obviously a very easy upgrade.This is certainly not a budget keyboard, but you could honestly spend a lot more, and get a lot less.I would 100%, absolutely, unequivocally buy another one of these should anything happen to this.In fact, if that were ever not an option, I would happily rebuild this one from the ground up, soldering every darn switch and all, because of how enamored I am with the block aluminum case.If you're on the fence, don't be--you'll love it, and only wonder why you didn't buy it sooner.
product.title: iKBC MF108 v3 RGB LED Backlit Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Brown Switch for Windows and Mac, Full Size Computer Keyb...

RGB is basic, but I don’t care. I just set to solid white lowest level and it’s perfect.Detachable USB-C.Cherry silent reds are perfect for gaming. I ended up replacing the switches with Zeal Zilent 65g for typing.I really wish iKBC still made the 68 key version of this keyboard as well.Anyway, you need to build a custom keyboard to get close to this quality. It’s a great value. Buy it.

review.title: Outstanding
review.review: I abused mine and it finally quit. I just ordered two more. This thing would be outstanding at 3 times the price. Everything about it is top of the line. You really can't do any better if this is the kind of thing you want. It is very heavy. Very thick PBT keycaps. Great stabilizers. No software needed. USB C cable. If you want a full size Cherry board with these switches I would recommend none other. Simply outstanding!
product.title: iKBC MF108 v3 RGB LED Backlit Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Brown Switch for Windows and Mac, Full Size Computer Keyb...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2020
review.title: Amazing keyboard
review.review: Top to bottom everything about this keyboard is amazing. This keyboard is a tank and should last you a lifetime. The keycaps are high quality and since it's cherry switches everything can be easily replaced. One thing to note: the learning curve on light functions is higher than expected so be prepared to take some time to learn how to use it if you are going to want to. The instructions are difficult to navigate.The only suggestion I would have is to offer it with a brass keyboard plate maybe for a premium price. It comes with a steel keyboard plate and I might look to have that upgraded down the line.
product.title: iKBC MF108 v3 RGB LED Backlit Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Brown Switch for Windows and Mac, Full Size Computer Keyb...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2021
review.title: defective product
review.review: Had this product for just under a year before it started acting up. It will fail to process inputs, then send them all at once. This happens intermittently, and comes and goes. There is also a power issue associated with it.I've been really communicative with the seller hoping to fix my board but they're very slow and their messages are not helpful. e.g. I send a request for help and their response time is three days "please hold fn+del for 3 seconds, the indicators will flash" I immediately respond "okay, I've done that many times and the indicators don't flash, what do I try now?"->"make sure the dongle is plugged into the USB port".A product like this should last more than one year.
product.title: iKBC W210 Wireless Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Blue Switch for Windows and Mac OS, Enables Media Key and LED Indica...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2021
review.title: Buy this one!
review.review: I absolutely love this board but first let me give you some clarification. I wanted a mechanic keyboard for the office, and I wanted something that would be quite and did not light up. I also really wanted something with the calendar button and that was wireless. That being said I can’t tell you how well this would work for gaming but I can tell you in a day to day fast paced office setting this keyboard is amazing! The stabilizers came pre lubricatedand do not rattle like a lot of other boards. I switch out the key caps for something to brighten up my desk and give a hint of personality but even the original key caps are of great quality!

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2021
review.title: Absolutely not.
review.review: This keyboard is awful.It works 60% of the time - keystrokes simply stop registering for seconds to minutes at a time, and then queue up and come out all at once later.The key images look like they were printed using spray paint and a stencil.The indicator lights for caps and num lock go off after less than a second - what is the point of an indicator light if I have to press the button anyway in order to get it to come on to indicate to me whether the lock is activated or not?I cannot believe I paid $100 for this piece of absolute flaming garbage.I wish I could throw it out, but it's too expensive.I now have to use two keyboards - a $20 keyboard I bought four years ago that works ten times better, and this thing, which I would not even use as a paperweight.
product.title: iKBC W210 Wireless Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Blue Switch for Windows and Mac OS, Enables Media Key and LED Indica...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2021
review.title: Small
review.review: I agree with what was mentioned in the other review that it is a little small.I have big hands and fingers and I find myself making a lot of mistakes typing on this keyboard.It is solid feeling and does not slide on the desk.Mine did not come with a wrist rest or any extra key caps.I like the mx blue switches though.if you have small hands you will probably like this keyboard.Everything else about it is awesome.Due to the size I will either return this or order new key caps.

Definitely much faster than a Bluetooth keyboard. I’ve been using it daily for about a month, and I’m still on the first set of batteries.

review.title: Essential keyboard

(Plus BT is not secure anyway).100% will buy more of these. I'd like to have one for all of the workstations at our offices.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2021
review.title: Wonderful keyboard!
review.review: I do not know why, but finding a wireless white mechanical full-size keyboard is so difficult to find. I have it about a meter away from the receiver and there is noticeable input lag.PROS :+ 3 height adjustments+ Quiet and stabilized keys+ Great battery life (still haven't needed to change the batteries since I got it!)+ Durable build with no deck flex+ Rubberized feet for those not using a desk mat+ 10 key (was an absolute must for excel)CONS:- No backlight (but that would cause battery life issues)
product.title: iKBC W210 Wireless Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Brown Switch for Windows and Mac OS, Enables Media Key and LED Indic...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2020
review.title: Excellent keyboard; however, see below
review.review: Two gripes I have with this keyboard:a.) (and this may be something which is now the norm for all mechanical keyboards) Keys are for TINY FINGERS.I am a 37 years-old woman, with average sized-hands for my 5'6" height, yet pretty narrow fingers, but I can barely type on this without hitting two keys at once.I had hoped for a similarly-featured keyboard to the "old-school" 80s/90s Apple keyboard.However, I can attest if you're looking for similar, be aware that the size of these individual keys is NOT COMPARABLE. Not sure whose fingers are being used to manufacture these keys, but they are lacking at least 2mm on either side of each key, resulting in the pads of my fingers hitting two keys at once nearly 4/5 of the time.Yes, I've tried modifying my "keystroke," to no avail.If you are a man (or a woman) with normal-to-wide sized finger 'pads', good luck.b.) If you happen to lose the little thingie which plugs into your laptop/pc to connect the keyboard, good luck.Getting in touch with these people is NOT GOING TO HAPPEN for you, because they do not respond to direct emails, emails through amazon, or phone calls (numbers given not valid).
product.title: iKBC W210 Wireless Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Brown Switch for Windows and Mac OS, Enables Media Key and LED Indic...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2020
review.title: Best mechanical wireless keyboard
review.review: Why is it so hard to find a keyboard that:- Use an actual "mechanical" switch? (and I define that as "activates before bottoming out")- Is full-sized- Is wireless, but with a USB dongle and not Bluetooth (BT keyboards cannot access BIOS, bootloaders, flaky, uses more battery)- Runs on AA/AAA batteries (so that when battery runs out, a simple battery swap gets you back to work right away, as opposed to finding a charging cable and wait for it to charge for hours)This keyboard fits all of those, is solidly constructed, and have an unassuming look to boot. This is just the best keyboard for working people.
product.title: iKBC W210 Wireless Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Brown Switch for Windows and Mac OS, Enables Media Key and LED Indic...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2021
review.title: I highly recommend you switch the keycaps!
review.review: Upon opening the box, I was highly tempted to press some keys; I must admit, it was kind of downplayed once I heard how subtle the sounds were. I am switching to Cherry MX Browns from Gateron Browns, and it sounded not as expected... Once I moved it to my wooden desk and propped up the feets and switched out the keycaps with $30 XDA ones, it sounded much better. This keyboard comes with OEM keys, that I must admit, do sound good, but not as good as newly-bought PBT keycaps. I highly recommend you purchase some of those if you are to be using this keyboard for the sound :3 That is why I gave 4-5 stars for quality of material.Thank you for your read, and these keycaps are on Amazon for $30. t.ly/pfmG
product.title: Durgod Taurus K310 Mechanical Gaming Keyboard - 104 Keys - Double Shot PBT - NKRO - USB Type C (Cherry Brown, Grey)

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2021
review.title: Quiet for a mechanical but still pretty clicky
review.review: Bought this for use in the office after getting fed up with terrible wireless keyboards. The quiet brown switches have good feedback and the board itself is rigid and stable. I have had a couple keycaps come loose but they popped back on and are holding well after. It's definitely not quiet for an office environment but it's not overly disturbing to those around me even though I'm a hammer typer.
product.title: Durgod Taurus K310 Mechanical Gaming Keyboard - 104 Keys - Double Shot PBT - NKRO - USB Type C (Cherry Brown, Grey)

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2021
review.title: Stopped Functioning After 2 Months
review.review: Recently, I started having an issue where the keyboard would stop responding to one or two button presses. The lights would keep working. If I would roll my hand over it, pressing several keys simultaneously, it would put those keys in, but not all of them. When I would launch the Durgod Zeus program, it would either fix the issue, or cause a DPC_WATCHDOG VIOLATION crash. I normally dislike doing updates, but I updated the Zeus thing to the latest version. Now, the keyboard has this problem constantly. 3 minutes of working and then it does the above-described thing - only multiple keys work, no response otherwise. Re-plugging the keyboard sometimes fixes it for 3 more minutes, but then the problem resumes.I attempted to contact their customer support, but they didn't get back to me. I would be very careful in buying this keyboard.
product.title: Durgod Taurus K310 Mechanical Gaming Keyboard - 104 Keys - Double Shot PBT - NKRO - USB Type C (Cherry Brown, Grey)

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2021
review.title: Keys Get Stuck Digitally
review.review: For the first six months, it was a solid quieter mechanical keyboard. Then, as others have noted, the keys started getting stuck digitally - not physically. Un- and replugging fixes it, but it's starting to happen multiple times a day and is just not acceptable for what's supposed to be a product you use for years. Go elsewhere for your mechanical keyboard.
product.title: Durgod Taurus K310 Mechanical Gaming Keyboard - 104 Keys - Double Shot PBT - NKRO - USB Type C (Cherry Brown, Grey)

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2021
review.title: Looks good but poor quality

product.title: Durgod Taurus K310 Mechanical Gaming Keyboard - 104 Keys - Double Shot PBT - NKRO - USB Type C (Cherry Brown, Grey)

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2021
review.title: This keyboard is better than sex.
review.review: I never write reviews, but I had to for this keyboard.I'm not a gamer.I just type all day and I tend to bang the keys pretty hard which means I go through at least 2 membrane keyboards a year.My son who is a gamer has convinced me to buy mechanical keyboards in the past, but I've never liked them even after prolonged use.The keys are too tall, the feedback is so hard it hurts my fingers, and they're too loud.This keyboard is another story.I love it so much my productivity has probably gone up 50% since I purchased it.It's just a pleasure to type on.The size, height, and angle of the keys are just right.No matter how hard you hit them the feedback is firm but gentle and it's quiet enough you can type during a conference call without it sounding obnoxious.I could definitely sit in a cubicle adjacent to a person typing on this keyboard and not want to murder them.The keys themselves feel thick and durable with a silky, but not slippery texture.While you get the full set of keys, the layout is compact with very little dead space.It may look lightweight, but is hefty when you pick it up.It's not going to bend or come apart.I love that the housing is such I would have no problem occasionally replacing switches and\or keys as needed.Other mechanical keyboards I've owned never seemed worth the fuss, especially considering wearing one out meant an excuse to get something else.I fully expect this keyboard to be with me for years.
product.title: Durgod Taurus K310 Mechanical Gaming Keyboard - 104 Keys - Double Shot PBT - NKRO - USB Type C (Cherry Brown, Grey)

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2021
review.title: Excellent build quality, versatile RGB, stellar switches.
review.review: You can read other reviews to learn more about the generic positives of this keyboard, but I just want to point out that the Durgod Zeus Engine software for the RGB control is literally a straight copy of Razer's Chroma Studio - which is a good thing!Not many keyboard lighting software come with such comprehensive and intricate control over lighting effects, layers, and directions.The PBT doubleshot keycaps feel great with Cherry MX Brown switches, but some of the transparent areas of the keys have slightly darker, more opaque areas (most noticeably, the "8"and "Del" keys) that make the light effect on the key look less uniform.
product.title: Durgod Taurus K310 Mechanical Gaming Keyboard - 104 Keys - Double Shot PBT - NKRO - USB Type C (Cherry Brown, Grey)

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2021
review.title: Do Not Buy!!! Stopped Working within the first 2 months!
review.review: The keyboard worked well for the first month or so but soon after, my keys would randomly short-circuit and stop working (I would press down on the key and nothing would pop up on screen). And then randomly, in the middle of typing, my key would start spazzing out like I was pressing down on a key (Ex: the keyboard would suddenly type out rrrrrrrrrrrrr as if I was holding the r key down). The only way to fix the issue would be to unplug the keyboard and plug it back in. It's not worth the money I paid and I would advise you do not buy this item.
product.title: Durgod Taurus K310 Mechanical Gaming Keyboard - 104 Keys - Double Shot PBT - NKRO - USB Type C (Cherry Brown, Grey)

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2021
review.title: Nice Quality, Compact, and Sturdy
review.review: This is my first mechanical keyboard, and I put in a lot of research before buying. I had been using a 10-year-old Lenovo board that felt as close I could get to mechanical out of the keyboards I had (and I love Lenovo quality).I went with the MX Blues because I enjoy the tactile feel and auditory pleasure that comes from switches. It does sound like a typewriter if you type lightly. I am a writer and editor, so I put in quite a few hours on the keyboard, and there are a few things that I will have to get used to. The keyboard is quite compact, and I have very long fingers, which makes me feel slightly cramped while typing, but I will get used to it quickly. I love high-quality/industrial items to which the product is close. I think it will last me a long time if I don't get sucked into the mechanical keyboard hobby and end up buying ten more, lol.Pros:Solid build quality (heavy)Decent packaging and dust coverDoes not move on the desk (I can shake my whole desk by pushing on the keyboard before it slips)It came with nice and decently heavy-gauge cords (USB-A and USB-C)I know this sounds silly, but the included mousepad coaster is also of high quality and fully stitched.It came with a key puller and dust cover.The Okay:The compactness will take some time to get used to; it is good for desk space and portability but is a bit cramped for writing.The key feel (much better than ABS)No backlightingNo individual media keysSoftware
product.title: Durgod Taurus K310 Mechanical Gaming Keyboard - 104 Keys - Double Shot PBT - NKRO - USB Type C (Cherry Brown, Grey)

review.title: Not MX Red, likely MX Red Silent
review.review: I have iKBC CD87 v2 MX Red and I like it very much. So I bought an iKBC W200 Wireless MX Red for the other computer. The first thing I noticed is W200 MX Red is not MX Red switch. The keystroke feels dull, key traveling and actuation force all feel different.The keyboard on top of the photo I attached is CD87, the bottom one is W200. The color of the switches are different, bottom one is more like pink. I don't see the switch spec on the product package.Will return.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on June 29, 2021
review.title: Great build, not so great wireless
review.review: Solid build, nice feel, and has good battery life. However, as of recently (approx 8-10 months after purchase) the keyboard seems to be picking up a lot of wireless interference - keystrokes are either undetected or lag seriously at random moments.I've tried with multiple ports on my desktop (front/rear IO, USB2.0, USB3.0) but it keeps occurring, and the lack of a wired connection means that there's no real alternative to replacing it with a wired board. For people who know that they're using it in an area with reduced/no wireless 'noise', this is a great board - but if not, I'd suggest looking at something wired instead. This interference occurs enough that I would say even for typing/document work it's annoying enough to recommend avoiding.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2021
review.title: Keyboard Heaven for Typists
review.review: This plug and play wireless keyboard is heavenly, especially for those who spent their formative years using actual typewriters. I did not know mechanical keyboards were a thing until this past month. I've been geeking out on them since, and have tried several, with wireless being my essential requirement.As keyboard geeks know, this limits the selection. I sampled several different brands (with Brown, Red, and Topre switches) but was not too impressed and sent each of them back. Some used Bluetooth and establishing connections was not always easy. The dongle/2.4 setup is best for wireless.These Cherry Blues are heavenly and this iKBC keyboard is the One. The wireless works perfectly with no perceptible lag when I'm typing at 100 wpm. As for the Blues, they are (satisfyingly) loud but I work from home and my dog doesn't mind.Strong recommend on this keyboard.
product.title: iKBC W200 Wireless Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Brown Switch for Windows and Mac OS, Enables Media Key and LED Indic...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2021
review.title: Small keycaps?Odd complaint
review.review: 1.) "Small" keycaps.I was reading through the Amazon reviews on this keyboard and I was somewhat alarmed by the one that complained about the size of the keycaps.These keys are a very normal size.They width of the top of the key is .515" according to my calipers (13mm).2.) With or without number pad?So I use this keyboard with either a mouse or a touchpad sitting just to the right of the keyboard.Since I use the mouse/touchpad so frequently, I find that the reduced distance I need to travel in order to get to the keyboard/mouse is wonderful, so I recommend omitting the number pad.I have a second keyboard that has a number pad that I can pull out if I have a bunch of number data entry to do, but for daily typing tasks, I don't feel like I'm missing much by not having the number pad.3.) Feeling of the key action (aka the switches).I got the Cherry MX brown switches.They seem great, but I'm not a mechanical switch aficionado.I would love to have tried them all out side by side, but I'm happy with the browns.They aren't too loud, but they're definitely not silent.My laptop keyboard and my other keyboard (Microsoft wireless bluetooth keyboard) are both virtually silent.4.) Typing speed.I type pretty quickly, and although I feel like I'm still getting used to this bad boy, I find that the responsiveness is very good, and I did a quick typing test online to see the how I was doing on the new keys.The Microsoft keyboard requires quite a bit of force to depress each key.The Cherry browns are definitely a much lighter actuation force.I found that I was immediately able to type about 15-20% faster which I attribute mostly to the lighter key actuation force and the solidity of the keyboard.5.) Build quality.Last thing I'll mention is that this keyboard is heavy.It feels well built and I suspect that it will last me for a long long time.Maybe (hopefully) a lifetime.6.) Scratchiness on the keystroke.There was a complaint from another reviewer that the keys felt a little scratchy on the way down as they are being depressed (They compared the feeling to another mechanical keyboard that they had used which felt "silky smooth").I notice this as well.I'm not sure if it bothers me, but I agree that it is noticeable.All that said, I have only had the keyboard for a day, so take it with a grain of salt.We'll see what I think in a year about this guy.
product.title: iKBC W200 Wireless Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Brown Switch for Windows and Mac OS, Enables Media Key and LED Indic...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2021
review.title: keys sstick like crazzy
review.review: I'm writing this review using this keyboard and as you'll probably see, there will be many duplicated letters that constantly happen througghout my typing process because this keyboard, while expensive, constantly has keys that stick. And you may wonder, well there's not that many issues then, what's the big deal? That that would be beccause I had to go back kand add specificc letters where appropriate beccause if the keys stick, they sometimes also don't get picked up. So I'm workingg with 3 kinds of keys here: Some that work normally, some that stickc, and some that don't work unless you really give them a good jab. It's quite frustrating because I really like the volume dial on this keyboard.I should have listened to the other reviews.
product.title: iKBC Typemaster X410 White Backlit LED Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Low Profile Red Switch for Windows/Mac, Full Siz...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2021
review.title: Phenomenal! ...But Takes Some Getting Used To
review.review: Okay so I absolutely love this keyboard, no doubt about that now. It wasn't like that at first though.I initially purchased the keyboard for my first gaming desktop PC (avid longtime PC gamer, putting in 80-90 hours every week on average back on my gaming laptops) and I liked the black/white aesthetic that matched my PC and speakers, but also because of its minimalist design and THE VOLUME KNOB <3Upon first getting it and using it however, I found myself accidentally pressing other keys by accident because they aren't spaced very far apart and don't take a lot of force to press. Honestly I almost considered returning it after a few days because I hated all the misspellings I was making and having to correct.After a few weeks of usage though I suddenly realised that I wasn't making misspellings hardly at all anymore and my fingers had already memorised the placement of all the keys so I don't even look at the keyboard when I type now.So for anyone who just got this keyboard and is having a similar issue, just stick with it for a few more weeks and I promise you it gets better! For anyone on the fence about it, just be aware that you may have this issue at first but like I told the current users, you get used to the keyboard after a short while!Alright here's the Pros/Cons list: The Cons: - The narrow spacing between keys can lead to some accidental key presses in the early days of getting used to the keyboard - It isn't wireless (this may or may not be a con for some people, I personally don't care much) - Um... I think that's it?And the Pros: - Typing is pretty quiet compared to a lot of other keyboards! My roommate said he was glad I switched to this keyboard finally just because he could finally read in peace haha. Combine this keyboard with the Emopeak silent mouse and you've got a nice quiet setup, though that mouse may be a bit small for some people. - The ever-so-silky smooth volume knob! I honestly can't get over how nice the knob is. It has the perfect amount of resistance when turning it, its metal construction makes it feel very premium, and if you want to mute the volume, you can just press it down to mute instead of turning the knob to the left. I refuse to get another keyboard that doesn't have a volume knob. - The individually-backlit keys! There's plenty of lighting pattern customisation, from the speed of the animations to the brightness as well---and of course there is the ability to have the keys constantly illuminated or not at all. - The ability to set a PIN to unlock the keyboard when turning it on--to prevent any unwanted users accessing your keyboard/PC - Low profile makes it a good entry-level keyboard for long-time laptop users wanting to get into the desktop world. - Very portable since it has a low profile, isn't very large, and the USB-C to USB-A cable is detachable. - Media control buttons in the top right of the keyboard! I'd've preferred the Play button to be between the Previous and Next buttons instead of the button order being Play, Previous, Next. They still work great though and I love using these in conjunction with the volume knob when listening to music. - Also the calculator button, right next to the media control buttons. Didn't think this was something I'd put on the list of pros for a keyboard review but honestly I use it far more often than I ever thought I would. - Great build quality! I saw a previous 1-star review saying that many keys stopped working for them after a few weeks or months of use but I've been using my keyboard for 12-13 hours almost every single day now for over a year and I have had absolutely ZERO problems in all that time.So I'm not sure what that person may or may not have done to their keyboard or if they just happen to have received a faulty model but their case about their keyboard is definitely not something you should expect to find with your keyboard.Who knows, maybe they didn't read the manual and accidentally locked themselves out of their keyboard haha.Features: 10/10Ergonomics: Initial Use - 6/10, Later Use - 9/10Build Quality: 10/10 (so far still holding up with no issues whatsoever over a year later of constant usage)Portability: 10/10Would Recommend: 13.5/10

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2020
review.title: Key switches failing after 3 months - can't recommend
review.review: Pros:This keyboard has a nice feel to it, the key press is just the right weight and was a pleasure to use - for about two months.The volume control knob is exactly what I wanted and the reason I bought this keyboard in the first place. To many times have I gone from one video with super quiet audio to another that wants to blow my speakers. Having an audio dial that accessible is the solution I needed.Cons:I have at least three key switches that are causing issues after 3 months.The tab key either doesn't work at all or "bounces" (detects multiple triggers when only struck once) and sends multiple tab keys. As someone who uses tab to move between fields when filling forms and auto completing text, this has become quite a nuisance. Autocomplete in gmail has turned into auto-send an email before I'm done typing it.the shift key (and yes that non-capital at the beginning of this sentence is the issue) fails to work about one in ten times. Half the time I catch it and go back and have to fix it - slowing me down.The "j" key is super sensitive meaning if I brush it when putting my hands on the keyboard or while typing around it, I end up with a random j in the middle of the page.In short, I can't recomjmend this keyboard. It's caused a lot of issues and definitely not worth the $100 price tag.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2020
review.title: Day1 - It's what I wanted!
review.review: I have been using the Keychron K2 for a month or so now and I love it, my only gripe was the angled height of the keyboard, so I decided to try something low profile. Enter the iKBC cherry mx red tkl keyboard. Even after using mechanical keyboards for almost a year now, I still prefer thesatisfying tactile feedback of brown switches, nonetheless, the typing experience on the iKBC takes a little getting used to if you are coming from more traditional keyboards. The 3 biggest differences for me were the height of the keyboard (very comfortable without a wrist rest), the size of the keys (they look like they have been squashed down by Wreck it Ralph) and the unique sizing of the spacebar, enter and backspace keys. The keycaps are not that great and have no texture on top. They are quite smooth and if you have any moisture on your fingers, it will show a glossy reflection on the caps. This keyboard is so silent, especially for a mechanical keyboard! and It comes with a volume wheel. This is the only reason I spend an extra $25 on this keyboard over another low-profile tkl that uses a micro usb connection. For what I spent, I hoped I would have gotten a better quality keyboard, but for my use, this should do the trick at least for a while. I will update in a few months

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2021
review.title: Used? No manual. Loose, wrinkly tamper stickers. Odd S/N.
review.review: The keyboard itself has been incredible, which is why I left 3 stars, more on that soon.When it arrived, I was extremely excited to open its brand new packaging and most likely rate it 5 stars.However, it arrived with tamper stickers that definitely looked like the package had been opened at least once, and the manual listed on the box was missing. As a lesser concern, the serial number also didn't look anything like those listed in their website's software downloads.Opened tamper seals and not receiving everything listed on the box are generally huge red flags to me, which tend to be signs of refurbished items. Aside from that, it just seems like a product at full price should come in professional packaging with all the promised parts. If things have changed from what the packaging indicates, they could at least add a sticker stating that new products will have opened seals and missing manuals. For now, I'm not sure if my product is refurbished or used even though I payed full price.The keyboard itself works extremely well, and the brown switches feel wonderful to type on. The spacebar has a very light chirp when pressed, and I'm not sure if that's a sign of a refurbished item with a quirk in the stabilizer or if it's normal. However, it's barely noticeable and probably wouldn'taffect the review stars if I were certain it arrived brand new. There has been no key chatter, the keys feel very stable and crisp, and the build quality has been fantastic. The LEDs and the software have worked in a stable manner, even though it required downloading the "other" version of the GMMK software on their site, because the serial is very different from any of the mentioned ones. The small size of the TKL model feels much nicer than I expected it to and leaves a lot of desk space free compared to my old Razer BlackWidow.The product probably would have easily gotten 5/5, but it's unclear whether it's new and I'm not interested in refurbished products at full price even if they've only been touched once by a different owner, wearing gloves. There's a reason I purchase things new at full price.However, I refuse to deal with shipping hassles even if it's refurbished, and I also don't want to go without this type of keyboard while waiting for another, so it seems stuck here either way.It's a fantastic keyboard and I'd like to be certain it arrived brand new and not refurbished. A manual would have been especially useful for explaining things like the uses of the function key, along with tightly closed tamper seals or shrink wrap for a complete "everything listed on the sealed, professional package" feel.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2021
review.title: I love this keyboard.It isn't perfect, but I would certainly buy it again.
review.review: Reviewing the Glorious GMMK TKL (87 key) RGB model, black version, bought populated (not bare bones) through Amazon. The board is for my own use, I am not a paid reviewer. This is my third mechanical keyboard, and is by far the best of the three (vs Corsair & Rantopad).The keyboard feels solid and well-built. I have only had the board a few weeks so cannot comment on reliability. One reviewer mentioned ESD susceptibility in winter, so I plan to take ESD precautions in dry weather.Regarding the furnished keycaps, the translucent letters do not diffuse light as much as you'd think, so the lighting is considerably brighter when I sit up above the keyboard than it is if I slouch. This may be different if you use different keycaps. The keycap font is odd, but to me only a few keys are actually annoying:&, 8, 0, O, D and B.I can live with this for the time being; maybe in a year or so I will get new keycaps but I am not in a hurry.The RGB lighting is good, with only minor light bleed around the keys. If you want lots of light shining around the keys, buy a set of "pudding" keycaps (offered with the bare-bones version) that have clear surrounds; but personally I would find this distracting. But my keyboard sits next to a large north-facing window, lots of ambient light, and the keys are plenty bright for me.The stock Gateron Brown switches are very smooth, more smooth than their namesake Cherry MX Browns which feel scratchy to me. But in exchange for the smooth feel they are not very tactile, and pretty light (48 grams tactile peak, 36 grams at actuation and 52 grams to bottom).I am fine with this, but some people might want switches that are stiffer, perhaps more tactile, or perhaps clicky. If so, consider buying the bare-bones version of the board and adding the preferred switches separately.I am happy with the stock brown switches. I put some stiffer, clicky switches (Gateron green) in just a few places like caps lock and the windows & menu keys where I want to feel & hear when I've accidentally pressed one. Sawpping the switches out was easy.The software to set up custom key colors is OK but not well documented. I have had some problems with color profiles disappearing when the computer is restarted. Helpful hint: the "Apply" button doesn't acknowledge when you click it, but click it anyway. Otherwise the profile you've been working on may not be saved. Also be sure to close edit mode on one profile before opening another (you can have three profiles).PROS:>Well-built, quiet board>My connector is USB-C (I have the TKL 87-key board, bought August 2021)>Per-key RGB lighting with ability to switch between 3 custom lighting profiles>Can change switches without soldering / unsoldering – I have done this and it is easy>Can be purchased as bare-bones, allowing separate choice of switches and keycapsCONS:>USB-C connector fits rather loose and is easily bumped.>Software to program per-key colors has issues with save & restore, if you do subtle colors that aren't in the furnished 48-color palette you may need to write down RGB values and re-enter them.>The lighting is bright when viewed from above, but it is rather directional so it looks less bright (bu still bright enough) if I slouch back in my chair. Keycaps with more diffusive windows might help this.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2020
review.title: Excellent keyboard; however, see below
review.review: Two gripes I have with this keyboard:a.) (and this may be something which is now the norm for all mechanical keyboards) Keys are for TINY FINGERS.I am a 37 years-old woman, with average sized-hands for my 5'6" height, yet pretty narrow fingers, but I can barely type on this without hitting two keys at once.I had hoped for a similarly-featured keyboard to the "old-school" 80s/90s Apple keyboard.However, I can attest if you're looking for similar, be aware that the size of these individual keys is NOT COMPARABLE. Not sure whose fingers are being used to manufacture these keys, but they are lacking at least 2mm on either side of each key, resulting in the pads of my fingers hitting two keys at once nearly 4/5 of the time.Yes, I've tried modifying my "keystroke," to no avail.If you are a man (or a woman) with normal-to-wide sized finger 'pads', good luck.b.) If you happen to lose the little thingie which plugs into your laptop/pc to connect the keyboard, good luck.Getting in touch with these people is NOT GOING TO HAPPEN for you, because they do not respond to direct emails, emails through amazon, or phone calls (numbers given not valid).

There is also a power issue associated with it.I've been really communicative with the seller hoping to fix my board but they're very slow and their messages are not helpful. e.g. I send a request for help and their response time is three days "please hold fn+del for 3 seconds, the indicators will flash" I immediately respond "okay, I've done that many times and the indicators don't flash, what do I try now?"->"make sure the dongle is plugged into the USB port".A product like this should last more than one year.

I switch out the key caps for something to brighten up my desk and give a hint of personality but even the original key caps are of great quality!

review.title: Absolutely not.
review.review: This keyboard is awful.It works 60% of the time - keystrokes simply stop registering for seconds to minutes at a time, and then queue up and come out all at once later.The key images look like they were printed using spray paint and a stencil.The indicator lights for caps and num lock go off after less than a second - what is the point of an indicator light if I have to press the button anyway in order to get it to come on to indicate to me whether the lock is activated or not?I cannot believe I paid $100 for this piece of absolute flaming garbage.I wish I could throw it out, but it's too expensive.I now have to use two keyboards - a $20 keyboard I bought four years ago that works ten times better, and this thing, which I would not even use as a paperweight.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2021
review.title: Worked fine for a year, but starting to fail, cheaper quality than I expected
review.review: I like the overall feel of this keyboard, and it worked well for a year. The keyboard feels heavy and solid, so I had confidence in it working well and being reliable. However, lately the space bar has been acting up. It 'duds' sometimes causing the space bar to not travel straight down, especially when hitting it off center towards the right side.This is very annoying as space bar strokes are almost by definition (two hand typing) off-center. This is definitely something with the underlying mechanics in the keyboard or the stabilizing mounts.This has become a real nuisance, I am with some regularity missing entire space bar strokes, which is sadness, I liked this keyboard otherwise, but I am afraid I will have to junk it, missing 1 out of N key strokes is simply unacceptable.POST EDIT: I contacted the seller who advised to remove the space bar and clean the stabilizers, which didn't really help much, but now I have a 2nd problem that the Caps Lock and ESC keys sometimes output garbage which could either be indicators of dirt or short on the circuit, or a break in the circuit?It looks impossible to clean this keyboard internally without desoldering the whole thing, remvoing the external housing doesn't do much other than concluding that the board and is inaccessible, so if there were an issue that can be fixed, there is no way to get there

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2021
review.title: Great no-frills keyboard
review.review: My job went to permanent work from home, so it was time to up my game and get a really decent keyboard.This was surprisingly hard to find.I knew I wanted something like the IBM Model M.It had to be wired because my work PC doesn't play well with wireless devices.I didn't need or want rainbow backlighting.I just wanted a keyboard with a traditional layout that I could get some typing speed on.This fits the bill nicely.The keys don't snap quite like the Model M but I'm going to be on the phone a lot so it's a good compromise.It's good and heavy, it's not going anywhere.I read the other reviews but I had no problem with loose keys, it was packed well enough.I think maybe down the road I may wish there were more palm support but I can add something for that.If you want a keyboard that means business, if you are going to be on it 40 hours a week, and you like the old Model M, this could be a good choice.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 7, 2021
review.title: Excellent quality and had the "sound" I was looking for
review.review: I bought this keyboard to replace another that supposedly had anti-ghosting and key rollover; it did not (or it functioned poorly, one or the other). That is not the case with this keyboard. I do a lot of typing and I haven't had a single issue with missed keystrokes since I began using it.The quality of material is apparent out of the box. First, this is a hefty keyboard; while not a perfect indicator of quality, it's a sign that the manufacturer did not skimp on materials. The keycaps have a comfortable contour but are strong and secure enough to withstand the strokes I'm pounding out while composing the angriest of email replies.The best thing about the keyboard, in my opinion, is the sound. If you are buying Cherry MX Blue Switches, you should expect loud "click" with each keystrokes. If like me, you find that both audibly and tactilely pleasing, you will probably enjoy this keyboard.

review.title: Good keyboard overall with some quirks.
review.review: This is a sturdy keyboard with some good heft to it. Cherry MX switches perform as expected and with some decent quality caps. However, I have some qualms with the fit and finish. The pcb seems to be off-center inside the case, making the cutouts closer to one side. The escape key is almost rubbing the case on the right side. The usb C port has a loose fit that feels like it will wear out quickly, and the firmware built in is very confusing and unintuitive. However, at roughly half the cost of a WASD brand equivalent, I would say this is a good buy.

review.title: Big CHONK keyboard

product.title: iKBC MF108 v3 RGB LED Backlit Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Blue Switch for Windows and Mac, Full Size Computer Keybo...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2020
review.title: On another level
review.review: This keyboard is just incredible.You really have to have all of its ~5.5 lbs in front of you and under your fingers to really appreciate just how impressive and well-built it is, and how solid it feels.Once on your desk, it does NOT move.Unintended bonus in that regard is that in a pinch you could legitimately use it to fend off an attacker, or perhaps anchor a small-to-medium-sized yacht after a long day of offshore hacking.Got mine with MX Browns, and the typing experience is just about perfect, provided of course tactile switches are your jam.Height is not adjustable, but I did not find this to be an issue, and found it extremely pleasing to type on both as-is, as well as with a Glorious wooden wrist rest.I have medium to large-ish hands, FWIW.RGB is not insanely bright, but easily bright enough to do the job, and the effects are particularly wonderful.Doubleshot PBT backlit keycaps are a nice touch, and if you wanted to up your game in that regard, it is obviously a very easy upgrade.This is certainly not a budget keyboard, but you could honestly spend a lot more, and get a lot less.I would 100%, absolutely, unequivocally buy another one of these should anything happen to this.In fact, if that were ever not an option, I would happily rebuild this one from the ground up, soldering every darn switch and all, because of how enamored I am with the block aluminum case.If you're on the fence, don't be--you'll love it, and only wonder why you didn't buy it sooner.
product.title: iKBC MF108 v3 RGB LED Backlit Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Blue Switch for Windows and Mac, Full Size Computer Keybo...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2020
review.title: This is the one!

RGB is basic, but I don’t care. I just set to solid white lowest level and it’s perfect.Detachable USB-C.Cherry silent reds are perfect for gaming. I ended up replacing the switches with Zeal Zilent 65g for typing.I really wish iKBC still made the 68 key version of this keyboard as well.Anyway, you need to build a custom keyboard to get close to this quality. It’s a great value. Buy it.

review.title: Great build, not so great wireless
review.review: Solid build, nice feel, and has good battery life. However, as of recently (approx 8-10 months after purchase) the keyboard seems to be picking up a lot of wireless interference - keystrokes are either undetected or lag seriously at random moments.I've tried with multiple ports on my desktop (front/rear IO, USB2.0, USB3.0) but it keeps occurring, and the lack of a wired connection means that there's no real alternative to replacing it with a wired board. For people who know that they're using it in an area with reduced/no wireless 'noise', this is a great board - but if not, I'd suggest looking at something wired instead. This interference occurs enough that I would say even for typing/document work it's annoying enough to recommend avoiding.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2021
review.title: Keyboard Heaven for Typists
review.review: This plug and play wireless keyboard is heavenly, especially for those who spent their formative years using actual typewriters. I did not know mechanical keyboards were a thing until this past month. I've been geeking out on them since, and have tried several, with wireless being my essential requirement.As keyboard geeks know, this limits the selection. I sampled several different brands (with Brown, Red, and Topre switches) but was not too impressed and sent each of them back. Some used Bluetooth and establishing connections was not always easy. The dongle/2.4 setup is best for wireless.These Cherry Blues are heavenly and this iKBC keyboard is the One. The wireless works perfectly with no perceptible lag when I'm typing at 100 wpm. As for the Blues, they are (satisfyingly) loud but I work from home and my dog doesn't mind.Strong recommend on this keyboard.
product.title: iKBC W200 Wireless Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Blue Switch for Windows and Mac OS, Enables Media Key and LED Indica...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2021
review.title: Small keycaps?Odd complaint
review.review: 1.) "Small" keycaps.I was reading through the Amazon reviews on this keyboard and I was somewhat alarmed by the one that complained about the size of the keycaps.These keys are a very normal size.They width of the top of the key is .515" according to my calipers (13mm).2.) With or without number pad?So I use this keyboard with either a mouse or a touchpad sitting just to the right of the keyboard.Since I use the mouse/touchpad so frequently, I find that the reduced distance I need to travel in order to get to the keyboard/mouse is wonderful, so I recommend omitting the number pad.I have a second keyboard that has a number pad that I can pull out if I have a bunch of number data entry to do, but for daily typing tasks, I don't feel like I'm missing much by not having the number pad.3.) Feeling of the key action (aka the switches).I got the Cherry MX brown switches.They seem great, but I'm not a mechanical switch aficionado.I would love to have tried them all out side by side, but I'm happy with the browns.They aren't too loud, but they're definitely not silent.My laptop keyboard and my other keyboard (Microsoft wireless bluetooth keyboard) are both virtually silent.4.) Typing speed.I type pretty quickly, and although I feel like I'm still getting used to this bad boy, I find that the responsiveness is very good, and I did a quick typing test online to see the how I was doing on the new keys.The Microsoft keyboard requires quite a bit of force to depress each key.The Cherry browns are definitely a much lighter actuation force.I found that I was immediately able to type about 15-20% faster which I attribute mostly to the lighter key actuation force and the solidity of the keyboard.5.) Build quality.Last thing I'll mention is that this keyboard is heavy.It feels well built and I suspect that it will last me for a long long time.Maybe (hopefully) a lifetime.6.) Scratchiness on the keystroke.There was a complaint from another reviewer that the keys felt a little scratchy on the way down as they are being depressed (They compared the feeling to another mechanical keyboard that they had used which felt "silky smooth").I notice this as well.I'm not sure if it bothers me, but I agree that it is noticeable.All that said, I have only had the keyboard for a day, so take it with a grain of salt.We'll see what I think in a year about this guy.

product.title: iKBC Typemaster X410 White Backlit LED Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Low Profile Red Switch for Windows/Mac, Full Siz...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2021
review.title: Phenomenal! ...But Takes Some Getting Used To
review.review: Okay so I absolutely love this keyboard, no doubt about that now. It wasn't like that at first though.I initially purchased the keyboard for my first gaming desktop PC (avid longtime PC gamer, putting in 80-90 hours every week on average back on my gaming laptops) and I liked the black/white aesthetic that matched my PC and speakers, but also because of its minimalist design and THE VOLUME KNOB <3Upon first getting it and using it however, I found myself accidentally pressing other keys by accident because they aren't spaced very far apart and don't take a lot of force to press. Honestly I almost considered returning it after a few days because I hated all the misspellings I was making and having to correct.After a few weeks of usage though I suddenly realised that I wasn't making misspellings hardly at all anymore and my fingers had already memorised the placement of all the keys so I don't even look at the keyboard when I type now.So for anyone who just got this keyboard and is having a similar issue, just stick with it for a few more weeks and I promise you it gets better! For anyone on the fence about it, just be aware that you may have this issue at first but like I told the current users, you get used to the keyboard after a short while!Alright here's the Pros/Cons list: The Cons: - The narrow spacing between keys can lead to some accidental key presses in the early days of getting used to the keyboard - It isn't wireless (this may or may not be a con for some people, I personally don't care much) - Um... I think that's it?And the Pros: - Typing is pretty quiet compared to a lot of other keyboards! My roommate said he was glad I switched to this keyboard finally just because he could finally read in peace haha. Combine this keyboard with the Emopeak silent mouse and you've got a nice quiet setup, though that mouse may be a bit small for some people. - The ever-so-silky smooth volume knob! I honestly can't get over how nice the knob is. It has the perfect amount of resistance when turning it, its metal construction makes it feel very premium, and if you want to mute the volume, you can just press it down to mute instead of turning the knob to the left. I refuse to get another keyboard that doesn't have a volume knob. - The individually-backlit keys! There's plenty of lighting pattern customisation, from the speed of the animations to the brightness as well---and of course there is the ability to have the keys constantly illuminated or not at all. - The ability to set a PIN to unlock the keyboard when turning it on--to prevent any unwanted users accessing your keyboard/PC - Low profile makes it a good entry-level keyboard for long-time laptop users wanting to get into the desktop world. - Very portable since it has a low profile, isn't very large, and the USB-C to USB-A cable is detachable. - Media control buttons in the top right of the keyboard! I'd've preferred the Play button to be between the Previous and Next buttons instead of the button order being Play, Previous, Next. They still work great though and I love using these in conjunction with the volume knob when listening to music. - Also the calculator button, right next to the media control buttons. Didn't think this was something I'd put on the list of pros for a keyboard review but honestly I use it far more often than I ever thought I would. - Great build quality! I saw a previous 1-star review saying that many keys stopped working for them after a few weeks or months of use but I've been using my keyboard for 12-13 hours almost every single day now for over a year and I have had absolutely ZERO problems in all that time.So I'm not sure what that person may or may not have done to their keyboard or if they just happen to have received a faulty model but their case about their keyboard is definitely not something you should expect to find with your keyboard.Who knows, maybe they didn't read the manual and accidentally locked themselves out of their keyboard haha.Features: 10/10Ergonomics: Initial Use - 6/10, Later Use - 9/10Build Quality: 10/10 (so far still holding up with no issues whatsoever over a year later of constant usage)Portability: 10/10Would Recommend: 13.5/10

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2020
review.title: Key switches failing after 3 months - can't recommend
review.review: Pros:This keyboard has a nice feel to it, the key press is just the right weight and was a pleasure to use - for about two months.The volume control knob is exactly what I wanted and the reason I bought this keyboard in the first place. To many times have I gone from one video with super quiet audio to another that wants to blow my speakers. Having an audio dial that accessible is the solution I needed.Cons:I have at least three key switches that are causing issues after 3 months.The tab key either doesn't work at all or "bounces" (detects multiple triggers when only struck once) and sends multiple tab keys. As someone who uses tab to move between fields when filling forms and auto completing text, this has become quite a nuisance. Autocomplete in gmail has turned into auto-send an email before I'm done typing it.the shift key (and yes that non-capital at the beginning of this sentence is the issue) fails to work about one in ten times. Half the time I catch it and go back and have to fix it - slowing me down.The "j" key is super sensitive meaning if I brush it when putting my hands on the keyboard or while typing around it, I end up with a random j in the middle of the page.In short, I can't recomjmend this keyboard. It's caused a lot of issues and definitely not worth the $100 price tag.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2020
review.title: Day1 - It's what I wanted!
review.review: I have been using the Keychron K2 for a month or so now and I love it, my only gripe was the angled height of the keyboard, so I decided to try something low profile. Enter the iKBC cherry mx red tkl keyboard. Even after using mechanical keyboards for almost a year now, I still prefer thesatisfying tactile feedback of brown switches, nonetheless, the typing experience on the iKBC takes a little getting used to if you are coming from more traditional keyboards. The 3 biggest differences for me were the height of the keyboard (very comfortable without a wrist rest), the size of the keys (they look like they have been squashed down by Wreck it Ralph) and the unique sizing of the spacebar, enter and backspace keys. The keycaps are not that great and have no texture on top. They are quite smooth and if you have any moisture on your fingers, it will show a glossy reflection on the caps. This keyboard is so silent, especially for a mechanical keyboard! and It comes with a volume wheel. This is the only reason I spend an extra $25 on this keyboard over another low-profile tkl that uses a micro usb connection. For what I spent, I hoped I would have gotten a better quality keyboard, but for my use, this should do the trick at least for a while. I will update in a few months

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2021
review.title: Great Build, Awesome Feels!
review.review: DURGOD Taurus K320 TKL Review - White LEDs with Cherry MX Silent Black Switches:I am absolutely in love with this keyboard, and I am selling my old Razer BlackWidow Chroma.Clicky Clicky --> Mushy Silence.As an MK enthusiast, The switch type I ordered is Cherry MX Silent Black, one of the rarest types of switches on the market. I have been hunting a descent backlit TLK keyboard with Cherry Silent Black switch type for years. Most MK doesn't offer this switch type, which leaves me frustrated. The moment I found this Durgod Taurus K320 TKL with Cherry MX Silent Black was the moment that a dream finally came true. Major keyboard companies would sell an MX silent red, a lighter version. Whereas the Silent Black variants usually lost popularity and went out of stock. What a nightmare for someone like me - someone who plays the heavy keys. Those butterfly red switches are just not my taste.Speaking of the build quality, the best descriptions are sturdiness and elegance. I love the font of the letters on the keycaps. They are simple, clean, and professional-looking. I seriously dislike the lousy and overly exaggerating fonts founded on the keycaps of other brands' gaming keyboards. The keycaps are a perfect fit for the Cherry MX switches, made of double-shot PBT. They feel great to type on. In sum, I love this keyboard for two reasons. First, it offers a rare switch I enjoy. Second, the build quality is excellent.One minor problem I have is that the included USB-C to USB-C cable seems to be flawed. It doesn't have a very stable connection to my laptop and randomly disconnects. Amazon resolved it for me by giving me a new USB-C cable for free. Hence, no complaints, though I hoped that the factory-given cable could work in the first place.

This is pure white.The function keys are great (media controls on F1-F7).Comes with two very high quality cables (USB3 to USB-C, and USB-C to USB-C), which feature a little locking mechanism on the keyboard side.Nice quality rubber stabilizers and plastic risers, to allow you to use it at a pitch or flat.Packaging was good as well.Overall for the money, I am extremely pleased with this product.

product.title: Durgod Taurus K320 TKL Mechanical Gaming Keyboard - 87 Keys - Double Shot PBT - NKRO - USB Type C (Cherry Clear, Space Grey)

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2021
review.title: One of my favorite keyboards yet!
review.review: Over the last several months, I've really gotten into portable mechanical keyboards. The K320 is my 5th such keyboard and is by far my favorite! Though more expensive than some other options,BUILD QUALITYWhile the frame is plastic, it's a very durable plastic that is quite rigid, giving an overall "well-built" feel. There's no appreciable "deck flex" even with good pressure. The included keycaps are solid - with some other keyboards that I've bought on Amazon, I've noticed that the keycaps can be quite thin - with clear printing. Unlike some other reviewers, I didn't have any issues with the quality of printing on some of the keys. The included USB C cables seem well-built, though braided cables would've been a nice touch. Overall, though, the board seems durable, and I'm not worried about its ability to stand the test of time. 5/5PERFORMANCEI went with the Cherry Brown switches. This is my first board with Cherry Brown switches and I absolutely love them! Very nice tactile feel with a satisfying - but not deafening - click. They're heavy - and I do notice that my typing is about 10% slower compared to "faster" switches - but for long typing sessions, I do prefer the heavier actuation weight of the Brown switch.Other than the switches, this board performs as-expected. I haven't had any issues with an unstable USB connection, missed key presses, or any other issues with the individual switches themselves. This board is an absolute pleasure to type with. In fact, I bought it originally for my office, but I ended up loving it so much that I took it home and used one of my other keyboards for my office instead.I didn't try Durgod's firmware update tool so I can't speak about issues related to firmware upgrades. I didn't really see the point since I didn't have any issues with the board out of the box. 5/5OVERALLIf, like me, you're on the quest for a perfect keyboard for your PC setup, put this on your short list. While I haven't entered the premium keyboard market - which I would define as $150-200+ - this is definitely the best keyboard in the $100 or less price point that I've tried so far. Very happy with the purchase and strongly recommended!
product.title: Durgod Taurus K320 TKL Mechanical Gaming Keyboard - 87 Keys - Double Shot PBT - NKRO - USB Type C (Cherry Clear, Space Grey)

review.review: The springs inside the switches make a bit of a scratchy feeling and are slightly audible. Would be better if they were lubed. If it was hot swappable it would be a simple fix but sadly to fix the issue you have to disassemble the whole board. Sort of removes any cost savings.For 100$ seems ok but would be way better of an option if it was hot swap.Lighting is good, key caps feel decent. No software to do customization of lighting is a plus.If you want to mod at all, the board is not easy to separate so I'd look elsewhere for something like a drop board. Plus those are hot swap.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2021
review.title: NOT a gaming keyboard!
review.review: How in the hell did Logitech get away with labeling this as a gaming keyboard?It's "mechanical" keys are slimy feeling- just like membrane keys. A non-removable palm rest. And idk bout y'all but when I game, it's in the pitch black darkness. I need backlit keys or light of some kind! I'm good on this one. Returned and getting the 915 with beautiful clicky keys.And since I got the combo. the MX Master is not a BAD mouse either... it's ergonomically fitting to my hand, a nice change to the sometimes too-small gaming mice that Logitech designs for my bigger hands.. But the side scroll is defunct and the forward/back buttons are literally on top of each other in a diagonal fashion. This makes it very tough to hit the correct button the first time. Worst of all however is the fact the polling rate is only 125hz. They say you miss 100% of the shots you don't take.. well with this mouse you can take 100 shots and miss a damn well lot of them due to the low rate. Again, returning this as well and getting the G502 wireless.Logitech needs to rethink their branding for this keyboard/mouse. You can even see from a lot of the reviewers here, this is ideally an OFFICE keyboard/mouse setup. Not a gaming setup! The gaming equivalents are the G915 keyboard and G502 or G903 or G604 or G703 or.. y'know what? There's a lot of good logitech gaming mice out there.. But just 1 (wireless) gaming keyboard by logitech worth it's price.
product.title: Logitech G613 LIGHTSPEED Wireless Mechanical Gaming Keyboard, Multihost 2.4 GHz + Blutooth Connectivity - Black

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2021
review.title: Bought 2, switches went bad in both, manually soldering in new switches is a pain!
review.review: The first keyboard I purchased started having bad switch issues about 3 months in. The switches would routinely duplicate the letters, and at one point even the backspace key failed (same style switch). Thankfully the switches are replaceable with a little soldering skill, but this is a real nuisance. Because I was in a rush (and thinking Logitech may have just gotten a bad batch of switches during assembly), I bought a second keyboard, identical model, different batch. STILL having switch failures. On the original keyboard I have now replaced a total of EIGHT switches, on the newer one I've had to replace two.Until/unless Logitech gets better switches I would avoid this keyboard. I didn't bother going through customer service because I knew I could repair this issue myself, but not everyone has the tools or is handy. If you're handy and don't mind replacing switches, I've otherwise enjoyed the keyboard. Keystrokes are nice, responsiveness is excellent, and the range of the wireless is great. But c'mon Logitech, for the cost of this keyboard I shouldn't be having switch issues. Two stars because this is a serious flaw.
product.title: Logitech G613 LIGHTSPEED Wireless Mechanical Gaming Keyboard, Multihost 2.4 GHz + Blutooth Connectivity - Black

review.title: Mostly good things.
