review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2021
review.title: Bad Value, Skip It
review.review: The RPrepublic YC66 is a SLIGHTLY cheaper Womier K66 sent in a Womier branded box but with a worse value - The KC66 is a barebones kit I can't recommend to anyone when you look at the complete package.The YC66:-Not programmable-No switches-No keycaps-Build quality is poor-Acrylic plates misaligned-Bad stabilizers-Switches don't click inThe K66:-Not Programmable (sort of)-Switches included-Keycaps included-Build quality is poor-Bad stabilizers-Switches don't click inSame layout, same design, same materials - you're only saving about 10 dollars between the two but the added value in the K66 it is ready to go out of the box with switches and keycaps installed and the YC66 is barebones, you need your own switches and keycaps. Since the price difference is less than 10 dollars? if you decide to buy your own switches and keycaps, you'll be spending way more than 10 on switches alone, so think about that before making your decision.Now, aside from this observation between the two which are essentially the same keyboard - do I recommend it? No. The mechanical keyboard market keeps getting bigger and more accessible every month, I firmly believe there is better keyboards in this price range with better build quality and much more features for beginners or pros. I've been collecting and building keyboards for the past two years and one thing I've learned the hard way is looks don't conquer functionality and reliability. Don't let the RGB light show on this keyboard trap you into thinking this keyboard is worth it, explore your options, there is many, trust me, and much better.Save your money! bad value, bad build quality, less features than others in this price range - skip it.
product.title: hot swappable YC66 PCB Custom Mechanical Keyboard RGB SMD Switch LEDs Type c USB Port with Acrylic case RGB Side Light (YC...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2021
review.title: Great Hot Swappable RGB Keyboard but Sketchy Build Quality
review.review: The media could not be loaded. I wanted something hot swappable and this was one that caught my eye.I am not really a big RGB fan but it's fun to play around with and looks really good.Probably one of the better looking options.There are some color pattern presets you can mess around with and the option to make it light a single color.The stabs that come with it are surprisingly good with very little rattle.Space bar rattle is almost non existent if that's something you're concerned about.I was a little concerned about the PCB moving around in the case but once you put in your switches it's pretty stable.Speaking of the PCB.. There were actually some brownish red stains on it.It looked a little like dry blood.I was able to wipe off most of it.I am not sure what it was but hopefully nothing to worry about.Inserting the switches were easy and everything worked painlessly.My biggest downside is the build quality.Honestly the build is quite bad.I am not sure if I just got a defective unit but one of the acrylic plates particularly the one on top sadly seems to be shorter than the others in a noticeable way as can be seen by my photos.Actually all the plates seem to be slightly off in size and dont align perfectly.But honestly it's not really a deal breaker for me. I am still satisfied with the purchase but I think its worth mentioning.It does still feel quite solid with little flex.Just as an FYI.I am using Kailh Box Jade Switches with cherry profile pbt keycaps.Overall despite my issues, I can still recommend this keyboard.It is mostly because there arent many other options like this that are readily available.I do wish there was some better quality control.I mean, the PCB shouldn't have had any mystery stains on it and the acrylic plates should have been better aligned or at least the same size.
product.title: hot swappable YC66 PCB Custom Mechanical Keyboard RGB SMD Switch LEDs Type c USB Port with Acrylic case RGB Side Light (YC...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2020
review.title: Fantastic value
review.review: I'm swappin' switches like everyday. Lovely and sometimes OVER THE TOP rgb effects. The acrylic frame is great. Lube the stabilizers when you get it in and the thing will sound great! It's plastic so no case ping. South facing LEDs and support for all varieties of switch pin configuration. The only downside (and it's a doozy for some) is that it's not programmable. Not just the lights, but the inputs. I would love to reprogram the insert and delete keys to function as home and end, but I cannot. I think you can flash this to work with QMK, but do so at your own peril. You do have the ability to control volume and can access the function keys utilizing the function key + number row. If you're a programmer - forget about it! If you're a casual typist and gamer - you can really explore all of the keycaps and switches out there quite easily with this handsome board. Works great on Mac or PC.Comes in a nondescript case from china with two switches keeping the pcb in place. The USB C to A cable is fine. Oh, and you can turn off the RGB entirely.I really think this is a fabulous value if you lube the stabs and do not need key or RGB remapping.Enjoy!

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Excellent value for money, and great for productivity
review.review: I has used a Logitech solar powered keyboard for almost 4 years and fancied a change. I had seen so many reviews of mechanical keyboards. I was intrigued by the idea of switches that trigger in a linear way, sit higher up than the low laptop like solar powered keyboard, but not be full height and travel like a regular "gaming" keyboard. And this K60 LP is the perfect middle ground. Love the RGB, subtle but useful. I like the full layout as I use the num pad for work. Solid aluminium chassis. Only negative and I am being picky - it lacks media buttons and volume scroller, but you have access to volume and skip track vi FN+ F5 to F12 keys. The keys trigger at around the 0.8mm mark with is fantastic for touch typing. I love the choice I made. I added a wrist wrest to reduce pronation of my wrists when typing. Only downside is that at the office, I do not have this same keyboard... oh well.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2021
review.title: Review one month after purchase
review.review: To start out, I really like this keyboard. A lot of my comments follow what other reviews have said.Yes the keyboard is a bit loud as others have stated, but it isn't an issue for me, so I couldn't put it as a pro or con.Pros -The keyboard feels nice, it is heavy and feels like it has quality materials.The lighting controls work with the iCUE software and there are many customizable options and profiles.responsiveness of the keyboard is great.Cons -Unfortunately there are no ports on this keyboard, but I dont tend to use them myself. But this maybe a con for someone else.I have seen this issue on many other reviews and I have the same major issue. During the first month of use my A key (extremely important for gaming) started to experience key chatter, the key would register twice and when held the action would not be sustained. Fortunately for me I was still in the first month of use I got a free replacement with return. Because of this reason I had to give a 3/5 star review. As of today (10/4/21) I am sending the first unit back and am receiving the new unit this week.I will update this review with my experience going forward with the replacement.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2021
review.title: Defective after 5 months of use
review.review: This is my first mechanical keyboard, and in less than 5 months with moderate use it's basically bricked.The first 4.5 months were fine, no issues. Then about a week ago, an issue started where I'd hit the "r" key and would repeat two or three times with only a single press. After reaching out for help, they explained it may need cleaned. I do not eat anything near my keyboard and have never spilled anything on my desk, so figured this was unlikely but decided to try anyway. I pulled the key off, saw nothing on the board nor within the key itself, used canned air just in case, put it back together, and the same issue.If cleaning didn't work, the second option was to force the keyboard into "CRP_Disabled" drive and sent me files to replace the firmware.bin. Since I tried this, following their instructions step-by-step, my keyboard no longer works at all. No lights, no response, nothing. I tried different USB ports, reset my computer, tried a different computer, nothing. I can get it back to the "DRP_Disabled" drive but that's it.Not happy. I'll update if they respond to my latest email, however their initial response took 4 business days so I'm not holding my breath for a quick reply.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review.title: This is my favorite premade 60% board.
review.review: I own two and think they're great. The only way I'll switch is if I start making my own custom builds.Pros:* Programmable without software.I'm a Linux user so not having to use custom software that won't run on Linux is great.All of the customization is done directly on the board.* Tons of RGB settings. I'm not a big RGB guy but if you're into that, Ducky has you covered.* Lots of integrated functions onboard by default.For example, FN + WASD moves the mouse, FN + QE left/right clicks. FN + RF is mouse wheel up/down. FN + IJKL are the arrow keys.* Fully customizable.You can record macros or totally rearrange every key on the board if you want to.* Switches and stabilizers are lubed at the factory so it feels and sounds really nice for a premade board.* Two sets of adjustable feet for whatever incline you find most comfortable.Cons:* None. I love everything about this board.

review.title: Great build, not so great wireless
review.review: Solid build, nice feel, and has good battery life. However, as of recently (approx 8-10 months after purchase) the keyboard seems to be picking up a lot of wireless interference - keystrokes are either undetected or lag seriously at random moments.I've tried with multiple ports on my desktop (front/rear IO, USB2.0, USB3.0) but it keeps occurring, and the lack of a wired connection means that there's no real alternative to replacing it with a wired board. For people who know that they're using it in an area with reduced/no wireless 'noise', this is a great board - but if not, I'd suggest looking at something wired instead. This interference occurs enough that I would say even for typing/document work it's annoying enough to recommend avoiding.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2021
review.title: Keyboard Heaven for Typists
review.review: This plug and play wireless keyboard is heavenly, especially for those who spent their formative years using actual typewriters. I did not know mechanical keyboards were a thing until this past month. I've been geeking out on them since, and have tried several, with wireless being my essential requirement.As keyboard geeks know, this limits the selection. I sampled several different brands (with Brown, Red, and Topre switches) but was not too impressed and sent each of them back. Some used Bluetooth and establishing connections was not always easy. The dongle/2.4 setup is best for wireless.These Cherry Blues are heavenly and this iKBC keyboard is the One. The wireless works perfectly with no perceptible lag when I'm typing at 100 wpm. As for the Blues, they are (satisfyingly) loud but I work from home and my dog doesn't mind.Strong recommend on this keyboard.
product.title: iKBC W200 Wireless Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Brown Switch for Windows and Mac OS, Enables Media Key and LED Indic...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on March 6, 2021
review.title: Small keycaps?Odd complaint
review.review: 1.) "Small" keycaps.I was reading through the Amazon reviews on this keyboard and I was somewhat alarmed by the one that complained about the size of the keycaps.These keys are a very normal size.They width of the top of the key is .515" according to my calipers (13mm).2.) With or without number pad?So I use this keyboard with either a mouse or a touchpad sitting just to the right of the keyboard.Since I use the mouse/touchpad so frequently, I find that the reduced distance I need to travel in order to get to the keyboard/mouse is wonderful, so I recommend omitting the number pad.I have a second keyboard that has a number pad that I can pull out if I have a bunch of number data entry to do, but for daily typing tasks, I don't feel like I'm missing much by not having the number pad.3.) Feeling of the key action (aka the switches).I got the Cherry MX brown switches.They seem great, but I'm not a mechanical switch aficionado.I would love to have tried them all out side by side, but I'm happy with the browns.They aren't too loud, but they're definitely not silent.My laptop keyboard and my other keyboard (Microsoft wireless bluetooth keyboard) are both virtually silent.4.) Typing speed.I type pretty quickly, and although I feel like I'm still getting used to this bad boy, I find that the responsiveness is very good, and I did a quick typing test online to see the how I was doing on the new keys.The Microsoft keyboard requires quite a bit of force to depress each key.The Cherry browns are definitely a much lighter actuation force.I found that I was immediately able to type about 15-20% faster which I attribute mostly to the lighter key actuation force and the solidity of the keyboard.5.) Build quality.Last thing I'll mention is that this keyboard is heavy.It feels well built and I suspect that it will last me for a long long time.Maybe (hopefully) a lifetime.6.) Scratchiness on the keystroke.There was a complaint from another reviewer that the keys felt a little scratchy on the way down as they are being depressed (They compared the feeling to another mechanical keyboard that they had used which felt "silky smooth").I notice this as well.I'm not sure if it bothers me, but I agree that it is noticeable.All that said, I have only had the keyboard for a day, so take it with a grain of salt.We'll see what I think in a year about this guy.
product.title: iKBC W200 Wireless Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Brown Switch for Windows and Mac OS, Enables Media Key and LED Indic...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2020
review.title: Excellent keyboard; however, see below
review.review: Two gripes I have with this keyboard:a.) (and this may be something which is now the norm for all mechanical keyboards) Keys are for TINY FINGERS.I am a 37 years-old woman, with average sized-hands for my 5'6" height, yet pretty narrow fingers, but I can barely type on this without hitting two keys at once.I had hoped for a similarly-featured keyboard to the "old-school" 80s/90s Apple keyboard.However, I can attest if you're looking for similar, be aware that the size of these individual keys is NOT COMPARABLE. Not sure whose fingers are being used to manufacture these keys, but they are lacking at least 2mm on either side of each key, resulting in the pads of my fingers hitting two keys at once nearly 4/5 of the time.Yes, I've tried modifying my "keystroke," to no avail.If you are a man (or a woman) with normal-to-wide sized finger 'pads', good luck.b.) If you happen to lose the little thingie which plugs into your laptop/pc to connect the keyboard, good luck.Getting in touch with these people is NOT GOING TO HAPPEN for you, because they do not respond to direct emails, emails through amazon, or phone calls (numbers given not valid).

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2020
review.title: Best mechanical wireless keyboard
review.review: Why is it so hard to find a keyboard that:- Use an actual "mechanical" switch? (and I define that as "activates before bottoming out")- Is full-sized- Is wireless, but with a USB dongle and not Bluetooth (BT keyboards cannot access BIOS, bootloaders, flaky, uses more battery)- Runs on AA/AAA batteries (so that when battery runs out, a simple battery swap gets you back to work right away, as opposed to finding a charging cable and wait for it to charge for hours)This keyboard fits all of those, is solidly constructed, and have an unassuming look to boot. This is just the best keyboard for working people.

There is also a power issue associated with it.I've been really communicative with the seller hoping to fix my board but they're very slow and their messages are not helpful. e.g. I send a request for help and their response time is three days "please hold fn+del for 3 seconds, the indicators will flash" I immediately respond "okay, I've done that many times and the indicators don't flash, what do I try now?"->"make sure the dongle is plugged into the USB port".A product like this should last more than one year.

product.title: iKBC Typemaster X410 White Backlit LED Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Low Profile Red Switch for Windows/Mac, Full Siz...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2021
review.title: Phenomenal! ...But Takes Some Getting Used To
review.review: Okay so I absolutely love this keyboard, no doubt about that now. It wasn't like that at first though.I initially purchased the keyboard for my first gaming desktop PC (avid longtime PC gamer, putting in 80-90 hours every week on average back on my gaming laptops) and I liked the black/white aesthetic that matched my PC and speakers, but also because of its minimalist design and THE VOLUME KNOB <3Upon first getting it and using it however, I found myself accidentally pressing other keys by accident because they aren't spaced very far apart and don't take a lot of force to press. Honestly I almost considered returning it after a few days because I hated all the misspellings I was making and having to correct.After a few weeks of usage though I suddenly realised that I wasn't making misspellings hardly at all anymore and my fingers had already memorised the placement of all the keys so I don't even look at the keyboard when I type now.So for anyone who just got this keyboard and is having a similar issue, just stick with it for a few more weeks and I promise you it gets better! For anyone on the fence about it, just be aware that you may have this issue at first but like I told the current users, you get used to the keyboard after a short while!Alright here's the Pros/Cons list: The Cons: - The narrow spacing between keys can lead to some accidental key presses in the early days of getting used to the keyboard - It isn't wireless (this may or may not be a con for some people, I personally don't care much) - Um... I think that's it?And the Pros: - Typing is pretty quiet compared to a lot of other keyboards! My roommate said he was glad I switched to this keyboard finally just because he could finally read in peace haha. Combine this keyboard with the Emopeak silent mouse and you've got a nice quiet setup, though that mouse may be a bit small for some people. - The ever-so-silky smooth volume knob! I honestly can't get over how nice the knob is. It has the perfect amount of resistance when turning it, its metal construction makes it feel very premium, and if you want to mute the volume, you can just press it down to mute instead of turning the knob to the left. I refuse to get another keyboard that doesn't have a volume knob. - The individually-backlit keys! There's plenty of lighting pattern customisation, from the speed of the animations to the brightness as well---and of course there is the ability to have the keys constantly illuminated or not at all. - The ability to set a PIN to unlock the keyboard when turning it on--to prevent any unwanted users accessing your keyboard/PC - Low profile makes it a good entry-level keyboard for long-time laptop users wanting to get into the desktop world. - Very portable since it has a low profile, isn't very large, and the USB-C to USB-A cable is detachable. - Media control buttons in the top right of the keyboard! I'd've preferred the Play button to be between the Previous and Next buttons instead of the button order being Play, Previous, Next. They still work great though and I love using these in conjunction with the volume knob when listening to music. - Also the calculator button, right next to the media control buttons. Didn't think this was something I'd put on the list of pros for a keyboard review but honestly I use it far more often than I ever thought I would. - Great build quality! I saw a previous 1-star review saying that many keys stopped working for them after a few weeks or months of use but I've been using my keyboard for 12-13 hours almost every single day now for over a year and I have had absolutely ZERO problems in all that time.So I'm not sure what that person may or may not have done to their keyboard or if they just happen to have received a faulty model but their case about their keyboard is definitely not something you should expect to find with your keyboard.Who knows, maybe they didn't read the manual and accidentally locked themselves out of their keyboard haha.Features: 10/10Ergonomics: Initial Use - 6/10, Later Use - 9/10Build Quality: 10/10 (so far still holding up with no issues whatsoever over a year later of constant usage)Portability: 10/10Would Recommend: 13.5/10

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2020
review.title: Key switches failing after 3 months - can't recommend
review.review: Pros:This keyboard has a nice feel to it, the key press is just the right weight and was a pleasure to use - for about two months.The volume control knob is exactly what I wanted and the reason I bought this keyboard in the first place. To many times have I gone from one video with super quiet audio to another that wants to blow my speakers. Having an audio dial that accessible is the solution I needed.Cons:I have at least three key switches that are causing issues after 3 months.The tab key either doesn't work at all or "bounces" (detects multiple triggers when only struck once) and sends multiple tab keys. As someone who uses tab to move between fields when filling forms and auto completing text, this has become quite a nuisance. Autocomplete in gmail has turned into auto-send an email before I'm done typing it.the shift key (and yes that non-capital at the beginning of this sentence is the issue) fails to work about one in ten times. Half the time I catch it and go back and have to fix it - slowing me down.The "j" key is super sensitive meaning if I brush it when putting my hands on the keyboard or while typing around it, I end up with a random j in the middle of the page.In short, I can't recomjmend this keyboard. It's caused a lot of issues and definitely not worth the $100 price tag.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2020
review.title: Exactly what I was looking for.
review.review: Alright, so simply put if you are like me, you wanted a keyboard with the following features: - Compact - Quality built with quality mechanical switches - No gaudy, flashy design elements.I love this keyboard because it's simple, works just how I wanted and needed, without being overstated.I personally can't stand the gaudy RGB backlights, and I'm really happy this has simple white, well made larger keycaps, that you can tell are double-shot so the lettering or some cheap paint won't wear off.The board itself just feels sturdy, yes it's made of plastic, but that's really not a downside.It's quiet, which for me is what I wanted.I don't mind the clack of mechanical, but in a shared space, it gets annoying.This keyboard is pretty much whisper quiet.I really love this board and would recommend it for anyone.1 year later updateStill agree with all of the above, I game with this keyboard all the time, it's held up SUPER well, and is great when I need a compact working space.
product.title: iKBC Typemaster X410 White Backlit LED Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Low Profile Red Switch for Windows/Mac, Full Siz...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2020
review.title: Day1 - It's what I wanted!
review.review: I have been using the Keychron K2 for a month or so now and I love it, my only gripe was the angled height of the keyboard, so I decided to try something low profile. Enter the iKBC cherry mx red tkl keyboard. Even after using mechanical keyboards for almost a year now, I still prefer thesatisfying tactile feedback of brown switches, nonetheless, the typing experience on the iKBC takes a little getting used to if you are coming from more traditional keyboards. The 3 biggest differences for me were the height of the keyboard (very comfortable without a wrist rest), the size of the keys (they look like they have been squashed down by Wreck it Ralph) and the unique sizing of the spacebar, enter and backspace keys. The keycaps are not that great and have no texture on top. They are quite smooth and if you have any moisture on your fingers, it will show a glossy reflection on the caps. This keyboard is so silent, especially for a mechanical keyboard! and It comes with a volume wheel. This is the only reason I spend an extra $25 on this keyboard over another low-profile tkl that uses a micro usb connection. For what I spent, I hoped I would have gotten a better quality keyboard, but for my use, this should do the trick at least for a while. I will update in a few months

review.title: Low quality
review.review: Interesting design that doesn't quite work.The C and O keys had key chatter (key input rrrrrrepeats itself beyond key-press) out of the box.There is near-zero gap between keys, so you will often press neighboring keys by accident.The two shift keys have a very irritating clicking sound as a result of bottoming-out, while apparently all other keys are OK (have the expected low "thunk" sound).After a mere 7 days of use, the keyboard starts to feel different, though I am not sure if this is a defect of the switch or the keys.The switch itself seems OKAY; I prefer my gateron reds which still feel smooth after a year of use.Overall, disappointed and would not recommend at the $100 price-point.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2021
review.title: Good keyboard overall with some quirks.
review.review: This is a sturdy keyboard with some good heft to it. Cherry MX switches perform as expected and with some decent quality caps. However, I have some qualms with the fit and finish. The pcb seems to be off-center inside the case, making the cutouts closer to one side. The escape key is almost rubbing the case on the right side. The usb C port has a loose fit that feels like it will wear out quickly, and the firmware built in is very confusing and unintuitive. However, at roughly half the cost of a WASD brand equivalent, I would say this is a good buy.

review.title: Big CHONK keyboard
review.review: I've used this keyboard for about 3 months, and it's extremely durable and spectacular to type on.The included PBT keycaps don't shine like my old ABS keycaps used to, which is a huge plus, and I love the fact they upgraded to a removeable USB C cable for this revision.The color controls are a bit confusing at first, but all the keys are programmable and have a variety of RGB functions.I would highly recommend to anyone looking to buy a solid brick of a keyboard.
product.title: iKBC MF108 v3 RGB LED Backlit Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Brown Switch for Windows and Mac, Full Size Computer Keyb...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2020
review.title: On another level
review.review: This keyboard is just incredible.You really have to have all of its ~5.5 lbs in front of you and under your fingers to really appreciate just how impressive and well-built it is, and how solid it feels.Once on your desk, it does NOT move.Unintended bonus in that regard is that in a pinch you could legitimately use it to fend off an attacker, or perhaps anchor a small-to-medium-sized yacht after a long day of offshore hacking.Got mine with MX Browns, and the typing experience is just about perfect, provided of course tactile switches are your jam.Height is not adjustable, but I did not find this to be an issue, and found it extremely pleasing to type on both as-is, as well as with a Glorious wooden wrist rest.I have medium to large-ish hands, FWIW.RGB is not insanely bright, but easily bright enough to do the job, and the effects are particularly wonderful.Doubleshot PBT backlit keycaps are a nice touch, and if you wanted to up your game in that regard, it is obviously a very easy upgrade.This is certainly not a budget keyboard, but you could honestly spend a lot more, and get a lot less.I would 100%, absolutely, unequivocally buy another one of these should anything happen to this.In fact, if that were ever not an option, I would happily rebuild this one from the ground up, soldering every darn switch and all, because of how enamored I am with the block aluminum case.If you're on the fence, don't be--you'll love it, and only wonder why you didn't buy it sooner.
product.title: iKBC MF108 v3 RGB LED Backlit Mechanical Keyboard with Cherry MX Brown Switch for Windows and Mac, Full Size Computer Keyb...

I ended up replacing the switches with Zeal Zilent 65g for typing.I really wish iKBC still made the 68 key version of this keyboard as well.Anyway, you need to build a custom keyboard to get close to this quality. review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2021
review.title: NOT a gaming keyboard!
review.review: How in the hell did Logitech get away with labeling this as a gaming keyboard?It's "mechanical" keys are slimy feeling- just like membrane keys. A non-removable palm rest. And idk bout y'all but when I game, it's in the pitch black darkness. I need backlit keys or light of some kind! I'm good on this one. Returned and getting the 915 with beautiful clicky keys.And since I got the combo. the MX Master is not a BAD mouse either... it's ergonomically fitting to my hand, a nice change to the sometimes too-small gaming mice that Logitech designs for my bigger hands.. But the side scroll is defunct and the forward/back buttons are literally on top of each other in a diagonal fashion. This makes it very tough to hit the correct button the first time. Worst of all however is the fact the polling rate is only 125hz. They say you miss 100% of the shots you don't take.. well with this mouse you can take 100 shots and miss a damn well lot of them due to the low rate. Again, returning this as well and getting the G502 wireless.Logitech needs to rethink their branding for this keyboard/mouse. You can even see from a lot of the reviewers here, this is ideally an OFFICE keyboard/mouse setup. Not a gaming setup! The gaming equivalents are the G915 keyboard and G502 or G903 or G604 or G703 or.. y'know what? There's a lot of good logitech gaming mice out there.. But just 1 (wireless) gaming keyboard by logitech worth it's price.
product.title: Logitech G613 LIGHTSPEED Wireless Mechanical Gaming Keyboard, Multihost 2.4 GHz + Blutooth Connectivity - Black

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2021
review.title: Bought 2, switches went bad in both, manually soldering in new switches is a pain!
review.review: The first keyboard I purchased started having bad switch issues about 3 months in. The switches would routinely duplicate the letters, and at one point even the backspace key failed (same style switch). Thankfully the switches are replaceable with a little soldering skill, but this is a real nuisance. Because I was in a rush (and thinking Logitech may have just gotten a bad batch of switches during assembly), I bought a second keyboard, identical model, different batch. STILL having switch failures. On the original keyboard I have now replaced a total of EIGHT switches, on the newer one I've had to replace two.Until/unless Logitech gets better switches I would avoid this keyboard. I didn't bother going through customer service because I knew I could repair this issue myself, but not everyone has the tools or is handy. If you're handy and don't mind replacing switches, I've otherwise enjoyed the keyboard. Keystrokes are nice, responsiveness is excellent, and the range of the wireless is great. But c'mon Logitech, for the cost of this keyboard I shouldn't be having switch issues. Two stars because this is a serious flaw.
product.title: Logitech G613 LIGHTSPEED Wireless Mechanical Gaming Keyboard, Multihost 2.4 GHz + Blutooth Connectivity - Black

Unfortunately it is sending random key inputs I have a wired mouse G600 and was using a wired keyboards G710 and G13 with no issues. The G613 is now on the back up CPU and I’m back to the G710.

review.title: Seems good so far
review.review: + Keycaps seem solid/sturdy - Matt type material+ Gateron brown feels similar to MX Brown with very slight difference in actuation force+ No technical problems .. Keyboard is not defective+ Enjoying the 75% size for FPS gaming- There is a slight curve on keyboard. It's not a straight incline plane from the F keys to spacebar. There's a slight curve in the middle. I prefer the straight inclined. It's not super pronounced so it doesn't bother me that much.Keyboard stand at bottom is not necessary. Makes the already thick keyboard even taller off the ground, hard to type because of the curve plus the extra angle.Keyboard already raised at the back near the F keys by design of its case. Adding the stand makes it even more raised at the back.Overall decent gaming and compact keyboard style. Keycaps are smaller than fullsize keyboard. I don't know if they make a 75% that has full sized keycaps but these smaller keycaps are pretty easy to type on.

I would like to make note I use it for my TV and sometimes for my PC as well.)Anyway this one doesn't hold a good charge before you have to plug it in again.I might as well just have a plugged-in keyboard at this point.2. When you open the battery compartment there's solid plastic there. You have to completely disassemble this dumpster fire of a keyboard to realize that there's now a soldered in lithium battery there. review.title: Love it but a few small problems
review.review: Pros:I love that you can light each individual key, it really does help me finding the pointer finger keys when typing in the dark and I go to hit ='s while still holding the mouse in my right hand, or other weird situations like that.I like that the software has a macro and the hyper shift function that allows me to switch multiple keys with the click of one.I like the clicking it makes and mid actuation, it helps a little when doing speed runs and just working on being smooth overall.Cons:My "s"button don't click completely and my "k" button doesn't making a clicking noises unless pushed down right. I can over look this but still worth noting.The two small things that irritate me the most about this keyboard is that because of the length of the spacebar and the fact that it's only supported under the middle, it sits tiled slightly and looks curved sometimes. The second thing is that I am able to click the key but not actually get the response from the switch underneath, so sometimes I get the audible click of the key but miss that fraction of length to also hit the switch to actually type the letter.Also there is one cntrl key with a small jagged edge on arrival.

review.title: Don't use it, it's misuse.
review.review: Screw this company. Bought a keyboard just over a year ago. The Ornata and in the last week one of the keys stopped clicking, so I remove the keycap and find that the tiny plastic knob that holds the metal clicker down was worn down to the point it couldn't hold the metal clicker in place. I filed a warranty claim and they said it was MY fault that I somehow misused it. "after careful inspection and investigation they deemed the damage as a customer induced."You mean, gaming and typing 7 days a week is misuse on a keyboard?Then they spout this bull crap at me "Please understand that the main reason we cannot honor your request is that doing so would not be fair to all of our customers who purchased a RazerCare Plan who covers customer induced damage cases."Customer induced damages my ass. Maybe poor craftsmanship or poor design. They even show you an image of how the key is made and there are two tiny knobs that hold the metal piece in place. Design flaw at best but saying it was customer induced damage. I totally understand, I'm not valued as a customer who has purchased a LOT of their products over the years and I get it. They don't even make the older Ornata and don't want to send a customer a V2 replacement. Buyer beware, gaming/writing/typing over 40hrs a week is misuse on a keyboard with a flaw in design. There are grooves in the tabs above the metal clicker piece.Guess the metal piece won against plastic. Go figure.I'm pretty sure the Ornata V2 is designed the exact same way. But, it's MY FAULT it happened.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2021
review.title: Died in 5 minutes
review.review: I'm not exaggerating, it literately stopped working in around 5 minutes. I had it plugged into my desktop and the lights turned off after just a few minutes. I thought maybe my computer went to sleep, nope. I tried unplugging and plugging it back in on both ends of the usb cable nothing and lights wouldn't come back on. Tried another usb C to A cable, didn't work. Took it and plugged it into my Razer Blade laptop and nothing. The keyboard feels and sounds great, but considering it didn't last for me beyond 10 minutes I can't call it good which sucks because the typing feels and sounds great! So for now, I've plugged back in my reliable $15 Walmart keyboard.Next day editAfter fiddling with it some more it would seem the usb c port on the keyboard is where the problem is. I can get Windows to detect the keyboard if I wiggle the plugged in cable provided but it rapidly connects and disconnects and the lights on the keyboard flash. It doesn't stay on long enough for Windows to set it up. So I'm not sure if this is a quality or shipping issue, but either way still disappointing. I also tried multiple other usb cables and they didn't help. I actually had better luck with the cable provided, but still not enough to get it to stay on.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2021
review.title: Great Build, Awesome Feels!
review.review: DURGOD Taurus K320 TKL Review - White LEDs with Cherry MX Silent Black Switches:I am absolutely in love with this keyboard, and I am selling my old Razer BlackWidow Chroma.Clicky Clicky --> Mushy Silence.As an MK enthusiast, The switch type I ordered is Cherry MX Silent Black, one of the rarest types of switches on the market. I have been hunting a descent backlit TLK keyboard with Cherry Silent Black switch type for years. Most MK doesn't offer this switch type, which leaves me frustrated. The moment I found this Durgod Taurus K320 TKL with Cherry MX Silent Black was the moment that a dream finally came true. Major keyboard companies would sell an MX silent red, a lighter version. Whereas the Silent Black variants usually lost popularity and went out of stock. What a nightmare for someone like me - someone who plays the heavy keys. Those butterfly red switches are just not my taste.Speaking of the build quality, the best descriptions are sturdiness and elegance. I love the font of the letters on the keycaps. They are simple, clean, and professional-looking. I seriously dislike the lousy and overly exaggerating fonts founded on the keycaps of other brands' gaming keyboards. The keycaps are a perfect fit for the Cherry MX switches, made of double-shot PBT. They feel great to type on. In sum, I love this keyboard for two reasons. First, it offers a rare switch I enjoy. Second, the build quality is excellent.One minor problem I have is that the included USB-C to USB-C cable seems to be flawed. It doesn't have a very stable connection to my laptop and randomly disconnects. Amazon resolved it for me by giving me a new USB-C cable for free. Hence, no complaints, though I hoped that the factory-given cable could work in the first place.
product.title: Durgod Taurus K320 TKL Mechanical Gaming Keyboard - 87 Keys - Double Shot PBT - NKRO - USB Type C (Cherry Brown, Space Grey)

review.title: Great keyboard for the price.
review.review: Felt compelled to review this one. I've been using a Daskeyboard Professional for a long long time, with Cherry MX Blues.Bought this keyboard for use for a secondary computer which manages my server, and I absolutely love it. The Cherry MX Browns I chose for this one perform exactly as you might expect.I bought the white and grey. From the photos I was expecting an off white/light grey and dark grey, but really it's a bright white with a dark grey. So if you want a more eggshell / retro color, keep that in mind. This is pure white.The function keys are great (media controls on F1-F7).Comes with two very high quality cables (USB3 to USB-C, and USB-C to USB-C), which feature a little locking mechanism on the keyboard side.Nice quality rubber stabilizers and plastic risers, to allow you to use it at a pitch or flat.Packaging was good as well.Overall for the money, I am extremely pleased with this product.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2021
review.title: One of my favorite keyboards yet!
review.review: Over the last several months, I've really gotten into portable mechanical keyboards. The K320 is my 5th such keyboard and is by far my favorite! Though more expensive than some other options,BUILD QUALITYWhile the frame is plastic, it's a very durable plastic that is quite rigid, giving an overall "well-built" feel. There's no appreciable "deck flex" even with good pressure. The included keycaps are solid - with some other keyboards that I've bought on Amazon, I've noticed that the keycaps can be quite thin - with clear printing. Unlike some other reviewers, I didn't have any issues with the quality of printing on some of the keys. The included USB C cables seem well-built, though braided cables would've been a nice touch. Overall, though, the board seems durable, and I'm not worried about its ability to stand the test of time. 5/5PERFORMANCEI went with the Cherry Brown switches. This is my first board with Cherry Brown switches and I absolutely love them! Very nice tactile feel with a satisfying - but not deafening - click. They're heavy - and I do notice that my typing is about 10% slower compared to "faster" switches - but for long typing sessions, I do prefer the heavier actuation weight of the Brown switch.Other than the switches, this board performs as-expected. I haven't had any issues with an unstable USB connection, missed key presses, or any other issues with the individual switches themselves. This board is an absolute pleasure to type with. In fact, I bought it originally for my office, but I ended up loving it so much that I took it home and used one of my other keyboards for my office instead.I didn't try Durgod's firmware update tool so I can't speak about issues related to firmware upgrades. I didn't really see the point since I didn't have any issues with the board out of the box. 5/5OVERALLIf, like me, you're on the quest for a perfect keyboard for your PC setup, put this on your short list. While I haven't entered the premium keyboard market - which I would define as $150-200+ - this is definitely the best keyboard in the $100 or less price point that I've tried so far. Very happy with the purchase and strongly recommended!
product.title: Durgod Taurus K320 TKL Mechanical Gaming Keyboard - 87 Keys - Double Shot PBT - NKRO - USB Type C (Cherry Brown, Space Grey)

review.title: Non rgb one is probably worth it
review.review: The springs inside the switches make a bit of a scratchy feeling and are slightly audible. Would be better if they were lubed. I don't notice while typing but playing games you can feel it and then once you do you can't forget about it. If it was hot swappable it would be a simple fix but sadly to fix the issue you have to disassemble the whole board. Sort of removes any cost savings.For 100$ seems ok but would be way better of an option if it was hot swap.Lighting is good, key caps feel decent. No software to do customization of lighting is a plus.If you want to mod at all, the board is not easy to separate so I'd look elsewhere for something like a drop board. Plus those are hot swap.

review.title: Lives up to tank-like reputation, solid construction. But 170 and no backlighting?
review.review: I was drawn in by the reviews, and was impressed with the setup and quality. It really is Mac native and solidly built. I found the Cherry Brown's a bit lack luster for my taste, but that's subjective, you may love them. I found the volume knob nifty and satisfying to use. Most glaring criticism, was the lack of back-lighting. At this price, (170), you'd expect at least white LED backit keys for working in dark rooms. There are much other options out there just as well built going for 30-60 dollars less that include backlighting which you can turn off if not to your liking.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2021
review.title: Great Mechanical Keyboard
review.review: Great feedback from the buttons and volume knob. It reminds me of the old keyboards I grew up with in the early 90's but, MUCH more refined. I love the noise it makes when I'm typing quick. It's such a pleasant sound. "The perfect amount of noise, the perfect amount of feedback, the perfect WEIGHT." The construction is what you would expect from a keyboard in this price-point. It's extremely solid, stays planted on my glass desk. Nothing feels cheap about it. It's fairly heavy. There is a magnetic ruler that is under the keyboard that is used to prop it up. I wish there was more adjustability for keyboard angle but, I can't knock a star off for that. It's such a great experience. Also, the cord is slightly ridgid and has a fairly large diameter. To some this may not mean much but, it doesn't appear to be something fragile. As in, my 3 year old could drag the keyboard around the house by the cord and I doubt the cord would be damage at all. One thing I can add (that may be something to look at in future revisions of this keyboard) is about the 'sleep, mute, previous, play/pause, next' buttons. It would be nice if they had more of a mechanical feel too. I would love to try the different mechanical buttons from Das Keyboard just to compare them. If you are on the fence, you won't be disappointed. This is worth the price of entry.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2021
review.title: Amazing typing feel if you like tall keys. (cherry brown)
review.review: Very solid feeling keys and great key action. The cherry brown switches have a very light touch and soft tactile bump. If you have good form then they will work well. I am not a great typist so I tend to hit adjacent keys sometimes due to the high key height. Not the KB's fault. A good typist will love the quick feel and light touch. The fonts are very standard and easy to see.I noticed the "s" key started out scratchy but has improved after a few hours. I assume breaking in the KB will help but I would expect for the price all keys should be silky from the start. By scratchy I mean the key seems to have an annoying resistance/stick at the top of the stroke especially if you hit the key off-center. It is still about 50% noticeable after a few hours of continuous use.The height is adjusted by a ruler gimmick which now has feet to prevent sliding. This is a really dumb feature.Overall I would keep the keyboard if the keys break in nicely. For the price I would expect a more refined product. Perhaps a used KB would be worth it.

review.title: Worn out switches after two years
review.review: Using the keyboard itself has been fine.Hefty, nice aluminum finish, I like the feel of the keys.Unfortunately, after two years of typical office use, a couple of keys started chattering (sending double key presses).No big deal, just order some Cherry MX Browns and swap them out like on other enthusiast mechanical keyboards, right? WRONG.THE KEY SWITCHES ARE SOLDERED ON.It's repairable, but what a gigantic pain in the rear.And since I ordered it on Amazon, it's outside of Das Keyboard's warranty period.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2021
review.title: Keyboard Built for TYPING!
review.review: I purchased this keyboard to replace a water-damaged Logitech G610 that I really liked. I wanted a backlit mechanical keyboard built for TYPING, not GAMING. Unfortunately, this keyboard IS NOT backlit, but I knew that when I purchased it.I'm an IT professional that spends 8 hours a day interacting with my keyboard, so it is essential that it works properly and has a good feel. My particular keyboard is shared with several other computers through a KVM switch, so I wanted something that would just work without installing a bunch of stuff on every computer. (I have a mixture of Macs and PCs). The media controls are a bonus and work on all the computers as expected. The blue NUMLOCK/CAPSLOCK indicators are almost too bright, but if you aren't looking at them directly, they are fine.

review.review: I've been using this keyboard for 9 months.Ordered this keyboard to pair with my new Mac Mini. i do not do a bunch of gaming. i bought this as my primary keyboard. i use it when i telework. Good: I really like that it has a switch to use as a Mac keyboard and take advantage of the key shortcuts (e.g. command-n). i like the mechanical feel - it has a great feel for typing.probably works great as a gaming keyboard.issues:it drains the battery in ~2 days.i could go in and mess with the light settings, turn it off every night or when i'm not using it to extend battery life, but thats a pain and not what i need for a daily use, home office keyboard.sometimes i just connect it and use it as a usb-c keyboard because i get tired of having to charge it. it is loud. others can hear it during a zoom or teams meeting. i will probably buy a different keyboard that is a better keyboard for daily and home office use.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2021
review.title: Good for gaming and everyday use, just a minor catch for productivity.
review.review: First off, don't get me wrong at all, this is a great keyboard, low profile switches, low profile case, and its low profile keycaps, it's cool. But specifically for my use case, there was a killer catch that made me return it the next day. That catch is that the keyboard is missing three keys on top of the home/end/inset group which are the print screen, scroll lock, and pause buttons. Honestly, I didn't even know they weren't in the keyboard to begin with, but only after I started using it, I found out that it wasn't there, which impacted my productivity heavily since I have them bound as shortcuts and macros for other programs. So for me, the removal of those keys was the killing catch, but to other people who may not care about the keys and only use the keyboard for gaming or everyday use that's not for productivity, then it would be a solid catch, but this keyboard just isn't for me. And after finding out that almost all Keychron keyboards don't have the three keys, I may not be able to buy any of their keyboards because of the loss of that feature.I even tried looking all over the internet for ways around it, but I just couldn't find a way that made it work well for my use case, so I just couldn't use it anymore, and therefore also don't recommend this keyboard for people who use those keys.

review.title: Worked well for 9 months, then stopped functioning
review.review: I really loved this keyboard - took some getting used to in terms of the format (it's smaller than a traditional keyboard) but nice and compact for my small work from home desk. the backlight is great, and the keys all have great action -- nice bounce-back and depth. Major downside is the battery life - it can go dead in under two weeks of normal use, so keep that charger handy. When it dies, it does take several minutes of charging to get back to life so you can start using it.The feel of typing is definitely an acquired taste, but one that I quite enjoy now. However, it mysteriously stopped working. I am hoping that the manufacturer or seller gets back to me to troubleshoot or do a warranty replacement. Definitely should last longer than 9 months!

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2021
review.title: Excellent keyboard for both gaming and productivity at half the price
review.review: Picked up the Gateron Red version, and I am extremely happy with this purchase so far. The keys are nice and responsive, they feel great and the quality of the switches are consistent between the keys. The red switches are decently quiet while still being satisfying with a low clunk while bottoming out the key, and it is quieter then my previous keyboard which is a selling point for me. One weird thing was that when I pulled my keyboard out of the box, I had to push down about half of the keys to make sure they were fully seated properly, but that wasn't a big deal.I picked up a Bluetooth receiver for my gaming desktop to use it wirelessly and reduce the amount of cable clutter and it has worked excellently. I haven't had any of the common connectivity issues such laggy inputs, missing inputs, double inputs, and I have multiple other wireless devices at my desk. For gaming, there is no noticeable latency over Bluetooth, even in fast-paced and reaction based games like FPS's. As long as you're not a heavy competitive gamer where the additional 10-20ms of wireless latency of Bluetooth 5.0 vs a wired connection could be an actual concern, I doubt you will ever notice it, but if that is something you care about then just keep it wired.I spent a long time researching wireless mechanical keyboard for both productivity and gaming. It was between this and the Logitech G915. I can honestly say I don't believe I would have liked that keyboard much more then I am enjoying the Keychron K4, and this is coming from a Logitech fan, and at 1/2 the price, I couldn't be happier.
product.title: Keychron K4 Hot swappable Wireless Bluetooth/USB Wired Mechanical Gaming Keyboard, 96% Layout 100 Keys Computer Keyboard w...

review.title: Seems good so far
review.review: + Keycaps seem solid/sturdy - Matt type material+ Gateron brown feels similar to MX Brown with very slight difference in actuation force+ No technical problems .. Keyboard is not defective+ Enjoying the 75% size for FPS gaming- There is a slight curve on keyboard. It's not a straight incline plane from the F keys to spacebar. There's a slight curve in the middle. I prefer the straight inclined. It's not super pronounced so it doesn't bother me that much.Keyboard stand at bottom is not necessary. Makes the already thick keyboard even taller off the ground, hard to type because of the curve plus the extra angle.Keyboard already raised at the back near the F keys by design of its case. Adding the stand makes it even more raised at the back.Overall decent gaming and compact keyboard style. Keycaps are smaller than fullsize keyboard. I don't know if they make a 75% that has full sized keycaps but these smaller keycaps are pretty easy to type on.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2021
review.title: BEST KEYBOARD FOR 50 DOLLARS
review.review: This keyboard had me very surprised because for 50 dollars you get SO much value of a keyboard. First of it connects to Mac and windows with a usb-c cable (most keyboard in this price point use mirco usb) and it comes with a type a adapter if you don’t have a type c connection. Also it comes with a GREAT key cap puller incase you need to swap some keys out. But the best thing of this keyboard I would say is the feel and the sound. This is a true mechanical keyboard unlike the fakes around this price range so it sound really nice and smooth (or clicky if you choose brown or blue switches) and this keyboard has to kickstand options on it so you can choose the most comfortable way to use it. One thing I will say is if you hit a key a little to hard sometimes it will make a whiny high pitch clang which can be annoying at times but it rarely ever happens.In conclusion this mechanical keyboard is by far the best keyboard you can get for 50 dollars as it offers many good features 100 keyboard DONT have. I will 100 percent recommend this to anyone who wants a incredible keyboard at a affordable price!
product.title: Keychron C1 Mac Layout Wired Mechanical Keyboard, Gateron Brown Switch, Tenkeyless 87 Keys ABS keycaps Computer Keyboard f...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2021
review.title: Excellent value keyboard
review.review: This is probably the best mechanical keyboard you can get at this price range. If you don't like RGB, you can save a bit, if you want hot-swappable switches, you can pay a bit more, it works well enough for Mac and PC, the build quality is fantastic.I'm docking a star for two things:- The switches are a bit squeaky (this model is Gateron Brown)- The dedicated Siri/Cortana key is stupid and should be hardware-mappable to something less stupid. Luckily AutoHotKey/Karabiner existThe RGB effects are 99% ugly and unusable, but some of them look really good. I'd love a software-based tool for selecting exact colors to match with other RGB hardware, but for a built-in toggle system it's fairly flexible.The keycaps looked a bit ugly in the photos, but in person it's actually a beautiful keyboard. The keycap build quality is clearly to the same standard as the rest of the build, but as I didn't like the look in the photos, I did also buy a cheap pudding cap set that I replaced them with. It looks great with both the originals and the replacement caps, though the spacebar has limited backlighting for the translucent keycap base (very common, not really an issue).I would 100% recommend this keyboard to basically anyone at this price point. There are things I would do differently (dedicated media keys would be *amazing* and are never an option for some reason on TKLs), but it's really a fantastic keyboard for every OS.

review.title: Better than k552, feels amazing!
review.review: The media could not be loaded. I got the wired C1, and it is fantastic. Need my A key to move left, I decided it's time to invest a bit more money into a keyboard. Amd this keyboard (so far) has been wonderful. So many rgb settings, I could look at the lights for hours. The keys are so nice to hit, so much better than the clunky ones on other gaming keyboards. Only issue I have is sometimes the space bar is a bit chunky, but I barely notice it after hitting it a few times in game, and the tab key usually doesn't work on the first hit, but always works on the second and after that. This keyboard not only looks nice, but also feels nice. I hope it doesn't fail me like my redragon. 4.8/5 (rounding up to a 5).

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2021
review.title: Great bang for your buck
review.review: Really happy with this keyboard, especially for the price.Pros:-Good build quality and finish-Gateron brown switches are quiet and offer excellent tactile feedback-RGB effects are nice and there are several options to choose from, no software required-Included key caps feel nice to the touch and are thick enough to prevent light from showing through where its not supposed to-Hot-swappable so you change out the switches and keycaps to suit your preferences-Braided usb-c cable is plenty long enough and feels as nice as the one that came with my razer tournament edition keyboard, they even include a usb-c to usb-a adapter which comes in handy when switching between devices-Key caps for both mac and windows are included, and they include an easy follow guide for swapping them out-Packaging is simple, but well padded and easy to open-Seemed to be just as responsive as the razer keyboard I own and has been great to game with-The compact layout is perfect for smaller desks and gives you more room to move your mouse. You get used to not having a number pad pretty quickly as long as you aren't working in spreadsheets all day-Lower profile than Keychron's K series keyboards which is nice if you type with your wrists resting on your desk.Cons:-There is a little more play in the key caps than the razer keyboard I own (which has stabilizers built into each key) but I got used to it rather quickly-It can be a tad bit noisy when typing hard and bottoming out the keys, which is expected at this price point. Still sounds nice overall.-No wireless connectivity, which may be a deal-breaker for some but wasn't something I needed.To sum up, I would highly recommend this keyboard to anyone looking for a solid all-purpose mechanical tenkeyless keyboard. It checked all the boxes for me, and the fact that it is so affordable is just the icing on the cake.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2021
review.title: Solid Mac-first keyboard, with only a few caveats...
review.review: Since I needed new peripherals to go along with my new M1 Mac mini last November, after years of typing on flat MacBooks, I decided to finally treat myself to my first mechanical keyboard since the original IBM PC was offered with one.After a long online dive, when I surfaced I had decided on the 75% Keychron Wireless Backlit RGB with Brown switches and Aluminum Frame.For me, these Browns by Gateron are an acceptable compromise between mechanical feel and reasonable noise, just as long as you are okay with the lack any actual mechanical "break" when actuating. I prefer not waking up the house late at night!That being said, I do sometimes still miss a clearly felt mechanical actuation feel, but this works for me, and is still legions ahead of any membrane keyboard, or Apple's own.IThe keyboard is rather tall, but not exceptionally so.I use it with the rear feet extended for a more sloped typing angle, which helps.I ordered the matching Keychron Wooden Palm Rest in anticipation of this and it makes a big difference when I do serious typing.I also prefer the feel of the finished wood on my palms over spongy fabric covered palmrests, or the bare glass top of my desk. When just casually surfing the web or doing other non-typing-intensive tasks, I put away the palmrest since it just tends to get in the way if I have to move the keyboard around and have desk clutter.Bluetooth is rock-solid, with never a glitch or delay, ever.In fact the connection is far more reliable than with Apple's Magic Trackpad 2 that I bought at the same time.If I recall, I think I had to use a wired connection just once, to be able to boot up my brand new M1 Mac mini.This is a condition specific to only the M1 versions when using a non-Apple keyboard on a new machine.The RGB color options and patterns, though entertaining as heck at first, end up becoming more of a distraction after a while.I ended up using one preferred color pretty much all the time. Keyboard circus lights can be distracting!A note on the colors, specifically blue.Normally a color I might choose, this blue is not very bright, even when turned all the way up in the dark.I always end up using the brightest setting for all the colors, all the time, to get to a decent brightness level.Except for blue.I find it far too subtle.in my photos I use cyan/teal, which I like very much.Battery life with the RGB lighting activated is an issue, but it's addressed in the descriptions when you buy it.Expect to get a full day's use out of it, then plug it in overnight so you're ready to go in the morning.With the illumination turned off, it's much longer, maybe a few days.After nearly a year of use, I can say I am still satisfied with my purchase.I wish the lighting was a tad brighter, and the rubber on one of the folding feet has disappeared (a much bigger problem on the Keychron Palm Rest on which ALL of the pads slid right off it's base - a BIG problem since it'll wobble without!), but not enough suffer any buyers remorse.The keycaps still look good with crisp lettering, and they haven't acquired significant shine from use yet.Battery life is as purchased.it still looks and types great.Whether or not you consider it's reasonable cost vs. comparably featured keyboards from some others, it's a worthy purchase.Except for that one rubber foot-pad... When one falls off, you know more will eventually follow.Especially when you consider how awful they were on my Palmrest.I tried everything to get them to stick - unacceptable that they all fell off within a few weeks of purchase.Keychron, you make some good gear that I'm comfortable recommending to others.I want mine made right again; how does one get replacement feet, please?
product.title: Keychron K2 Wireless Bluetooth/USB Wired Gaming Mechanical Keyboard, Compact 84 Keys RGB LED Backlit N-Key Rollover Alumin...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Where has this keyboard been my whole life?
review.review: I have been a Mac user for the last decade, typed on many types of keyboards. I recently tried a number of cheaper membrane keyboards, but never found one that I felt at home on. I had started seeing all the hype and talk about mechanical keyboards and was curious as to what all of the fuss was about. After doing some research, watching more YouTube videos than I care to admit, I took a leap and purchased a Keychron K3.As far as fit and form is concerned, I can honestly say that I love this keyboard so far. I opted for Blue Gateron low profile, non-hot swappable switches as I figured if I don't really like the feel, I'd send back and try something different. I am in my own closed office space, so noise is not a factor. Though, I will have to mute my mic when in virtual meetings and need to type notes.Two not so positive observations:1) I had read a number of not flattering reviews regarding the Bluetooth connectivity. I have found that connecting to my iPhone is ok, though my Dell XPS 13 has not been so crash hot.2) this be a peculiarity of the Gateron switch, but when you press down a key past the 'click' point, and then partially release it back up, you can actually continue to press it all the way back down and register clicks. I was under the impression that it had to fully release and go back down past the 'click' point to register the next keypress.Other than that, the key layout is a little different that what I am used to. I find myself missing the Backace key and landing on the '=+' key. Bu this is just a matter of getting used to it.Fix the flaky Bluetooth, and it will be a FiveStar review from me.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2021
review.title: Good desktop keyboard for all the Sir Thinkpad Type-a-lot out there
review.review: Type feel:I personally like the Thinkpad keyboards and was looking for a desktop equivalent. Instead of going for the Thinkpad desktop version or the Logitech MX Mini, I went for the K3 brown optical switch version. The color indicates the type feel. Red=linear, blue=clicky, brown=tactile. The total travel distance of the keys are more than on the laptop but much less than a “traditional” mechanical keyboard. Felling wise, for the brown one, it is exactly what you would expect when you combine the laptop keyboard feeling between a good laptop keyboard and a mechanical mechanism. I ordered the red version first and was dissatisfied from the haptic feedback I got from the keys.Quality:The keyboard itself is simple and clean engineered. The quality seems on point and longlivity seems very likely. Due to the design and fact that the buttons can be removed the keyboard is easy to clean. I am sure even for the worst cookie monsters and chips eater will be happy. And if worst comes to worst it is possible to order a new set of keys directly from the manufacturer.Illumination:The light function is an extra gimmick but looks nice. A short youtube search should bring enough examples.Summary:Good keyboard. Can recommend. Reference Keyboard for me are Thinkpad laptops. K3 brown optical switch was the right choice for me. Tried the red one first and returned it.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2021
review.title: Wow
review.review: This keyboard is spectacular. I replaced my Razer Huntsman Mini with this as the Huntsman typing expereince was not what I was looking for.This on the other hand is exactly what I was looking for. I think the only real complaint I could level at it right now is that the backspace key is a little funky, but that is apparently an easy fix.The Gateron brown switches are fantastic, and I am excited about the opportunities afforded by the hot swappable nature of this keyboard.The TKL nature of the keyboard is also awesome, and saves some space on my desk (part of the reason I opted for the Huntsman mini in the first place). I appreciate the fact that this still has the function keys as well as arrow keys. I sorely missed that on the Huntsman.The RGB was a nice surprise too, since I didn't realize this model came with it! I just have mine set to blue to match my PC build.Overall, 10/10. Initial impressions are very positive. Now to maintain and lube it, since that seems to be a very common suggestion among keeb enthusiasts.The only reason I didn't give it full marks for quality of material is because of the issues I mentioned with the backspace key and the fact that the spacebar is doing the same. Other than that... This is perfect for me and the aforementioned issues may just be me adapting to a new board.
product.title: Keychron K8 Tenkeyless Wireless Mechanical Keyboard for Mac, Bluetooth RGB Backlight Multitasking Type-C Wired Gaming Keyb...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2021
review.title: I can't speak to it's longevity, but it seems like a great TKL so far.
review.review: I'm not familiar with Keychron, and I wasn't sure if I could trust it's quality, but I figured I'd take a shot with it and see how it went.I went with the Gateron Blues since that's what I'm used to typing with, and so far, this board gets high marks.The build quality is strong, and it's a heavy board, which gives me hopes that it will last a while for me.Coming from an Anne Pro II (which I still have, but it's now my travel keyboard), this is a very worthy replacement.There are three things that I would caution you with, though, if you plan to buy this.Firstly, the keycaps aren't textured and feel a little "slick" for lack of a better term.It's not a bad thing, just different than what I'm used to, but they don't feel cheap.This isn't too big of a deal, because you can always swap them for another set, or even your favorite set from the board this is replacing.Second, it is a loud board.I don't know if it's because of the aluminum housing, or the way the board is laid out in the recession of that housing, but the keystrokes echo much louder than my other keyboard.It's not bad, and if you love the sound of blues then you probably don't care about noise anyway, but it's a warning for those that have sensitive partners, roommates, or neighbors :)Lastly, this board sits high.If you don't have a wrist wrest, you may want to invest in one.All of that said, I give the board high praise and as long as it holds up, I'll recommend it to others.
product.title: Keychron K8 Tenkeyless Wireless Mechanical Keyboard for Mac, Bluetooth RGB Backlight Multitasking Type-C Wired Gaming Keyb...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2021
review.title: Good desktop keyboard for all the Thinkpad Type-a-lots out there
review.review: Type feel:I personally like the Thinkpad keyboards and was looking for a desktop equivalent. Instead of going for the Thinkpad desktop version or the Logitech MX Mini, I went for the K3 brown optical switch version. The color indicates the type feel. Red=linear, blue=clicky, brown=tactile. The total travel distance of the keys are more than on the laptop but much less than a “traditional” mechanical keyboard. Felling wise, for the brown one, it is exactly what you would expect when you combine the laptop keyboard feeling between a good laptop keyboard and a mechanical mechanism. I ordered the red version first and was dissatisfied from the haptic feedback I got from the keys.Quality:The keyboard itself is simple and clean engineered. The quality seems on point and longlivity seems very likely. Due to the design and fact that the buttons can be removed the keyboard is easy to clean. I am sure even for the worst cookie monsters and chips eater will be happy. And if worst comes to worst it is possible to order a new set of keys directly from the manufacturer.Illumination:The light function is an extra gimmick but looks nice. A short youtube search should bring enough examples.Summary:Good keyboard. Can recommend. Reference Keyboard for me are Thinkpad laptops. K3 brown optical switch was the right choice for me. Tried the red one first and returned it.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2021
review.title: Bad Stabilizers that Can't be Easily Fixed
review.review: Two issues that work in tandem to make this version of the Keychron K8 an absolute DO NOT BUY:1. It needs to be more clearly advertised that the switches are not hotswappable. All switches are soldered on. Which is fine if this was a great keyboard out of the box, but:2. The stabilizers on this thing are BAD. Like, very mushy and unresponsive. The spacebar sticks constantly. Unless I absolutely slam it, I have a 50/50 shot of my keystroke actually registering. The other keys using stabilizers are mushy at best (e.g. enter, backspace, shift).The spacebar is relatively important, and the end result is a very bad keyboard. I will be ordering the hotswappable version direct from keychron's site because I think this would actually be a very good keyboard with upgraded stabilizers. But learn from my $80 down the drain for what is ultimately some spare keyboard parts...Do not buy this keyboard from Amazon directly. You will be getting a version that is very hard to modify, with some bad key issues, and you will regret it.

review.review_data: Reviewed in Australia on March 24, 2021
review.title: Takes a little getting use to but it's a great little keyboard
review.review: These brown switches feel more stiff than the cherry brown switches I have on my corsair keyboard. But thats not low profile and so maybe thats the difference. Though it still feels like it's tougher than it should be.Otherwise this is a very neat nifty compact low profile keyboard. Loving it so far, been using it for about a day now and so far like the extra space and no numpad on the right.The low profile and space between the keys feel perfect otherwise.Notes for improvement:* Windows and Mac symbols on keys rather than actually having to replace them to get the symbol/icon for windows on them I switch between mac and windows very regularly and will not be swapping the key caps every time.* Some macro options without the use of software like the cooler master k622 does.* Though the width of the keyboard is great, I find I keep hitting the arrow key instead of the right shift. So maybe for me a layout like the K1 but with the low profile and design of this K3. Or better yet something in between as I would like the del and ins to be separate keys.Finally this would be 5 stars if the keys felt softer or not as stiff to press on these brown switches and insert and del being separate keys with a full width right shift key.UPDATE: Weeks of using it now at my primary keyboard.* Still find the keys a little stiff compared to my corsair cherry mx browns* Switch between mac and windows mode is very annoying and not very easy to switch. I switch between mac and pc very often. Wish the switch was like switching between bluetooth devices, or easier then the switch on there now. Though I'm getting use to it I feel like I'm going to eventually damage it and not be able to switch between pc/mac. Question is which mode will I be left in when that happens. Anyways, really hoping it won't get wrecked.* The size and spacing have been great.* The active bluetooth is wonderful, switching between devices has been instant once active.* Would have been nice to configure the idle time before it turns off. It also turns off after 10 mins when connected via cable and using bluetooth. And turning this feature off is not a good option as the battery has not been so great on this device.Hoping for a Keychron 3 rev 2 with the above addressed, be the perfect keyboard for me if that happens.

review.title: K8 Keyboard randomly remapped and can't reverse

After 5 months of use, and experimenting with more than one bluetooth receiver on my PC, it just...stopped doing anything meaningful with my PC. It won't even stay connected anymore, and even if I perform a factory reset, trying to resort to its chorded mode doesn't make a difference (in fact, it seems to get very confused, and the light effects start to slow down in weird ways). The poor thing has basically spent 99% of its life on my desk in some capacity, never really travelling anywhere, but it alas just decided to start giving up on me.I want to like it. Sometimes, it does work. The keys feel great, and I'm happy with the form factor. But I think I've been patient enough with the device. It's clearly not durable, and your money is probably best spent elsewhere.

review.title: Seems good so far
review.review: + Keycaps seem solid/sturdy - Matt type material+ Gateron brown feels similar to MX Brown with very slight difference in actuation force+ No technical problems .. Keyboard is not defective+ Enjoying the 75% size for FPS gaming- There is a slight curve on keyboard. It's not a straight incline plane from the F keys to spacebar. There's a slight curve in the middle. I prefer the straight inclined. It's not super pronounced so it doesn't bother me that much.Keyboard stand at bottom is not necessary. Makes the already thick keyboard even taller off the ground, hard to type because of the curve plus the extra angle.Keyboard already raised at the back near the F keys by design of its case. Adding the stand makes it even more raised at the back.Overall decent gaming and compact keyboard style. Keycaps are smaller than fullsize keyboard. I don't know if they make a 75% that has full sized keycaps but these smaller keycaps are pretty easy to type on.
