review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2021
review.title: Solid Mac-first keyboard, with only a few caveats...
review.review: Since I needed new peripherals to go along with my new M1 Mac mini last November, after years of typing on flat MacBooks, I decided to finally treat myself to my first mechanical keyboard since the original IBM PC was offered with one.After a long online dive, when I surfaced I had decided on the 75% Keychron Wireless Backlit RGB with Brown switches and Aluminum Frame.For me, these Browns by Gateron are an acceptable compromise between mechanical feel and reasonable noise, just as long as you are okay with the lack any actual mechanical "break" when actuating. I prefer not waking up the house late at night!That being said, I do sometimes still miss a clearly felt mechanical actuation feel, but this works for me, and is still legions ahead of any membrane keyboard, or Apple's own.IThe keyboard is rather tall, but not exceptionally so.I use it with the rear feet extended for a more sloped typing angle, which helps.I ordered the matching Keychron Wooden Palm Rest in anticipation of this and it makes a big difference when I do serious typing.I also prefer the feel of the finished wood on my palms over spongy fabric covered palmrests, or the bare glass top of my desk. When just casually surfing the web or doing other non-typing-intensive tasks, I put away the palmrest since it just tends to get in the way if I have to move the keyboard around and have desk clutter.Bluetooth is rock-solid, with never a glitch or delay, ever.In fact the connection is far more reliable than with Apple's Magic Trackpad 2 that I bought at the same time.If I recall, I think I had to use a wired connection just once, to be able to boot up my brand new M1 Mac mini.This is a condition specific to only the M1 versions when using a non-Apple keyboard on a new machine.The RGB color options and patterns, though entertaining as heck at first, end up becoming more of a distraction after a while.I ended up using one preferred color pretty much all the time. Keyboard circus lights can be distracting!A note on the colors, specifically blue.Normally a color I might choose, this blue is not very bright, even when turned all the way up in the dark.I always end up using the brightest setting for all the colors, all the time, to get to a decent brightness level.Except for blue.I find it far too subtle.in my photos I use cyan/teal, which I like very much.Battery life with the RGB lighting activated is an issue, but it's addressed in the descriptions when you buy it.Expect to get a full day's use out of it, then plug it in overnight so you're ready to go in the morning.With the illumination turned off, it's much longer, maybe a few days.After nearly a year of use, I can say I am still satisfied with my purchase.I wish the lighting was a tad brighter, and the rubber on one of the folding feet has disappeared (a much bigger problem on the Keychron Palm Rest on which ALL of the pads slid right off it's base - a BIG problem since it'll wobble without!), but not enough suffer any buyers remorse.The keycaps still look good with crisp lettering, and they haven't acquired significant shine from use yet.Battery life is as purchased.it still looks and types great.Whether or not you consider it's reasonable cost vs. comparably featured keyboards from some others, it's a worthy purchase.Except for that one rubber foot-pad... When one falls off, you know more will eventually follow.Especially when you consider how awful they were on my Palmrest.I tried everything to get them to stick - unacceptable that they all fell off within a few weeks of purchase.Keychron, you make some good gear that I'm comfortable recommending to others.I want mine made right again; how does one get replacement feet, please?
product.title: Keychron K2 Wireless Bluetooth/USB Wired Gaming Mechanical Keyboard, Compact 84 Keys RGB LED Backlit N-Key Rollover Alumin...

review.title: Had trouble pairing with Mac. Support unresponsive.
review.review: I was excited to get my hands on this keyboard. It’s one of the cleanest keyboards and the Mac specific key caps are almost impossible to find elsewhere. However I ultimately ended up going with a RK84 instead of this.I had trouble pairing this with my Mac. It would work and then stop pairing. I haven’t had the same experience with other bluetooth mechanical keyboards.I tried contacting support about this and took 2.5 weeks to get the first response. By that time I had given up and returned it. The instructions were no different than what I was able to find on forums so I doubt it would make a difference on getting it to work.Lastly, since switching to the RK84, I’ve appreciated being able to fully program the keyboard to rearrange keys. I didn’t get that opportunity with this board, but greatly appreciate it once i had it.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2021
review.title: Great keyboard!
review.review: Got this because I missed having a 75% keyboard. Been using a Kira for the past couple of years and before that, I had a crappy (but handsome) Excalibur 75% kb, this one is very nice. The only things I don't like about the keyboard is:- Lights reset whenever I switch machines or switch to Bluetooth. I have the keyboard attached to a KVM switch, whenever I switch the KVM to another machine. I'm not big on keyboard lights as I don't use shine-through keycaps. So it's pointless to have them on- Bluetooth is severely borked. It lags, types randomly by itself (usually the last key you pressed), its especially annoying when it gets stuck on backspace as it will delete everything you've typed until you hit another key.- The plastic case is plastic. I would have loved either a low-profile case or a metal one. I would have paid extra for either of those options. That being said, although it's plastic, and looks rather cheap, it's pretty solid and doesn't make weird plasticie noises when typing.If you use this keyboard with it plugged directly, it's great! Especially for the price. I highly recommend it if you are going to use it this way. But maybe do some research if you want to use this as a BT keyboard. I was hoping to be able to use it wirelessly, but I guess that's not going to happen.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2021
review.title: Bluetooth issues
review.review: I bought this keyboard specifically to use on the couch with my PC so wireless functionality was a must. However, as many other reviews have stated, the bluetooth connection is very iffy. I get disconnects multiple times in a week or when typing characters will continuously repeat. It gets so bad that even a reset or turning off/on the keyboard again doesn't work. I usually end up having to pair it again. For the price of these keyboards, the feature that they advertise should actually work reliably. If this was $50 I could live with it but for the price they ask just no. Now I have this keyboard connected via a cable to my PC. This is not the outcome I wanted. If you need the wireless feature of this keyboard, buyer beware.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2021
review.title: Great Keyboard for the price!
review.review: Been using this keyboard for over a month now and have been liking it.Been loving the Gateron browns.I also like how quick it is to swap out the switches which helps in customizing the keyboard to my liking.The sound is great and love the tactile feel.The sound is nice too.Not to load and has a distinct tone but is mostly silent.For gaming I prefer more linear switch's and switched out WASD with Gateron Yellows.This helped with the overall feel for the board with spring pressure matching closer to the Browns.I ended up swapping the spring in the space bar switch with a Gateron Black spring.This has just been my preference and have liked it so far.If I wanted I could change back to Browns, the keyboard would still be pretty awesome and makes it super easy with the hot swap.I love how you can connect through Bluetooth and have used it with my Samsung Fold 3 and a laptop.It's helped to have up to three different connections that you can use for this keyboard.One thing has been really bothering which makes me want to tear the keyboard apart.It's when I plug the keyboard in to use on my main gaming PC.There's an LED right under the Tilde and Tab keys which is supposed to show on the side if the keyboard is charging/connected.There's a small gap in the plate to the frame of the keyboard that the light from the USB C shines through.It becomes bothersome if you lookdown at the keyboard but if you change the RGB color to match it blends in.But shouldn't have to do that.This make me want to tear the keyboard apart so that I can glue or tape something to it so that the light won't be bleeding through from there.Other them that everything is pretty great with this keyboard.Kinda wished that I could have gotten the aluminum one though.Wasn't out when I bought this one.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2021
review.title: Cool Keyboard, great price to performance
review.review: I got this product for programming and gaming and it's probably the best out there for the price. The switches feel great, the lighting is bright, and the overall design language looks pretty cool. I got the K2 over Keychron's many other offerings because it's a compact keyboard that allows you to use your desk space effectively, but it's still got a function row (with multimedia controls), number keys, and arrow keys, which if you look at most other keyboard manufacturers, they will probably be missing one or more of those in their smaller keyboard sizes. Also, the Gateron brown switches feel great to me (although I'm not too experienced with mechanical keyboards) and the Bluetooth is an awesome feature for the price. Honestly, it just has everything you need and nothing you don't and is well worth it! Thanks Keychron!P.S. If you are wondering about the thickness of the keyboard, it's a lot better in the K2 Version 2 than in the Version 1. The V2 has a standard incline that makes it great to type on; you might still need a wrist rest but I would say try it first before you get one.

review.title: I like it better than my logitech mechs
review.review: The Gateron Brown switches go down much easier than my other keyboard (with Logitech Romer-G switches).The key presses are light but tactile, exactly how I want them to be.I was surprised at how much I liked these switches, they are my favorite now.The bluetooth works great, I have it synced to three different devices (two Windows laptops and an Android phone) that I can switch between with a press of a button, seamlessly.The screen brightness control function keys are a nice touch.The power switch has three positions, and the off position is in the middle, which can be annoying when trying to turn it off.However, on Bluetooth mode, it will sleep after five or ten minutes by default, so not too much to worry about even if you leave it on.After sleep mode, it does take a few seconds to reconnect, but this can be disabled if you follow the instructions in the box.The RGB lighting functions fine, but I don't think it looks very good under the grey keys.I tend to turn it off or leave it on a single uniform color.The keyboard is pretty thick.I haven't had issues with the thickness, but it's definitely the thickest keyboard I have used.If you are worried about this, keychron is coming out with a low profile version in early 2021, you may want to wait for that one instead.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2021
review.title: Key chattering/duplication issue is a deal breaker, Drop doesn't stand behind their products
review.review: This keyboard looks good and feels solid with it's all-aluminum construction. If you purely use it for gaming you might never even notice an issue. But if you use it for any kind of typing - writing, coding, etc. - you will notice after a few months that it begins to exhibit an issue where keystrokes are duplicated. This is referred to as "key chattering" and if you search for "Drop Ctrl key chattering" you'll find that it's a very common issue with these keyboards, with no real fix. It makes this keyboard incredibly frustrating to use for work (coding) because it significantly increases typos due to the random duplicated letters while typing.Drop has released several firmware updates that they claim resolve the issue, but none actually do. They seem unwilling to admit that it's a hardware issue and continue to sell a faulty product. They also are not willing to provide support for the product when it's purchased from Amazon instead of their own website. Because of this, I'm avoiding the Drop brand entirely in the future since they seem unwilling to stand behind their products.There are a lot of good options for keyboards in the $100-200 range. This keyboard is already pricey for what it is, but the key chattering issue is just a complete deal breaker. My 10 year old $60 Cooler Master mechanical keyboard doesn't have this issue. $5 rubber dome keyboards don't have this issue. A $220 keyboard having an issue like this is crazy.

review.review: I was having trouble with my Ducky 2 one keyboard as several keys' LEDs stopped working. Since the keytops are underlit by the LED you can't even see the legend so I had to get a replacement. The Drop keyboard was a bit pricey, but it features totally programmable LED lighting in white and colors, as well as "edge lighting" which I don't need but is handy for dark environments. It also has hot swap keys so if one goes bad, pop it out and get a single replacement. The construction is heavy and sturdy and the quality of the keytops and lighting are superb. Also comes with a longer cord. I bought the TKL (ten key-less) version and don't miss the extra numeric keypad on the Ducky. I would buy another one of these keyboards.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2021
review.title: Wanted to love it but it just didn't work out
review.review: I was looking for a budget-friendly mechanical keyboard and really wanted to love the k8 as so many of my friends recommended Keychron as one of the best first mechanical keyboards for their price and quality. Granted the version my friends purchased was the K2, I wanted dedicated arrows and opted for the K8.First off, if based on typing alone... out of the other keyboards I've tried, I've mistyped the least on the K8. I actually truly enjoyed typing on here and loved that there was an option to level the keyboard. My fingers felt pretty natural typing and I haven't had to look down on my keyboard yet. The simple white backlight is nice, nothing too fancy like the RGB (which is nice to look at but my eyes will be glued to the screen and wouldn't be able to enjoy it anyways). My main intended use for the K8 was to be able to one day bring it to work and use it as my dedicated work keyboard.Now for the bad... as much as I love how my hands fall naturally on the keyboard... out of the box there is a persistent ping and/or squeaking on certain keys, wobble or rattle on larger keys like the space bar. Also a little wonky connection when using Bluetooth. Unfortunately for this keyboard set for the price, I was hoping to have a better experience. Unfortunately, it seems like I would have to do a lot of work on the keyboard to fix a lot of these QA issues. Another thing to note, although the keycaps feel nice to touch, with the matte finish you can clearly see your finger oils on them. Which again, is a bit unfortunate.Overall, I'm sure what I received could be a dud, I wouldn't take it out of the running completely. Still could be a worthy contender for an 87 keyboard. It would just require more time, effort, and money to get the keyboard where I need it to be. Maybe next time Keychron.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2021
review.title: I love this keyboard and I couldn't be happier with my purchase
review.review: First of all, I'm no mechanical keyboard aficionado. It's just that I was looking towards mechanical keyboards because the keyboard I had been using had seen its better days behind it (Logitech K740), I was having trouble typing accurately on it, and I had heard so much about mechanical keyboards these days.What appealed to me about the K8 was that I could replace the keys and switches (I opted for Gateron browns), that it was backlit (I opted for the model with white lighting), the 10-keyless layout, and that it had Bluetooth support for up to 3 devices. This would allow me to easily switch between my Mac and my PC. The combination of this keyboard and my MX Master 3 mouse (which has the same ability to pair with multiple devices) has been a winning combination.I only use the keyboard for office type work (documents, programming) and also some creativity apps (Lightroom, Photoshop, Premiere). No gaming to speak of.Things that I like:* The general feel of the keyboard. I can't explain it, but I find myself getting a certain satisfaction from typing on this keyboard. I find it strangely pleasurable. That may have more to do with the current state of my previous keyboard but the feeling is there nonetheless.* Backlighting. I often like to work with little light, so it is convenient.* Bluetooth. See above.* Comes with both Mac and Windows keys.* The fact that I can replace both they keycaps and the switches means that it should have a longer life, and I have more room for customization if I desire.* Has the ability to have the back of the keyboard sit at 3 different heights.Things I don't like:* It's very thick. I just got it and I haven't done any marathon typing sessions yet, so it remains to be seen whether I'm going to want to have a wrist rest. (My old keyboard had a bit of one built in, although it was really an "edge of palm" rest.)* It's really dumb the way the recharge cable is on the left side of the keyboard instead of the back of the keyboard. That just doesn't make any sense, especially considering how much room is inside this thing - they surely could have place some electronics in back and kept the switches (for OS and for communications between Bluetooth and USB) on the side.
product.title: Keychron K8 Hot-swappable Wireless Bluetooth 5.1/Wired USB Mechanical Gaming Keyboard, Tenkeyless 87 Keys White LED Backli...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2021
review.title: Don't waste your money; barely lasted 5 months in one spot
review.review: It looks good, but it apparently wasn't meant to last. After 5 months of use, and experimenting with more than one bluetooth receiver on my PC, it just...stopped doing anything meaningful with my PC. It won't even stay connected anymore, and even if I perform a factory reset, trying to resort to its chorded mode doesn't make a difference (in fact, it seems to get very confused, and the light effects start to slow down in weird ways). The poor thing has basically spent 99% of its life on my desk in some capacity, never really travelling anywhere, but it alas just decided to start giving up on me.I want to like it. Sometimes, it does work. The keys feel great, and I'm happy with the form factor. But I think I've been patient enough with the device. It's clearly not durable, and your money is probably best spent elsewhere.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2021
review.title: Good desktop keyboard for all the Thinkpad Type-a-lots out there
review.review: Type feel:I personally like the Thinkpad keyboards and was looking for a desktop equivalent. Instead of going for the Thinkpad desktop version or the Logitech MX Mini, I went for the K3 brown optical switch version. The color indicates the type feel. Red=linear, blue=clicky, brown=tactile. The total travel distance of the keys are more than on the laptop but much less than a “traditional” mechanical keyboard. Felling wise, for the brown one, it is exactly what you would expect when you combine the laptop keyboard feeling between a good laptop keyboard and a mechanical mechanism. I ordered the red version first and was dissatisfied from the haptic feedback I got from the keys.Quality:The keyboard itself is simple and clean engineered. The quality seems on point and longlivity seems very likely. Due to the design and fact that the buttons can be removed the keyboard is easy to clean. I am sure even for the worst cookie monsters and chips eater will be happy. And if worst comes to worst it is possible to order a new set of keys directly from the manufacturer.Illumination:The light function is an extra gimmick but looks nice. A short youtube search should bring enough examples.Summary:Good keyboard. Can recommend. Reference Keyboard for me are Thinkpad laptops. K3 brown optical switch was the right choice for me. Tried the red one first and returned it.
product.title: Keychron K3 Ultra-Slim 75% Layout Wireless Bluetooth/Wired USB Mechanical Keyboard, Hot Swappable Low-Profile Keychron Opt...

review.review: I'm very happy with the build quality overall and everything, but the keycap situation is terrible. For this keyboard at least they use proprietary stabilizers with offset placement, which means that no other full keysets work.The biggest issue as a gamer is that there are no tactile indicators for any of the WASD keys, and the tactile bump for the F and J keys seems hard to find for some reason. Finding the right position without looking is difficult. I invested in buying aftermarket WASD keys that fit cherry mx low profile stems (again, couldn't replace the whole set), but they are higher than the regular keys.That aside works perfectly.

However, it did not fit my typing habit: I get used to scissor key laptop like keyboard where there is no steep ladder to climb when finger travelling up from south to north keys. I use to glide through keys but for this keycap shape, I had to lift the fingers a lot to when move upward.This is tiring for my fingers after a while.Nothing wrong with the keyboard but it's just my typing habit.

review.review: I really loved this keyboard - took some getting used to in terms of the format (it's smaller than a traditional keyboard) but nice and compact for my small work from home desk. the backlight is great, and the keys all have great action -- nice bounce-back and depth. Major downside is the battery life - it can go dead in under two weeks of normal use, so keep that charger handy. When it dies, it does take several minutes of charging to get back to life so you can start using it.The feel of typing is definitely an acquired taste, but one that I quite enjoy now. However, it mysteriously stopped working. I am hoping that the manufacturer or seller gets back to me to troubleshoot or do a warranty replacement. Definitely should last longer than 9 months!

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2021
review.title: Excellent Production Keyboard
review.review: Keychron K2, hot-swap aluminum frame, with Gateron bluesI got the blues because the brown one wasn't available at the time (had no idea it'd be restocked a week later. Oh well) and the reds were more expensive. I swapped them out for Kailh Speed Coppers. I didnt like the blues at all, but personal preference.This keyboard is excellent for typing. If you're into gaming, you may not like it. I haven't noticed any lag even on Bluetooth but according to RTings it's measured to be pretty high. You also don't have features like disabling the windows key or easy key remapping or macros.For work, though, it's awesome. Solid, good battery life (you can set it to never sleep automatically, default is sleep after 10 minutes and waking takes 5 seconds ish), no-fuss BT connection. Feels great to type on (I don't have a lot to compare it to), the keys don't rattle or ring a whole lot. The browns or reds should be quiet enough for most offices.One thing I was unpleasantly surprised by was the keycaps. I tried another keychron, with their stock gray almost blue-ish keycaps, and they felt great. I was expecting these to feel the same but they feel thinner and smoother. Not bad, but a little disappointing after feeling and expecting the other ones.Overall, you can't go wrong with this one. High quality and a fair price.

review.review_data: Reviewed in Australia on October 6, 2021
review.title: Fantastic keyboard for just about anyone.
review.review: This keyboard is fantastic. Just using it stock standard out of the box it's an exceptional keyboard but if you put a bit of time in modding and upgrading this keyboard is next level. Being hot swappable means that should I wish to change the feel of the keyboard by using different switches I won't have to break out the soldering iron.The convenience of having both wired and bluetooth connectivity is fantastic while working from home. I have it plugged in to my home PC and wirelessly connected to my work PC. This way I can flip between wired and wireless connection depending on which computer I want to use it with.The 75% configuration is perfect for general use while remaining as compact as possible. It provides the convenience of arrow keys which are not on a 60% keyboard and Function keys which are left off of a 65% configuration. On the other end it's smaller than a TKL keyboard while still providing access to a Del key as well as the Pg Up, Pg Dn, Homd and End navigation keys. The aluminium case is like a tank and provides the keyboard with a sturdy weighty feel.

review.title: Mac Compatible with Brown Switches!
review.review: I picked up this Keychron to replace a Logitech mechanical keyboard with Romer-G switches when I replaced my windows laptop with a Mac. I'm glad to say all my searching paid off. This keyboard is really fantastic to type on. The feel of the keys, the switch feedback, and the multiple options for connectivity make this a really great match for my work setup. I've been able to type for long periods without any discomfort, and it's quiet enough to not bother my coworkers if I have a nasty email to send out.The backlight it a little dim, which isn't a huge deal since the office is well lit. I leave the lights on, but it's hard to tell. I do wish the backlight was more controllable outside of the predefined patterns. This is absolutely a small complaint, and does not outweigh the benefits of this keyboard.Just buy it if you want a compact keyboard for Mac. You won't be disappointed.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2021
review.title: Wow
review.review: This keyboard is spectacular. I replaced my Razer Huntsman Mini with this as the Huntsman typing expereince was not what I was looking for.This on the other hand is exactly what I was looking for. I think the only real complaint I could level at it right now is that the backspace key is a little funky, but that is apparently an easy fix.The Gateron brown switches are fantastic, and I am excited about the opportunities afforded by the hot swappable nature of this keyboard.The TKL nature of the keyboard is also awesome, and saves some space on my desk (part of the reason I opted for the Huntsman mini in the first place). I appreciate the fact that this still has the function keys as well as arrow keys. I sorely missed that on the Huntsman.The RGB was a nice surprise too, since I didn't realize this model came with it! I just have mine set to blue to match my PC build.Overall, 10/10. Initial impressions are very positive. Now to maintain and lube it, since that seems to be a very common suggestion among keeb enthusiasts.The only reason I didn't give it full marks for quality of material is because of the issues I mentioned with the backspace key and the fact that the spacebar is doing the same. Other than that... This is perfect for me and the aforementioned issues may just be me adapting to a new board.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2021
review.title: I can't speak to it's longevity, but it seems like a great TKL so far.
review.review: I'm not familiar with Keychron, and I wasn't sure if I could trust it's quality, but I figured I'd take a shot with it and see how it went.I went with the Gateron Blues since that's what I'm used to typing with, and so far, this board gets high marks.The build quality is strong, and it's a heavy board, which gives me hopes that it will last a while for me.Coming from an Anne Pro II (which I still have, but it's now my travel keyboard), this is a very worthy replacement.There are three things that I would caution you with, though, if you plan to buy this.Firstly, the keycaps aren't textured and feel a little "slick" for lack of a better term.It's not a bad thing, just different than what I'm used to, but they don't feel cheap.This isn't too big of a deal, because you can always swap them for another set, or even your favorite set from the board this is replacing.Second, it is a loud board.I don't know if it's because of the aluminum housing, or the way the board is laid out in the recession of that housing, but the keystrokes echo much louder than my other keyboard.It's not bad, and if you love the sound of blues then you probably don't care about noise anyway, but it's a warning for those that have sensitive partners, roommates, or neighbors :)Lastly, this board sits high.If you don't have a wrist wrest, you may want to invest in one.All of that said, I give the board high praise and as long as it holds up, I'll recommend it to others.
product.title: Keychron K8 Tenkeyless Wireless Mechanical Keyboard for Mac, Bluetooth RGB Backlight Multitasking Type-C Wired Gaming Keyb...

review.title: Affordable Features! Use your savings to get a wrist with it.
review.review: The keychron keyboard is pretty high and can be uncomfortable to use for an extended period of time without a wrist rest. Moving up from a low profile membrane office keyboard, theres plenty of benefits on the feel of mechanical keyboard but leaves room for ergonomics and comfort. it seems in the mechanical keyboard space an additional purchase for a wrist is needed. I ended up replacing this keyboard board with an IKBC X400 because of its low height and comfort of use without a wrist rest. Keychron does offer a slim mechanical keyboard but doesn't specify the height difference between the models.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2021
review.title: Bad Stabilizers that Can't be Easily Fixed
review.review: Two issues that work in tandem to make this version of the Keychron K8 an absolute DO NOT BUY:1. It needs to be more clearly advertised that the switches are not hotswappable. All switches are soldered on. Which is fine if this was a great keyboard out of the box, but:2. The stabilizers on this thing are BAD. Like, very mushy and unresponsive. The spacebar sticks constantly. Unless I absolutely slam it, I have a 50/50 shot of my keystroke actually registering. The other keys using stabilizers are mushy at best (e.g. enter, backspace, shift).The spacebar is relatively important, and the end result is a very bad keyboard. I will be ordering the hotswappable version direct from keychron's site because I think this would actually be a very good keyboard with upgraded stabilizers. But learn from my $80 down the drain for what is ultimately some spare keyboard parts...Do not buy this keyboard from Amazon directly. You will be getting a version that is very hard to modify, with some bad key issues, and you will regret it.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Where has this keyboard been my whole life?
review.review: I have been a Mac user for the last decade, typed on many types of keyboards. I recently tried a number of cheaper membrane keyboards, but never found one that I felt at home on. I had started seeing all the hype and talk about mechanical keyboards and was curious as to what all of the fuss was about. After doing some research, watching more YouTube videos than I care to admit, I took a leap and purchased a Keychron K3.As far as fit and form is concerned, I can honestly say that I love this keyboard so far. I opted for Blue Gateron low profile, non-hot swappable switches as I figured if I don't really like the feel, I'd send back and try something different. I am in my own closed office space, so noise is not a factor. Though, I will have to mute my mic when in virtual meetings and need to type notes.Two not so positive observations:1) I had read a number of not flattering reviews regarding the Bluetooth connectivity. I have found that connecting to my iPhone is ok, though my Dell XPS 13 has not been so crash hot.2) this be a peculiarity of the Gateron switch, but when you press down a key past the 'click' point, and then partially release it back up, you can actually continue to press it all the way back down and register clicks. I was under the impression that it had to fully release and go back down past the 'click' point to register the next keypress.Other than that, the key layout is a little different that what I am used to. I find myself missing the Backace key and landing on the '=+' key. Bu this is just a matter of getting used to it.Fix the flaky Bluetooth, and it will be a FiveStar review from me.
product.title: Keychron K3 Version 2, 84 Keys Ultra-Slim Wireless Bluetooth/USB Wired Mechanical Keyboard with White LED Backlit, Low-Pro...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 9, 2021
review.title: Good desktop keyboard for all the Sir Thinkpad Type-a-lot out there
review.review: Type feel:I personally like the Thinkpad keyboards and was looking for a desktop equivalent. Instead of going for the Thinkpad desktop version or the Logitech MX Mini, I went for the K3 brown optical switch version. The color indicates the type feel. Red=linear, blue=clicky, brown=tactile. The total travel distance of the keys are more than on the laptop but much less than a “traditional” mechanical keyboard. Felling wise, for the brown one, it is exactly what you would expect when you combine the laptop keyboard feeling between a good laptop keyboard and a mechanical mechanism. I ordered the red version first and was dissatisfied from the haptic feedback I got from the keys.Quality:The keyboard itself is simple and clean engineered. The quality seems on point and longlivity seems very likely. Due to the design and fact that the buttons can be removed the keyboard is easy to clean. I am sure even for the worst cookie monsters and chips eater will be happy. And if worst comes to worst it is possible to order a new set of keys directly from the manufacturer.Illumination:The light function is an extra gimmick but looks nice. A short youtube search should bring enough examples.Summary:Good keyboard. Can recommend. Reference Keyboard for me are Thinkpad laptops. K3 brown optical switch was the right choice for me. Tried the red one first and returned it.
product.title: Keychron K3 Version 2, 84 Keys Ultra-Slim Wireless Bluetooth/USB Wired Mechanical Keyboard with White LED Backlit, Low-Pro...

review.review_data: Reviewed in Australia on March 24, 2021
review.title: Takes a little getting use to but it's a great little keyboard
review.review: These brown switches feel more stiff than the cherry brown switches I have on my corsair keyboard. But thats not low profile and so maybe thats the difference. Though it still feels like it's tougher than it should be.Otherwise this is a very neat nifty compact low profile keyboard. Loving it so far, been using it for about a day now and so far like the extra space and no numpad on the right.The low profile and space between the keys feel perfect otherwise.Notes for improvement:* Windows and Mac symbols on keys rather than actually having to replace them to get the symbol/icon for windows on them I switch between mac and windows very regularly and will not be swapping the key caps every time.* Some macro options without the use of software like the cooler master k622 does.* Though the width of the keyboard is great, I find I keep hitting the arrow key instead of the right shift. So maybe for me a layout like the K1 but with the low profile and design of this K3. Or better yet something in between as I would like the del and ins to be separate keys.Finally this would be 5 stars if the keys felt softer or not as stiff to press on these brown switches and insert and del being separate keys with a full width right shift key.UPDATE: Weeks of using it now at my primary keyboard.* Still find the keys a little stiff compared to my corsair cherry mx browns* Switch between mac and windows mode is very annoying and not very easy to switch. I switch between mac and pc very often. Wish the switch was like switching between bluetooth devices, or easier then the switch on there now. Though I'm getting use to it I feel like I'm going to eventually damage it and not be able to switch between pc/mac. Question is which mode will I be left in when that happens. Anyways, really hoping it won't get wrecked.* The size and spacing have been great.* The active bluetooth is wonderful, switching between devices has been instant once active.* Would have been nice to configure the idle time before it turns off. It also turns off after 10 mins when connected via cable and using bluetooth. And turning this feature off is not a good option as the battery has not been so great on this device.Hoping for a Keychron 3 rev 2 with the above addressed, be the perfect keyboard for me if that happens.

review.review_data: Reviewed in Australia on August 16, 2021
review.title: Amazing first mechanical keyboard experience!
review.review: Absolutely in love with my Keychron K3v2 Keyboard with Optical Red switches!This is my very first mechanical keyboard as I've always used membrane laptop keyboards prior. It didn't take long to transition and I feel like my accuracy has improved, my fingers are still moving at lightning speeds and can spend longer periods typing without fatigue. As a first mechanical experience, the keys are very 'bouncy' and I sometimes don't need to bottom out to register the keys. This could be a little sensitive for heavier typists out there, but it shouldn't be a problem if you are a light touch typist like me.I also like its hot-swappable capability so I can try out brown and blue switches later down the track :) The sounds are less silent than laptop keyboards, but they sound like you are being efficient and feels ASMR! There are lots of RGB effects to choose from and the size is perfect for me, compact for on-the-go and has all the keys I need. There are also two back legs to change the angle of the keyboard. The function keys are also easily accessible on the F row like volume, pause/play, brightness, etc. There is also Bluetooth and cable mode, switchable with Windows/Mac. The cable mode makes the RBG lights brighter and has no lag compared to the Bluetooth mode (I see some lag when it wakes up from Sleep mode, which I have now turned off). The keycaps are low profile, so they are quite easy to take off without the keycap puller tool provided. I have tried using the switch puller tool too and it works well if you squeeze the switch tightly top and bottom before pulling it out.All in all, I am loving the experience, typing more than I ever have and being more efficient with my work! If you need that to boost your motivation to WFH, this keyboard will hopefully work for you too :)NB: Shipping and delivery were exceptionally quick as well!

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2021
review.title: Bad Stabilizers that Can't be Easily Fixed
review.review: Two issues that work in tandem to make this version of the Keychron K8 an absolute DO NOT BUY:1. It needs to be more clearly advertised that the switches are not hotswappable. All switches are soldered on. Which is fine if this was a great keyboard out of the box, but:2. The stabilizers on this thing are BAD. Like, very mushy and unresponsive. The spacebar sticks constantly. Unless I absolutely slam it, I have a 50/50 shot of my keystroke actually registering. The other keys using stabilizers are mushy at best (e.g. enter, backspace, shift).The spacebar is relatively important, and the end result is a very bad keyboard. I will be ordering the hotswappable version direct from keychron's site because I think this would actually be a very good keyboard with upgraded stabilizers. But learn from my $80 down the drain for what is ultimately some spare keyboard parts...Do not buy this keyboard from Amazon directly. You will be getting a version that is very hard to modify, with some bad key issues, and you will regret it.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2021
review.title: Solid Mac-first keyboard, with only a few caveats...
review.review: Since I needed new peripherals to go along with my new M1 Mac mini last November, after years of typing on flat MacBooks, I decided to finally treat myself to my first mechanical keyboard since the original IBM PC was offered with one.After a long online dive, when I surfaced I had decided on the 75% Keychron Wireless Backlit RGB with Brown switches and Aluminum Frame.For me, these Browns by Gateron are an acceptable compromise between mechanical feel and reasonable noise, just as long as you are okay with the lack any actual mechanical "break" when actuating. I prefer not waking up the house late at night!That being said, I do sometimes still miss a clearly felt mechanical actuation feel, but this works for me, and is still legions ahead of any membrane keyboard, or Apple's own.IThe keyboard is rather tall, but not exceptionally so.I use it with the rear feet extended for a more sloped typing angle, which helps.I ordered the matching Keychron Wooden Palm Rest in anticipation of this and it makes a big difference when I do serious typing.I also prefer the feel of the finished wood on my palms over spongy fabric covered palmrests, or the bare glass top of my desk. When just casually surfing the web or doing other non-typing-intensive tasks, I put away the palmrest since it just tends to get in the way if I have to move the keyboard around and have desk clutter.Bluetooth is rock-solid, with never a glitch or delay, ever.In fact the connection is far more reliable than with Apple's Magic Trackpad 2 that I bought at the same time.If I recall, I think I had to use a wired connection just once, to be able to boot up my brand new M1 Mac mini.This is a condition specific to only the M1 versions when using a non-Apple keyboard on a new machine.The RGB color options and patterns, though entertaining as heck at first, end up becoming more of a distraction after a while.I ended up using one preferred color pretty much all the time. Keyboard circus lights can be distracting!A note on the colors, specifically blue.Normally a color I might choose, this blue is not very bright, even when turned all the way up in the dark.I always end up using the brightest setting for all the colors, all the time, to get to a decent brightness level.Except for blue.I find it far too subtle.in my photos I use cyan/teal, which I like very much.Battery life with the RGB lighting activated is an issue, but it's addressed in the descriptions when you buy it.Expect to get a full day's use out of it, then plug it in overnight so you're ready to go in the morning.With the illumination turned off, it's much longer, maybe a few days.After nearly a year of use, I can say I am still satisfied with my purchase.I wish the lighting was a tad brighter, and the rubber on one of the folding feet has disappeared (a much bigger problem on the Keychron Palm Rest on which ALL of the pads slid right off it's base - a BIG problem since it'll wobble without!), but not enough suffer any buyers remorse.The keycaps still look good with crisp lettering, and they haven't acquired significant shine from use yet.Battery life is as purchased.it still looks and types great.Whether or not you consider it's reasonable cost vs. comparably featured keyboards from some others, it's a worthy purchase.Except for that one rubber foot-pad... When one falls off, you know more will eventually follow.Especially when you consider how awful they were on my Palmrest.I tried everything to get them to stick - unacceptable that they all fell off within a few weeks of purchase.Keychron, you make some good gear that I'm comfortable recommending to others.I want mine made right again; how does one get replacement feet, please?
product.title: Keychron K2 Wireless Bluetooth/USB Wired Gaming Mechanical Keyboard, Compact 84 Keys RGB LED Backlit N-Key Rollover Alumin...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2021
review.title: Don't waste your money; barely lasted 5 months in one spot
review.review: It looks good, but it apparently wasn't meant to last. After 5 months of use, and experimenting with more than one bluetooth receiver on my PC, it just...stopped doing anything meaningful with my PC. It won't even stay connected anymore, and even if I perform a factory reset, trying to resort to its chorded mode doesn't make a difference (in fact, it seems to get very confused, and the light effects start to slow down in weird ways). The poor thing has basically spent 99% of its life on my desk in some capacity, never really travelling anywhere, but it alas just decided to start giving up on me.I want to like it. Sometimes, it does work. The keys feel great, and I'm happy with the form factor. But I think I've been patient enough with the device. It's clearly not durable, and your money is probably best spent elsewhere.

review.title: Seems good so far
review.review: + Keycaps seem solid/sturdy - Matt type material+ Gateron brown feels similar to MX Brown with very slight difference in actuation force+ No technical problems .. Keyboard is not defective+ Enjoying the 75% size for FPS gaming- There is a slight curve on keyboard. It's not a straight incline plane from the F keys to spacebar. There's a slight curve in the middle. I prefer the straight inclined. It's not super pronounced so it doesn't bother me that much.Keyboard stand at bottom is not necessary. Makes the already thick keyboard even taller off the ground, hard to type because of the curve plus the extra angle.Keyboard already raised at the back near the F keys by design of its case. Adding the stand makes it even more raised at the back.Overall decent gaming and compact keyboard style. Keycaps are smaller than fullsize keyboard. I don't know if they make a 75% that has full sized keycaps but these smaller keycaps are pretty easy to type on.

review.title: Bluetooth issues
review.review: I bought this keyboard specifically to use on the couch with my PC so wireless functionality was a must. However, as many other reviews have stated, the bluetooth connection is very iffy. I get disconnects multiple times in a week or when typing characters will continuously repeat. It gets so bad that even a reset or turning off/on the keyboard again doesn't work. I usually end up having to pair it again. For the price of these keyboards, the feature that they advertise should actually work reliably. If this was $50 I could live with it but for the price they ask just no. Now I have this keyboard connected via a cable to my PC. This is not the outcome I wanted. If you need the wireless feature of this keyboard, buyer beware.

review.title: Had trouble pairing with Mac. Support unresponsive.
review.review: I was excited to get my hands on this keyboard. It’s one of the cleanest keyboards and the Mac specific key caps are almost impossible to find elsewhere. However I ultimately ended up going with a RK84 instead of this.I had trouble pairing this with my Mac. It would work and then stop pairing. I haven’t had the same experience with other bluetooth mechanical keyboards.I tried contacting support about this and took 2.5 weeks to get the first response. By that time I had given up and returned it. The instructions were no different than what I was able to find on forums so I doubt it would make a difference on getting it to work.Lastly, since switching to the RK84, I’ve appreciated being able to fully program the keyboard to rearrange keys. review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2021
review.title: Great keyboard!
review.review: Got this because I missed having a 75% keyboard. Been using a Kira for the past couple of years and before that, I had a crappy (but handsome) Excalibur 75% kb, this one is very nice. The only things I don't like about the keyboard is:- Lights reset whenever I switch machines or switch to Bluetooth. I have the keyboard attached to a KVM switch, whenever I switch the KVM to another machine. I'm not big on keyboard lights as I don't use shine-through keycaps. So it's pointless to have them on- Bluetooth is severely borked. It lags, types randomly by itself (usually the last key you pressed), its especially annoying when it gets stuck on backspace as it will delete everything you've typed until you hit another key.- The plastic case is plastic. I would have loved either a low-profile case or a metal one. I would have paid extra for either of those options. That being said, although it's plastic, and looks rather cheap, it's pretty solid and doesn't make weird plasticie noises when typing.If you use this keyboard with it plugged directly, it's great! Especially for the price. I highly recommend it if you are going to use it this way. But maybe do some research if you want to use this as a BT keyboard. I was hoping to be able to use it wirelessly, but I guess that's not going to happen.
product.title: Keychron K2 Hot-swappable Bluetooth Mechanical Keyboard for Mac Layout with Double Shot Keycaps/Gateron Blue Switch/White ...

Good: I really like that it has a switch to use as a Mac keyboard and take advantage of the key shortcuts (e.g. command-n). i like the mechanical feel - it has a great feel for typing.probably works great as a gaming keyboard.issues:it drains the battery in ~2 days.i could go in and mess with the light settings, turn it off every night or when i'm not using it to extend battery life, but thats a pain and not what i need for a daily use, home office keyboard.sometimes i just connect it and use it as a usb-c keyboard because i get tired of having to charge it. it is loud. others can hear it during a zoom or teams meeting. i will probably buy a different keyboard that is a better keyboard for daily and home office use.

review.review: I picked up this Keychron to replace a Logitech mechanical keyboard with Romer-G switches when I replaced my windows laptop with a Mac. I'm glad to say all my searching paid off. This keyboard is really fantastic to type on. The feel of the keys, the switch feedback, and the multiple options for connectivity make this a really great match for my work setup. I've been able to type for long periods without any discomfort, and it's quiet enough to not bother my coworkers if I have a nasty email to send out.The backlight it a little dim, which isn't a huge deal since the office is well lit. I leave the lights on, but it's hard to tell. I do wish the backlight was more controllable outside of the predefined patterns. This is absolutely a small complaint, and does not outweigh the benefits of this keyboard.Just buy it if you want a compact keyboard for Mac. You won't be disappointed.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2021
review.title: Wow
review.review: This keyboard is spectacular. I replaced my Razer Huntsman Mini with this as the Huntsman typing expereince was not what I was looking for.This on the other hand is exactly what I was looking for. I think the only real complaint I could level at it right now is that the backspace key is a little funky, but that is apparently an easy fix.The Gateron brown switches are fantastic, and I am excited about the opportunities afforded by the hot swappable nature of this keyboard.The TKL nature of the keyboard is also awesome, and saves some space on my desk (part of the reason I opted for the Huntsman mini in the first place). I appreciate the fact that this still has the function keys as well as arrow keys. I sorely missed that on the Huntsman.The RGB was a nice surprise too, since I didn't realize this model came with it! I just have mine set to blue to match my PC build.Overall, 10/10. Initial impressions are very positive. Now to maintain and lube it, since that seems to be a very common suggestion among keeb enthusiasts.The only reason I didn't give it full marks for quality of material is because of the issues I mentioned with the backspace key and the fact that the spacebar is doing the same. Other than that... This is perfect for me and the aforementioned issues may just be me adapting to a new board.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2021
review.title: I can't speak to it's longevity, but it seems like a great TKL so far.
review.review: I'm not familiar with Keychron, and I wasn't sure if I could trust it's quality, but I figured I'd take a shot with it and see how it went.I went with the Gateron Blues since that's what I'm used to typing with, and so far, this board gets high marks.The build quality is strong, and it's a heavy board, which gives me hopes that it will last a while for me.Coming from an Anne Pro II (which I still have, but it's now my travel keyboard), this is a very worthy replacement.There are three things that I would caution you with, though, if you plan to buy this.Firstly, the keycaps aren't textured and feel a little "slick" for lack of a better term.It's not a bad thing, just different than what I'm used to, but they don't feel cheap.This isn't too big of a deal, because you can always swap them for another set, or even your favorite set from the board this is replacing.Second, it is a loud board.I don't know if it's because of the aluminum housing, or the way the board is laid out in the recession of that housing, but the keystrokes echo much louder than my other keyboard.It's not bad, and if you love the sound of blues then you probably don't care about noise anyway, but it's a warning for those that have sensitive partners, roommates, or neighbors :)Lastly, this board sits high.If you don't have a wrist wrest, you may want to invest in one.All of that said, I give the board high praise and as long as it holds up, I'll recommend it to others.
product.title: Keychron K8 Tenkeyless Wireless Mechanical Keyboard for Mac, Bluetooth RGB Backlight Multitasking Type-C Wired Gaming Keyb...

Also, because of bluetooth there is less wire clutter in my table now.Takes a while to get used to typing in the beginning but use it for couple of days and it'll just feel natural. Also, the keyboard lasts me one whole work week and I charge it during the weekend. This is just an awesome keyboard.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2021
review.title: Good for gaming and everyday use, just a minor catch for productivity.
review.review: First off, don't get me wrong at all, this is a great keyboard, low profile switches, low profile case, and its low profile keycaps, it's cool. But specifically for my use case, there was a killer catch that made me return it the next day. That catch is that the keyboard is missing three keys on top of the home/end/inset group which are the print screen, scroll lock, and pause buttons. Honestly, I didn't even know they weren't in the keyboard to begin with, but only after I started using it, I found out that it wasn't there, which impacted my productivity heavily since I have them bound as shortcuts and macros for other programs. So for me, the removal of those keys was the killing catch, but to other people who may not care about the keys and only use the keyboard for gaming or everyday use that's not for productivity, then it would be a solid catch, but this keyboard just isn't for me. And after finding out that almost all Keychron keyboards don't have the three keys, I may not be able to buy any of their keyboards because of the loss of that feature.I even tried looking all over the internet for ways around it, but I just couldn't find a way that made it work well for my use case, so I just couldn't use it anymore, and therefore also don't recommend this keyboard for people who use those keys.
product.title: Keychron K1 87 Key Ultra-Thin RGB Wireless Bluetooth/USB Wired TKL Mechanical Gaming Keyboard, RGB LED Backlit Low Profile...

Not too many RGB options. Also, seemingly no brightness adjustment (but I could be wrong on this one).Both the keyboard body and the keycaps feel way cheaper than my HyperX Alloy.

I have to bang on it really hard to get the keyboard to do anything at all now. Will be switching my keyboard to HyperX.

NOTHING WILL FIX IT. I looked around different boards and it seems many people have had this issue and there is no solution.I feel like I bought a piece of trash that is now useless. Would not recommend buying. I have always had Logitech mice and am going back to them. The close to 20 years i have been using Logitech mice I have not had to fool with them trying to make the combined mice work like i have with this single Razer mouse.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2021
review.title: Exactly as advertised
review.review: I've never used the G Pro before but this mouse (G102 IC Prodigy) feels really good.There only two things that feel a bit odd but not enough to give a 4 star rating.1. The scroll wheel click action is a bit lackluster for my likings. It's not as clicky and springy as I prefer but at the end of the day it all comes down to personal preference whether you like it or not. Now, the scrolling action itself is amazing, I love it. It give you the ability to precisely change weapons because you have that feedback from the scroll wheel.2. The two side buttons are a bit on the mushy side. They are definitely mushier than what I prefer and for some people this may be a nuisance if you often use them.As for the seller and the shipping process, everything was good. The only thing is that my package was preparing for shipment for around 2 1/2 weeks but after that it shipped and within 2 days arrived but all in all it arrived within the expected delivery window, no delays or anything.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Double-clicking issue solved
review.review: I really like this mouse. However, like many other users mentioned, after a few months it started developing a problem where it would send an extra click sometimes after releasing a button. Frustrating for sure. I called the Logitech G support/warranty number on their website, and was speaking to a helpful support guy within about 45 seconds. He had a list of things to try to fix the issue before proceeding with the warranty claim. One of those things was to blow air underneath the mouse buttons to clean out any dust/debris that collected there. I did this, and so far (a couple days only) it has fixed my problem. Time will tell if it keeps being an issue, but at least for now just blowing a little air to clear the dust is a simple solution.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Great mouse, did research before buying
review.review: I did my research directly on Razer's website to find the mouse that fit my needs best. I was having issues with my previous Razer mouse, only to find that my mousepad was the cause. I actually put away my Mamba Wireless for this mouse because I prefer the soft cord and typically don't gravitate toward wireless for gaming. If you are looking for a wireless mouse, I would recommend the Mamba wireless. For wired, any of Razer's Speedflex models, including this one. I ultimately chose this one and buying here for price and dpi, as I typically game at 9,000 dpi, but like to change that a bit for different games/gameplay types.Overall, would buy again and recommend as a wired mouse. The pink is a nice color to spice up my rig.
product.title: Razer Viper Mini Ultralight Gaming Mouse: Fastest Gaming Switches - 8500 DPI Optical Sensor - Chroma RGB Underglow Lightin...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Lost Connections, bad lag, poor performance
review.review: I had been looking at this mouse for a while and finally convinced myself to buy one.I was very excited for the new mouse.My somewhat new computer has the RGB fans and lighting, so I was excited to add to my setup with this mouse and mouse dock.Add to this the fact that this is a Razer product (supposedly top tier), I thought I was getting something good.I bought this mouse, received it two days latter, returned it the next day.I let the mouse fully charge before using (per the instructions).Once it was fully charged I started using it for the last part of my work day.I was presenting on a Teams meeting and twice in the hour meeting it lost connection.Luckily I still had my other mouse connected so I was able to use it the second time to finish the meeting.Several other times through the remaining part of the day/evening the mouse would lose connection with the computer, usually requiring me to turn it off then back on again for it to start working.Other times it would lag behind very bad and I would have to wait for it to catch up to what I was trying to do.If this is "hyperspeed" technology, I would hate to see how a normal speed mouse works from Razer.I could not imagine anyone using this for gaming, it is horrible.Finally, I tried to customize the buttons on the mouse through Razer Synapse.I would set the buttons, save the setup, and if I left Razer Synapse open, the buttons would work with no issues.As soon as I closed the Razer application, it is as if the mouse would reset to factory defaults and loose all the settings I had just saved.I tried this multiple times with the same results.I even checked other sites for instructions on how to customize the mouse settings to make sure I was not missing a step, no luck.So, in addition to the loss of connection, and horrible lagging; if I were to keep them mouse I would have to open Razer Synapse every morning, setup the mouse again how I wanted it to be, then leave the application open all day just to make sure it worked as designed.I am new to Razer products like this but not new to computers.I have been working in the IS field for over a decade, and I know how to use, and troubleshoot issues with these devices.This mouse just is not a good mouse and not worth the money at all.Please don't waste your money on this overpriced, underperforming mouse.
product.title: Razer Viper Mini Ultralight Gaming Mouse: Fastest Gaming Switches - 8500 DPI Optical Sensor - Chroma RGB Underglow Lightin...

review.title: TERRIBLE. Scroll Wheel WILL Start to Squeak and Fail After 3 Months.
review.review: For the first few months, it was good. Everything worked as it should. The cord was not a problem and extended long enough to reach my tower. I enjoyed having two buttons on the side for gaming purposes. The mouse fits nicely in your hand. The scroll wheel and the design light up a pretty white hue. Aesthetically pleasing and matches my white set-up.BUT. After 3 months, just this past September, the scroll wheel started to make this OBNOXIOUS screeching sound every time I scrolled. I didn't realize how much I scroll until this started to happen. It was ear aching and I looked up how to fix it, saw that MANY others with this mouse had a similar problem, and the fix requires you to dissemble the whole thing to oil it. I am not savvy with that so I left it alone in hopes that it would just go away with time.Well the squeaking has reduced but now everytime I attempt to scroll, it causes my window to jitter and scroll back the OPPOSITE way. So here I am battling with my mouse to scroll smoothly for just a couple inches. It's the most frustrating thing I've experienced with a mouse and I've finally given up and am purchasing a different one. I never had a mouse that couldn't even last a single year... this is a poor product in my opinion.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: Completely useless for my target purpose (gaming)
review.review: I've had a SteelSeries Rival 310 for a couple of years now and am perfectly happy with it, but then I found out about this model which seemed like a straight upgrade to me after watching and reading a couple of reviews. After getting it out of the box, I was excited to test it out in my favorite game, DOTA 2. Very quickly however I found out that unlike the two side buttons of the Rival 310, which are extremely easy and super natural to press, all 5 of the side buttons of the Rival 5 were exceedingly difficult and unnatural to press, and also led to mouse movement due to the force required to press the buttons. Also, my thumb had to be in a very weird and cramped position to be able to press the side buttons at all. The big forward side button was basically impossible to press, and the up/down rocker was very difficult to press as well. From the natural thumb resting position, it requires a significant movement to be able to press even the closest two ("back/forward") buttons, unlike with the Rival 310 where those buttons are basically instant-press as soon as you think about them. Therefore, this mouse is completely unusable for playing Dota 2, and I would guess any other game.I have medium to slightly large sized hands, and I would imagine someone with very large hands / long fingers, or some specific grip style might be able to use the side buttons (I am using a standard grip), but for me they are completely unusable. Again, the Rival 310 side buttons are perfectly usable so I'm unsure why they decided to move them way out of reach.The other features of the mouse are fine, as is the build quality, although I heavily dislike the default-on lighting, and the fact that the RGB lighting settings are NOT stored on the mouse itself, so if you use it with a different PC or laptop on which you don't have the SteelSeries software installed, you are forced to have your mouse glow super bright in random colors. The cable is OK too.I hope they make a "real" upgraded version of the Rival 310, with more side buttons, that are natural to reach, like the two existing ones, and not this "apparent" upgrade which is really a huge downgrade.
product.title: SteelSeries Rival 3 Gaming Mouse - 8,500 CPI TrueMove Core Optical Sensor - 6 Programmable Buttons - Split Trigger Buttons...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: Unacceptable Battery Life
review.review: I would have thought battery life would be great considering how quickly the mouse goes to sleep, but what would otherwise be a solid mouse for the price is ruined by terrible battery life. I am having to replace the AAAs in my mouse what feels like every 1-2 weeks.There is a power saving setting in the Steelseries software, but it is locked at 150hz polling rate which makes even browsing the web clunky and unresponsive. I especially notice it in the scroll wheel, which feels like it drops roughly every other click.I would recommend this mouse only if you have a battery charging station within reach of your desk and can live with the inconvenience. I will be replacing mine with a Logitech G305, and I guess this will be a fine emergency backup as it is past the return period.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review.title: Probably good, but mine wasn't.
review.review: Right off the bat, it's a comfortable mouse. Feels good for my hands, but your mileage may vary. That's basically where the good experiences end for me though.After a day of using it, the signal would cut out for seconds at a time. Tried a different usb port, tried a different machine entirely, it's either the dongle or the hardware in the mouse itself. Ok no problem, switched it to bluetooth and it worked for a bit but also would cut out occasionally though not as often as over the dongle.Ok, so I began troubleshooting. I downloaded the software and updated the firmware, which didn't help anything really, the mouse still had signal issues. Also of note is that the steelseries pc software is one of the more buggier third party apps I've experienced. At a certain point I needed to jump through hoops to get the mouse to update the DPI profiles properly like rapidly switching back and forth between bluetooth and radio in order to get the software to finally push the updated config to the mouse.So where does that leave you? Well, it's a crapshoot like 9 out of 10 modern "gaming" products. These companies cut corners somewhere, and usually a safe bet for them is to skimp on quality control. Despite this, people seem happy with the mouse, so buy it with free returns only just in case.
product.title: SteelSeries Rival 3 Gaming Mouse - 8,500 CPI TrueMove Core Optical Sensor - 6 Programmable Buttons - Split Trigger Buttons...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2021
review.title: Side-grade to the V2. Great if you never owned the V2 / Razer Basilisk Ultimate.
review.review: When compared to the V2 / Razer Basilisk Ultimate , after 1 week of use:TLDR - Scroll wheel and LED upgrades are good.But... the +/- resistance option for the scroll wheel on the underside of the mouse is now gone. I'm not a fan of the changes to the button internal switches and how they feel or sound.Pros: I like the changes to the scroll wheel. No complaints there. I like that they finally copied one of the features I loved about older Logitech mice. The LED zones on the bottom of the mouse are sweet for you RGB fans (which you probably area if you are buying this).Cons: (It's hard to know if these are little defects with the specific mouse I got, or all V3s are like this). I'm not a huge fan of these upgraded switches for the buttons. I liked the way the V2 felt and sounded better. These are louder and require more force to press. The thumb buttons for forward/back or buttons 3 and 4, feel and sound different from each other. It really annoys me. And the new version of the button 5 or the sniper button, feels worse than the V2 for sure. The button has farther travel distance, feels more mushy, and does not press smoothly. Pressing it feels like the bottom side of the button angles down more than the top. I also hoped this button would be closer to your thumb than it was with V2, which for me always felt too far away and I would need to adjust my whole hang to press it. With the V3, for better or worse, its in the same exact place as the V2.I'm actually debating buying another one to see if the switches feel or sound any better, and then return the worse of the two.The +/- resistance option for the scroll wheel on the underside of the mouse is now gone. No way to adjust resistance. I really wish they had kept that feature.Some people wont like the change to the weight, but I wont mind it.With all that said, if you never owned the V2 / Razer Basilisk Ultimate, you'll be happy with this mouse.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2021
review.title: A better wired V2, but with some slight setbacks
review.review: The infinite scroll wheel is awesome to have especially for someone like me who's switching over from a Logitech MX Master. The Basilisk's shape isn't as comfortable for my hands as that mouse, mainly because it's lacking a little in size compared to the MX. This mouse is much nicer for gaming though as there are more DPI options, and honestly the clicks seem a little more responsive for gaming.The software control for this mouse is good, but I feel it's not as responsive as the wired Basilisk V2 that I had was. This is mainly with regards to Razer's Chroma software. I tried to have the bottom portion of LEDs disabled, but it can be pretty laggy or buggy as an effect. The main reason why I tried to turn off the bottom portion of RGB lights is because it can be pretty distracting. The lighting around that area looks totally badass, but the reflection it makes against the surface looks kind of ugly. Honestly, I think V2 looks a little bit more classy because it's not leaving an RGB shadow behind by default.Still I think the V3 is overall a better upgrade over the V2 because of the infinite scroll wheel. If you don't mind the flashier RGB, this will give you the same comfort as the V2, but with more versatile functionality.

But after about a month of the Basilisk V3, I have run into many problems like slam clicking, the sensor spinning out and the mouse wheel detecting movement on its own. (no infinite scroll wheel is not on) I wanted to love this mouse but with these problems, I just can't. Looking past the defects that I have experienced I still hate that it weighs heavier than the V2. You can debate if having an infinite scroll wheel is useful enough to an extra 10+ grams. Sadly I will be returning this mouse.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2021
review.title: Arrived broken
review.review: Mouse is a bit heavier, and the mouse buttons a bit more (aurally) clicky and (physically) bouncy than the mice I'm familiar with (that being both cheap ones and ones in a similar price range to this one). I'm actually having the impression that $5 mice have more responsive buttons, due to the delay that the "bounce" of the buttons causes.I believe the clicking is about on par with a mechanical keyboard in volume.The cable is fluid enough, but a bit shorter than all the other mice I've used [making it impossible to reach the top of my desk from the back USB ports, forcing me to plug it into the front], and a bit draggy if you don't give it a bit of coil by the mouse [though still less draggy than a heavy stiff cable].The mouse wheel isn't especially pleasant to use, due mostly to an uncomfortable surface design. The middle button actually felt more like a proper mouse button than the left and right ones, and seemed responsive enough.Basic assessment aside, my experience with the mouse was overall a disaster. Upon hooking it up to my PC, the mouse failed to respond properly on any surface I put it to, as well as to both rapid and carefully inched motions.Regardless of attempt, it alternated between having a sort of delayed, jolting response to motion [the cursor basically hopping across the screen in a manner usually reserved for when your system memory is locked up] and having making shorter but similarly delayed jumps that then flickered a bit around the initial stopping position. Thus, in the first case, you have to guess where it'll land and, in the second instance, you might be able to get it to land near a button only to flicker off by a cusror length immediately after.I downloaded the management software for the company's products, but clicking the executable took me to an install confirmation prompt that, when accepted, simply vanished without actually proceeding to any kind of installation. Top quality, that.Looking at the software images provided in the Amazon listing, I notice that the sensor has a bright red glow similar to all other mice I've used. For the mouse I received, I had to put my eye right up touching the mouse just to see a very faint glow deep inside the mouse. With that in mind, I'm inclined to believe my issue was less one of general mouse quality or software configuration, and more of having a faulty sensor light.Either way, even if I did simply have a defective mouse, the overall quality of the mouse simply did not impress me for its price range. As I noted at the start, nearly every component of the mouse was far lower quality than I was expecting. The only redeemable parts- the grip/surface and the middle button, were simply average in quality, not notably standing out against budget mice.In the end, this mouse had nothing to offer but massive disappointment.

review.title: If your hands are any bigger than mine you'll be fine.
review.review: Very basic and simple design, if you're afraid that you'll find other "ergonomic" designs weird or uncomfortable, this is a reliable choice. And if you're a lefty, this is a decent choice as well due to it's symmetrical design (other than the side buttons). I have very small hands, and during games like LoL, C&C, or other games that may require a lot of micro and clicking, my fingers began to feel worn out due to the size of the mouse compared to my hand and the position of my fingers. For most adults it should be fine. The RGB is a nice touch, not too crazy and doesn't add much to the cost. Clicks and mouse wheel are nice. Overall, very good budget mouse. Nothing super crazy or special, but extremely good price to performance.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2021
review.title: You get what you pay for
review.review: Where does all your money go and why is it so much? That's the $150 question for everybody. The TLDR is that it's incredibly well built, fully wireless, responsive, and the lightest mouse on the market. And it's pearly white.I don't know what other relevant details I can give. This mouse has been stress-tested by the best in the tech. industry and Logitech weren't lying, this mouse is FAST. It has incredibly low latency, very good battery life (I mean...there's zero RGB lighting), and is quite possibly the safest shape a mouse can come in. If you don't consider your hands much larger or smaller than most people, it will probably be comfortable holding this mouse.The visual design is intelligent. It has this elegance that isn't the embarrassing "gamer" stylings of other products but isn't so minimalistic that you wouldn't immediately recognize this mouse at first glance. Anybody who's ever used this mouse knows exactly what this feels and looks like.Is this mouse necessary? Absolutely not. I think the only thing more over-the-top than this mouse is the amount of R&D and feedback Logitech went through to create one of the best mice in PC gaming. I do prefer the Razer Viper Ultimate over this because I prefer the texture and shape. I am also bothered that a $150 computer mouse looks almost too simple. Also, in my opinion, the Viper Ultimate doesn't feel that much heavier than this. I wanted to note that, in case anybody wanted a cheaper alternative.Overall, this mouse is a flex, or for anybody who wants to go out of their way to spend time and money on their gaming hobby (gaming career maybe?). I considered buying this since it launched and was not disappointed. Here's to hoping I get my $150 out of this mouse.
