review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2021
review.title: Side-grade to the V2. Great if you never owned the V2 / Razer Basilisk Ultimate.
review.review: When compared to the V2 / Razer Basilisk Ultimate , after 1 week of use:TLDR - Scroll wheel and LED upgrades are good.But... the +/- resistance option for the scroll wheel on the underside of the mouse is now gone. I'm not a fan of the changes to the button internal switches and how they feel or sound.Pros: I like the changes to the scroll wheel. No complaints there. I like that they finally copied one of the features I loved about older Logitech mice. The LED zones on the bottom of the mouse are sweet for you RGB fans (which you probably area if you are buying this).Cons: (It's hard to know if these are little defects with the specific mouse I got, or all V3s are like this). I'm not a huge fan of these upgraded switches for the buttons. I liked the way the V2 felt and sounded better. These are louder and require more force to press. The thumb buttons for forward/back or buttons 3 and 4, feel and sound different from each other. It really annoys me. And the new version of the button 5 or the sniper button, feels worse than the V2 for sure. The button has farther travel distance, feels more mushy, and does not press smoothly. Pressing it feels like the bottom side of the button angles down more than the top. I also hoped this button would be closer to your thumb than it was with V2, which for me always felt too far away and I would need to adjust my whole hang to press it. With the V3, for better or worse, its in the same exact place as the V2.I'm actually debating buying another one to see if the switches feel or sound any better, and then return the worse of the two.The +/- resistance option for the scroll wheel on the underside of the mouse is now gone. No way to adjust resistance. I really wish they had kept that feature.Some people wont like the change to the weight, but I wont mind it.With all that said, if you never owned the V2 / Razer Basilisk Ultimate, you'll be happy with this mouse.
product.title: Razer Basilisk V3 Customizable Ergonomic Gaming Mouse: Fastest Gaming Mouse Switch - Chroma RGB Lighting - 26K DPI Optical...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2021
review.title: A better wired V2, but with some slight setbacks
review.review: The infinite scroll wheel is awesome to have especially for someone like me who's switching over from a Logitech MX Master. The Basilisk's shape isn't as comfortable for my hands as that mouse, mainly because it's lacking a little in size compared to the MX. This mouse is much nicer for gaming though as there are more DPI options, and honestly the clicks seem a little more responsive for gaming.The software control for this mouse is good, but I feel it's not as responsive as the wired Basilisk V2 that I had was. This is mainly with regards to Razer's Chroma software. I tried to have the bottom portion of LEDs disabled, but it can be pretty laggy or buggy as an effect. The main reason why I tried to turn off the bottom portion of RGB lights is because it can be pretty distracting. The lighting around that area looks totally badass, but the reflection it makes against the surface looks kind of ugly. Honestly, I think V2 looks a little bit more classy because it's not leaving an RGB shadow behind by default.Still I think the V3 is overall a better upgrade over the V2 because of the infinite scroll wheel. If you don't mind the flashier RGB, this will give you the same comfort as the V2, but with more versatile functionality.

review.title: Seriously, the software is not compatible with MacOS?
review.review: It's 2021 so can someone please tell me why Razer is making software (for one of their more popular mice) which is not compatible with MacOS? Let me clarify, you'll be told to download Synapse 2, which is Mac compatible, but Synapse 2 is not compatible with the Razer Basilisk V2 – only Synapse 3 is compatible with this mouse. However, Synapse 3 is not compatible with Mac OS, so basically you cannot take advantage of all the mouse has to offer. You may as well be using a $10 USB mouse from Walgreens because without the software it offers the same level of customization.Arrrrrggggg!

review.title: Not a good mouse for work!
review.review: Razer mice in particular have a problem with the switches wearing out within a year or so of purchase. This mouse has those same switches. Also, with no pinky support it winds up really hurting your hands after prolonged use. Thumb support is there, but it tapers off at an angle that causes a lot of friction. It's just not designed for a comfortable fit. If you're looking for a gaming mouse you want to replace every year or so, it's fine, but please don't waste your money if you're an artist or someone that spends a lot of time on the mouse.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review.title: Click away
review.review: Perhaps one of nicest mouse clicking sounds and feeling I have ever heard with hardly any delay between clicks.However a major nitpick I have is when you use the mouse for the first time on a pc it opens up a download prompt for the software which is convenient but distracting when using it on a different pc for the first time (haven't tested it just hypothetically speaking)To use certain features i.e macros you need the software to be installed AND be in the background but overall mouse control you dont need the software.After you figure our your button bindings delete the software then have your pc forget the mouse then reconnect the mouse and close out the download prompt (after you do it once it won't reappear unless you make your pc forget it) This solved the issue I had with it skipping abruptly both in-game and browsing.After these changes its a very solid mouse and felt right at home using it without needing to make any adjustments.Only nitpick I have is that you can't get custom shells individually in the official website or other websites.

review.title: A major step back from the G602...

Sadly, I was very wrong. The G604 doesn't improve on the G602 in any way, and clearly took a major step back in terms of quality / quality control. The left mouse button squeaks loudly when used and often sticks in the engaged position when clicked. The scroll wheel is also infinitely worse (though I rarely use it anyway). I'm not mad, I'm just disappointed.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2021
review.title: The mouse is fine, but the mandatory G HUB sofware is awful
review.review: So Logitech decided to discontinue their software for various devices and consolidate them into on grand app to rule them all: G HUB. Not a bad strategy, but the execution was terrible.The mouse itself is pretty good, but there is no point extolling its virtues, since you shouldn't buy it anyway. In fact, you should not buy any Logitech wireless produce until they've fixed G HUB. Or eradicated it, hired a new engineering team, and written something better to replace it. Or, you know, just reverted to the LGS app that their older mice used that worked just fine for years.There are many reviews detailing G HUB's failings, so I won't list all of them here. I'll add my latest experience to the pile:I got the mouse and installed G HUB several months ago on a system with Windows 8.1. Today, I used the in-app button to upgrade to the latest version. But it turns out the latest version is only compatible with Windows 10. So it tried to upgrade itself and hung forever instead, showing me the cutesy animation that Logitech's engineering department apparently spent their time on instead of doing QA. I didn't even get the courtesy of an error message.As a programmer myself, I can tell you that's an inexcusable, novice, facepalm-grade error. An auto-updater should *always* perform proper version and requirements checks.Anyway, I headed to Logitech's site to find an installer for the earlier Windows 8 compatible version. I knew it existed, since just an hour before it was up and running on my system. But no luck, they now offer Windows 10 or Mac only. So then off to reddit, where quickly I found the hidden link to the older Win7 and Win8 versions. Pay no mind to the "There are no Downloads for this Version" message! It's there, or at least it was today, though it may be gone by the time you need it.That installer then failed because it was confused by the current, corrupt installation. So I spent some time ripping that one out by the roots from multiple file system and registry locations. After pausing for a moment to say goodbye to the mouse settings/macros I spent time writing, now all gone, I was able to reinstall it.The whole affair reminded me of this bit from the HHGTTG:“But the plans were on display…”“On display? I eventually had to go down to the cellar to find them.”“That’s the display department.”“With a flashlight.”“Ah, well, the lights had probably gone.”“So had the stairs.”“But look, you found the notice, didn’t you?”“Yes,” said Arthur, “yes I did. It was on display in the bottom of a locked filing cabinet stuck in a disused lavatory with a sign on the door saying ‘Beware of the Leopard.”
product.title: Logitech G604 LIGHTSPEED Wireless Gaming Mouse with 15 programmable controls, up to 240 hour battery life, dual wireless c...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2021
review.title: Can't Recommend
review.review: This mouse has really been a disappointment.Battery life is nowhere near what I was expecting. I replace batteries in my M510 maybe every 8 month's. That mouse is used 8 hours a day for work. Since I got this in July I have had to replace the batteries three times already (almost monthly).Functionally, this mouse would be terrible for any type of FPS. Half the time the first click I make doesn't register and I have to click again. I haven't experienced the double clicks that others have reported, but they may only be a matter of time. The two main buttons overhang the front of the mouse, so if you bump it into anything while moving it, you end up with random clicks.And last but definitely not least, the G-Hub software is absolute garbage. The interface is terrible and difficult to use. Nothing is where you expect it be and you have to click thru different screens to do basic things like remap buttons. It is buggy as hell, locking up when trying to update, requiring uninstalling and reinstalling it to get it to work. Half the time the profiles you get put in and saved don't activate when they should. For G-Hub alone I would say to stay away from any Logitech product that uses it.
product.title: Logitech G604 LIGHTSPEED Wireless Gaming Mouse with 15 programmable controls, up to 240 hour battery life, dual wireless c...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2021
review.title: Excellent physical design, absolutely unusable due to GHub.
review.review: I had my previous Logitech gaming mouse for almost 10-years before it gave up on life. So I went for this G604.It feels great in my hand, cradles my thumb perfectly and the buttons are all accessible for my tiny lady hands. Excellent design!But... The Ghub software? Randomly drops profiles so none of the programmed buttons work. Just randomly. It makes the mouse totally unusable. I will be in the middle of a project I rely on macro'd buttons to do for work? Mouse decides to stop working. I will be gaming and try to hit a macro? Bam! Dead!Trying to find a way to load the profile onboard is obtuse. This mouse is harder to program than units with more buttons were 10-years ago.Thing is, I trusted Logitech enough to throw out the package so I cannot even return this failure of a device. Ghub will spend hours trying to update and fail to, which leads to uninstalling and reinstalling just to use the %^&%^ mouse to do basic ^&%&^ mouse things. I have never had this kind of issue with Logitech devices and I have been a loyal customer for decades.Looks like I will be dropping $300 to buy a new copy of the same Logitech gaming mouse I got 10-years ago, because I know that it will survive being used for 16-hours a day for close to 10-years and remain a viable, reliable option until USB technology is completely phased out of PCs.

review.title: My favorite mouse of all time
review.review: I’ve been alive for 40 years and have used lots of computer mice. This is my favorite. I had the wired version for four years before buying this Bluetooth one. I really like the way the casing feels, my hand doesn’t cramp up while using it and it’s great to easily switch between wired and wireless modes. It lets me share the one mouse with my work MacBook and gaming PC. I just leave it wired with the PC and when I want to use it for work I switch to Bluetooth and unplug it.
product.title: Razer DeathAdder v2 Pro Wireless Gaming Mouse: 20K DPI Optical Sensor - 3X Faster Than Mechanical Optical Switch - Chroma ...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2021
review.title: Quality and lifespan is a fraction of what Razer used to be
review.review: This is my 3rd DeathAdder mouse. The first two I used for about 4 years each before having to upgrade to a new version due to wear and tear. I am 10 months in to using this version and there is already a tear forming in the thumbgrip. Razer has denied a warranty claim saying it is "customer induced". I guess their product lifespan has dropped so much that they will no longer honor a warranty claim inside the 1-year period they advertise.I'd recommend looking at other brands. Razer quality has degraded compared to the previous models.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2021
review.title: Customer Service is Awful
review.review: Didn’t work right out of the box. It was a gift for my son so I ordered it early and by the time he used it, it was too late to return it thru Amazon (which is stupid for products that are clearly never used but I digress..) I had to deal with Razer support which is excessively painful. The switch on the bottom won’t move and they want VIDEO of the switch not moving?!?! It also turns itself off when he’s gaming and they want someone to stand there and video him gaming until it shuts off. Really? I would happily send it back to exchange it, but they want all this other time wasting crap first. Not happy. It’s a high end piece of garbage. If you buy it, pray you don’t have to deal with their customer service. I’d give them zero stars if I could.

review.title: Get the wired version
review.review: This is the worst wireless mouse I have ever used. The battery only lasts 1-2 days max, and when you plug the cord into the mouse to charge it, you need to restart you computer in order to get the mouse to work in wired mode. What a piece of junk. Imagine being in the middle of a game and your mouse dies and you need to restart to get it working again... this is not a gaming mouse. I think razer intentionally designed the mouse to work this way to get you to buy their charging dock for the mouse... don't waste your money like I did, just get the wired version

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2021
review.title: I hope you have big hands.
review.review: This mouse is definitely *not* for people who have hands on the smaller side of average. I don't have tiny hands by any means, but this mouse is extremely awkward for me to use without accidentally hitting the first row of keys on the side. My hand simply doesn't wrap around enough of the bulk of this thing to get a good grip on only the non-button portions of the mouse. This leads to firing off skills or macros that I absolutely do not intend to use yet while just moving the mouse around; I've had to disable the first row of keys entirely to avoid this.Another problem the size presents is that it won't consistently hold down the LMB if I want to click and drag; it'll often let go prematurely because my fingertips apparently don't reach far enough forward to get the leverage it needs to keep the sensors in contact.Years ago, I had a Naga that had plates you could swap out to adjust the size appropriate to your needs, but they apparently don't make them anymore, and are going with a "one (large) size fits all" approach. This is a major shame, because it's excluding a fairly significant portion of the gaming population.If you have big ol' hands, then I bet this mouse would work great for you. It's lightweight (almost too lightweight) and pretty responsive.
product.title: Razer Naga Trinity Gaming Mouse: 16,000 DPI Optical Sensor - Chroma RGB Lighting - Interchangeable Side Plate w/ 2, 7, 12 ...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2021
review.title: The only premium wireless mmo mouse. needs some competition
review.review: The only MMO mouse that is wireless, from a name brand company.Features: comes with PTFE mouse feet which is very generous and not common, usually you buy these aftermarket.fairly light considering all the hardware on it. another big plus.comes with 3 side plates. one with 12 buttons, one with 2, and one with I think 6? very cool and convenient, and easy to swap out.no perceivable latency, however I originally bought this mouse used. it would lose connection for several seconds, which is unusable for gaming and just annoying in any other application, especially at this price.I returned it and bought a new one, which has the same issue but only loses connectivity very briefly, enough for me to just ignore. I dont play shooters or 1st person games with it so whatever.the razer software has automatic profile switching. you can set up specific keybinds for any program (even ones that arent games) and when you switch to a different program the keybinds automatically swap. this is insanely useful for video editing, music production, MMOs, all kinds of things.battery life is great. naturally, the lights suck a lot of it up but you should turn them off if you want it to last long.I like the ergonomics a lot, I think it feels great in my hand. it's meant to be held with your fingers laid on it and your palm mostly lifted off of it. it feels very comfortable but I'd like it slightly lighter for easier movement.if it werent for the disconnection this would be 5/5 stars. it has zero ccompetition, is feature packed and is good at what it does.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2021
review.title: Another bit of e-waste
review.review: Worked very well out of the box for 2-3 months. All of a sudden it stopped working via bluetooth or the dongle. I have tried multiple batteries. Have tried updating drivers both via Windows and Razer's firmware updater. Have installed Razer's ridiculous software which requires you to create an account just to open the software. NOTHING WILL FIX IT. I looked around different boards and it seems many people have had this issue and there is no solution.I feel like I bought a piece of trash that is now useless. Would not recommend buying. I have always had Logitech mice and am going back to them. The close to 20 years i have been using Logitech mice I have not had to fool with them trying to make the combined mice work like i have with this single Razer mouse.

review.title: Lightweight and Comfortable
review.review: I actually use this for working in CAD. I love the ability to adjust sensitivity on the fly, plus the extra programmable buttons. The cable for the wired version is very flexible, and doesn't ever get in the way or move the mouse like the old corded mice I've used. My one complaint is that the side scroll doesn't repeat when you hold it, but this can be worked around with a simple macro. While I use another mouse for gaming, I'd have no problems switching them out.

I really like the g502, but the scroll wheel thing is dumb and kind of useless. I use that button for remapping, and its kind of important for my muscle memory.The battery life is great, i havent had it die once and i have rgb on, using it for about a week. RND is great on it, good quality, smooth clicks on both main actuators. It fits really nicely in my hand (mostly claw grip, but i rest my palm on the back, medium hands). The pads on the bottom are literal butter. It glides with 0 friction, even on my admittedly worn mouse mat.Honestly a great mouse.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: Enjoyed the Mouse but it Broke
review.review: I enjoyed the mouse for 3 months or so but then the mouse wheel went wonky. I didn't have the issues others reported here with the buttons or the DPI, but one day the mouse wheel suddenly stopped working correctly-- jumped all over the place or wouldn't respond. review.title: Great mouse, did research before buying
review.review: I did my research directly on Razer's website to find the mouse that fit my needs best. I was having issues with my previous Razer mouse, only to find that my mousepad was the cause. I actually put away my Mamba Wireless for this mouse because I prefer the soft cord and typically don't gravitate toward wireless for gaming. If you are looking for a wireless mouse, I would recommend the Mamba wireless. For wired, any of Razer's Speedflex models, including this one. I ultimately chose this one and buying here for price and dpi, as I typically game at 9,000 dpi, but like to change that a bit for different games/gameplay types.Overall, would buy again and recommend as a wired mouse. The pink is a nice color to spice up my rig.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Lost Connections, bad lag, poor performance
review.review: I had been looking at this mouse for a while and finally convinced myself to buy one.I was very excited for the new mouse.My somewhat new computer has the RGB fans and lighting, so I was excited to add to my setup with this mouse and mouse dock.Add to this the fact that this is a Razer product (supposedly top tier), I thought I was getting something good.I bought this mouse, received it two days latter, returned it the next day.I let the mouse fully charge before using (per the instructions).Once it was fully charged I started using it for the last part of my work day.I was presenting on a Teams meeting and twice in the hour meeting it lost connection.Luckily I still had my other mouse connected so I was able to use it the second time to finish the meeting.Several other times through the remaining part of the day/evening the mouse would lose connection with the computer, usually requiring me to turn it off then back on again for it to start working.Other times it would lag behind very bad and I would have to wait for it to catch up to what I was trying to do.If this is "hyperspeed" technology, I would hate to see how a normal speed mouse works from Razer.I could not imagine anyone using this for gaming, it is horrible.Finally, I tried to customize the buttons on the mouse through Razer Synapse.I would set the buttons, save the setup, and if I left Razer Synapse open, the buttons would work with no issues.As soon as I closed the Razer application, it is as if the mouse would reset to factory defaults and loose all the settings I had just saved.I tried this multiple times with the same results.I even checked other sites for instructions on how to customize the mouse settings to make sure I was not missing a step, no luck.So, in addition to the loss of connection, and horrible lagging; if I were to keep them mouse I would have to open Razer Synapse every morning, setup the mouse again how I wanted it to be, then leave the application open all day just to make sure it worked as designed.I am new to Razer products like this but not new to computers.I have been working in the IS field for over a decade, and I know how to use, and troubleshoot issues with these devices.This mouse just is not a good mouse and not worth the money at all.Please don't waste your money on this overpriced, underperforming mouse.
product.title: Razer Viper Ultimate Hyperspeed Lightest Wireless Gaming Mouse & RGB Charging Dock: Fastest Gaming Mouse Switch - 20K DPI ...

review.review: I ordered this mouse because I wanted to switch to wireless mouse experience. I really like this mouse, nice and comfortable design and it fits perfectely in my hand with my claw grip.The only thing that keeps me back to give it 5 stars is the wireless modes. when I switch to 2.4GHz Slipstream wireless mode I get so much lags every 5 seconds which is awful for gaming, you just can't play games like this. When I switch to Bluetooth mode the amount of lags decrease but not completely and you can't controll the RGB lightning when using Bluetooth mode.I have to use the wired mode for smooth experience.UPDATE: I connected the 2.4GHz Slipstream receiver to the front panel and I have 0 lags, also can't notice any lags in bluetooth mode anymore.Advice: Don't connect the Slipstream receiver to the back of your PC and you won't get any lags.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2021
review.title: Side-grade to the V2. Great if you never owned the V2 / Razer Basilisk Ultimate.
review.review: When compared to the V2 / Razer Basilisk Ultimate , after 1 week of use:TLDR - Scroll wheel and LED upgrades are good.But... the +/- resistance option for the scroll wheel on the underside of the mouse is now gone. I'm not a fan of the changes to the button internal switches and how they feel or sound.Pros: I like the changes to the scroll wheel. No complaints there. I like that they finally copied one of the features I loved about older Logitech mice. The LED zones on the bottom of the mouse are sweet for you RGB fans (which you probably area if you are buying this).Cons: (It's hard to know if these are little defects with the specific mouse I got, or all V3s are like this). I'm not a huge fan of these upgraded switches for the buttons. I liked the way the V2 felt and sounded better. These are louder and require more force to press. The thumb buttons for forward/back or buttons 3 and 4, feel and sound different from each other. It really annoys me. And the new version of the button 5 or the sniper button, feels worse than the V2 for sure. The button has farther travel distance, feels more mushy, and does not press smoothly. Pressing it feels like the bottom side of the button angles down more than the top. I also hoped this button would be closer to your thumb than it was with V2, which for me always felt too far away and I would need to adjust my whole hang to press it. With the V3, for better or worse, its in the same exact place as the V2.I'm actually debating buying another one to see if the switches feel or sound any better, and then return the worse of the two.The +/- resistance option for the scroll wheel on the underside of the mouse is now gone. No way to adjust resistance. I really wish they had kept that feature.Some people wont like the change to the weight, but I wont mind it.With all that said, if you never owned the V2 / Razer Basilisk Ultimate, you'll be happy with this mouse.
product.title: Razer Basilisk V3 Customizable Ergonomic Gaming Mouse: Fastest Gaming Mouse Switch - Chroma RGB Lighting - 26K DPI Optical...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2021
review.title: A better wired V2, but with some slight setbacks
review.review: The infinite scroll wheel is awesome to have especially for someone like me who's switching over from a Logitech MX Master. The Basilisk's shape isn't as comfortable for my hands as that mouse, mainly because it's lacking a little in size compared to the MX. This mouse is much nicer for gaming though as there are more DPI options, and honestly the clicks seem a little more responsive for gaming.The software control for this mouse is good, but I feel it's not as responsive as the wired Basilisk V2 that I had was. This is mainly with regards to Razer's Chroma software. I tried to have the bottom portion of LEDs disabled, but it can be pretty laggy or buggy as an effect. The main reason why I tried to turn off the bottom portion of RGB lights is because it can be pretty distracting. The lighting around that area looks totally badass, but the reflection it makes against the surface looks kind of ugly. Honestly, I think V2 looks a little bit more classy because it's not leaving an RGB shadow behind by default.Still I think the V3 is overall a better upgrade over the V2 because of the infinite scroll wheel. If you don't mind the flashier RGB, this will give you the same comfort as the V2, but with more versatile functionality.

review.review: First of all the RGB on this mouse is slick.I has the DeathAdder Chroma (which was old, and the RGB didn't work with Synapse 3), but I loved the feel of it.This mouse had that similar feel, I actually may like this mouse's feel more than the DeathAdder and I'm happy with my decision for this mouse over the DeathAdder 2.I normally stick with what is familiar, and glad I broke out of my comfort zone.It glides easily across my desk and the DPI adjustable thing which I rarely ever use is still nice to have in case I ever need it.I do like you can reprogram the buttons (and those thumb buttons I have surprisingly found good uses for).One thing I'll say is the right mouse button sometimes gets accidentally pressed.Could be my long Diablo 3 constant clicking that my hand just hits the mouse button on accident frequently, but resting my hand on the mouse I don't feel it should be that easy that accidentally clicking occurs.So would have been 5 star, but subtracted half a star for those weird accidental mouse clicks.Subtracted another half only because it's not wireless for this price!

review.title: Left-Click Stopped Working After A Few Months
review.review: I purchased this mouse for light gaming and typical web browsing. Within 6 months, I noticed the left-click was not holding down correctly. Physically it felt fine, but it was basically unplayable in games. I tried every solution and the problem only got worse over time so I figured it was a hardware problem rather than a software issue. I took great care of the mouse and used it VERY lightly yet it still gave out quickly. Not to mention the Razer Synapse program is terrible. Unfortunately for me, the company that sold me the product through Amazon, "TECHLOBBY", is not an authorized seller of Razer products so the 2 year manufacturers warranty did NOT cover this issue. On Razer's website, Amazon is an authorized seller of Razer products but many of the companies that sell through Amazon are not so it is very misleading. This mouse is no longer manufactured by Razer so don't even bother buying it. For $50, this mouse became useless after a few months of light use, DO NOT RECOMEND.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2021
review.title: I hope you have big hands.
review.review: This mouse is definitely *not* for people who have hands on the smaller side of average. I don't have tiny hands by any means, but this mouse is extremely awkward for me to use without accidentally hitting the first row of keys on the side. My hand simply doesn't wrap around enough of the bulk of this thing to get a good grip on only the non-button portions of the mouse. This leads to firing off skills or macros that I absolutely do not intend to use yet while just moving the mouse around; I've had to disable the first row of keys entirely to avoid this.Another problem the size presents is that it won't consistently hold down the LMB if I want to click and drag; it'll often let go prematurely because my fingertips apparently don't reach far enough forward to get the leverage it needs to keep the sensors in contact.Years ago, I had a Naga that had plates you could swap out to adjust the size appropriate to your needs, but they apparently don't make them anymore, and are going with a "one (large) size fits all" approach. This is a major shame, because it's excluding a fairly significant portion of the gaming population.If you have big ol' hands, then I bet this mouse would work great for you. It's lightweight (almost too lightweight) and pretty responsive.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2021
review.title: The only premium wireless mmo mouse. needs some competition
review.review: The only MMO mouse that is wireless, from a name brand company.Features: comes with PTFE mouse feet which is very generous and not common, usually you buy these aftermarket.fairly light considering all the hardware on it. another big plus.comes with 3 side plates. one with 12 buttons, one with 2, and one with I think 6? very cool and convenient, and easy to swap out.no perceivable latency, however I originally bought this mouse used. it would lose connection for several seconds, which is unusable for gaming and just annoying in any other application, especially at this price.I returned it and bought a new one, which has the same issue but only loses connectivity very briefly, enough for me to just ignore. I dont play shooters or 1st person games with it so whatever.the razer software has automatic profile switching. you can set up specific keybinds for any program (even ones that arent games) and when you switch to a different program the keybinds automatically swap. this is insanely useful for video editing, music production, MMOs, all kinds of things.battery life is great. naturally, the lights suck a lot of it up but you should turn them off if you want it to last long.I like the ergonomics a lot, I think it feels great in my hand. it's meant to be held with your fingers laid on it and your palm mostly lifted off of it. it feels very comfortable but I'd like it slightly lighter for easier movement.if it werent for the disconnection this would be 5/5 stars. it has zero ccompetition, is feature packed and is good at what it does.

Sadly, I was very wrong. The G604 doesn't improve on the G602 in any way, and clearly took a major step back in terms of quality / quality control. review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2021
review.title: The mouse is fine, but the mandatory G HUB sofware is awful
review.review: So Logitech decided to discontinue their software for various devices and consolidate them into on grand app to rule them all: G HUB. Not a bad strategy, but the execution was terrible.The mouse itself is pretty good, but there is no point extolling its virtues, since you shouldn't buy it anyway. In fact, you should not buy any Logitech wireless produce until they've fixed G HUB. Or eradicated it, hired a new engineering team, and written something better to replace it. Or, you know, just reverted to the LGS app that their older mice used that worked just fine for years.There are many reviews detailing G HUB's failings, so I won't list all of them here. I'll add my latest experience to the pile:I got the mouse and installed G HUB several months ago on a system with Windows 8.1. Today, I used the in-app button to upgrade to the latest version. But it turns out the latest version is only compatible with Windows 10. So it tried to upgrade itself and hung forever instead, showing me the cutesy animation that Logitech's engineering department apparently spent their time on instead of doing QA. I didn't even get the courtesy of an error message.As a programmer myself, I can tell you that's an inexcusable, novice, facepalm-grade error. An auto-updater should *always* perform proper version and requirements checks.Anyway, I headed to Logitech's site to find an installer for the earlier Windows 8 compatible version. I knew it existed, since just an hour before it was up and running on my system. But no luck, they now offer Windows 10 or Mac only. So then off to reddit, where quickly I found the hidden link to the older Win7 and Win8 versions. Pay no mind to the "There are no Downloads for this Version" message! It's there, or at least it was today, though it may be gone by the time you need it.That installer then failed because it was confused by the current, corrupt installation. So I spent some time ripping that one out by the roots from multiple file system and registry locations. After pausing for a moment to say goodbye to the mouse settings/macros I spent time writing, now all gone, I was able to reinstall it.The whole affair reminded me of this bit from the HHGTTG:“But the plans were on display…”“On display? I eventually had to go down to the cellar to find them.”“That’s the display department.”“With a flashlight.”“Ah, well, the lights had probably gone.”“So had the stairs.”“But look, you found the notice, didn’t you?”“Yes,” said Arthur, “yes I did. It was on display in the bottom of a locked filing cabinet stuck in a disused lavatory with a sign on the door saying ‘Beware of the Leopard.”

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2021
review.title: Can't Recommend
review.review: This mouse has really been a disappointment.Battery life is nowhere near what I was expecting. I replace batteries in my M510 maybe every 8 month's. That mouse is used 8 hours a day for work. Since I got this in July I have had to replace the batteries three times already (almost monthly).Functionally, this mouse would be terrible for any type of FPS. Half the time the first click I make doesn't register and I have to click again. I haven't experienced the double clicks that others have reported, but they may only be a matter of time. The two main buttons overhang the front of the mouse, so if you bump it into anything while moving it, you end up with random clicks.And last but definitely not least, the G-Hub software is absolute garbage. The interface is terrible and difficult to use. Nothing is where you expect it be and you have to click thru different screens to do basic things like remap buttons. It is buggy as hell, locking up when trying to update, requiring uninstalling and reinstalling it to get it to work. Half the time the profiles you get put in and saved don't activate when they should. For G-Hub alone I would say to stay away from any Logitech product that uses it.
product.title: Logitech G604 LIGHTSPEED Wireless Gaming Mouse with 15 programmable controls, up to 240 hour battery life, dual wireless c...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2021
review.title: Excellent physical design, absolutely unusable due to GHub.
review.review: I had my previous Logitech gaming mouse for almost 10-years before it gave up on life. So I went for this G604.It feels great in my hand, cradles my thumb perfectly and the buttons are all accessible for my tiny lady hands. Excellent design!But... The Ghub software? Randomly drops profiles so none of the programmed buttons work. Just randomly. It makes the mouse totally unusable. I will be in the middle of a project I rely on macro'd buttons to do for work? Mouse decides to stop working. I will be gaming and try to hit a macro? Bam! Dead!Trying to find a way to load the profile onboard is obtuse. This mouse is harder to program than units with more buttons were 10-years ago.Thing is, I trusted Logitech enough to throw out the package so I cannot even return this failure of a device. Ghub will spend hours trying to update and fail to, which leads to uninstalling and reinstalling just to use the %^&%^ mouse to do basic ^&%&^ mouse things. I have never had this kind of issue with Logitech devices and I have been a loyal customer for decades.Looks like I will be dropping $300 to buy a new copy of the same Logitech gaming mouse I got 10-years ago, because I know that it will survive being used for 16-hours a day for close to 10-years and remain a viable, reliable option until USB technology is completely phased out of PCs.

review.title: Has Optical Switches
review.review: I'm not a gamer but I use a DAW a lot and there are many settings and adjustments to make on plug-ins, etc. It doesn't take long to wear out a mouse with contact switches. Regular contact switches bounce from day one and the bounce increases with wear until you get double-clicks and multiple clicks which cause errors and results other than what you want. I just wanted this mouse for the optical switch, which has no bounce. However, to get the driver, you have to install bloatwear and nagwear.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Left mouse button squeek, but I found a fix.
review.review: The media could not be loaded. It's going to take some time to get really 2nd nature fluid with it.I'm retiring my old Naga razor.If you play MMOs then these buttons are invaluable-so this mouse does the job once you get used to it.TlDR: squirt it with SILICONE lubricant spray.Like a lot of complaints on here, my left mouse button squeeked loudly. It's just brittle plastic scraping against itself.No big deal but loud and annoying. I was able to fix mine thou with a tiny (emphasis on tiny) squirt of silicone based lubricant ment for electronics.I used Blaster, as shown in photo.Just a very gentle squirt under it's "fingernail" so to speak.Then I tipped it upside to let any excess leak out and away from the pcb boards.Shouldn'tcause issue, but being careful.This is slick stiff, so it will feel like you let your nephew eat cheetos and use wipe greese everywhere.Just wipe exesive off with a paper towel, making sure not to let it seep deep down inside.Works immediately and working great now!Good luck, have fun!

I've never encountered a mouse mat surface this coarse. The cheap ones at my work have a smoother surface. My wife and I both agreed they were incredibly uncomfortable, even to REST your wrists on for typing, and had to return. I will say the product appeared to be HIGH quality. Very well made and looked like a well built product. I just take issue with that surface for gaming, it is absolutely inappropriate.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2021
review.title: Adds the Right RGB Flare
review.review: If you’re looking for an RGB gaming pad to work with all your other Razer pieces, this is the one.Note: as with almost all other Razer devices, Mac RGB functionality is quite limited (though there is a way to get around this with a slightly-hacked Razer app for Mac that can be found on GitHub). Works like a charm with PC though.Only complaint is that the grey one is pretty prone to spots, and it’s insanely difficult to clean and get spot-free. Even with water, it leaves odd splotches in places. In hindsight, I should’ve just went for the black one to avoid this headache altogether.TL;DR: it’s great, just as long as you buy the black one.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Good, but came broken.
review.review: I received this item and immediately plugged it in and set it up on my desk.It works, it does the basic function it is designed to do (big pad for your mouse and keyboard).I noticed a brighter light just to the left of the plastic piece that says Razer on the pad (see pictures).So I unplugged it and looked at that section.Well, it is broken/torn.Not sure what the deal is with this, I assumed Razer was higher quality, which is why I bought this item instead of other brands.I am glad I had points I was able to use to make this less expensive since it is obviously cheap.I figure I either received a returned item, this is just poor build quality, or poor handling/packaging that caused this to break (or a combination of all the above).Either way, I would not buy it again, and I do not recommend this to anyone.Quality assurance at this company is apparently not something they are concerned with.Additionally, the stitching that holds the LED tube to the mat is very annoying on my skin.not sure how this passed any sort of user testing.After my recent experience with a few of their other products and this item, I clearly will never buy Razer products again.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2021
review.title: A very fair mat solution, but wears quickly
review.review: So, I was turned off by all the reports of warping of the EL strips along its sides, but I took the leap and went for it. Happily, in the 9 months of ownership I've had, I can report no warping of the mat: It's as flat as it came on the first day. (...it came rolled up, but.. you know)I like the Extended model for desk coverage. It adds a nice touch to your workspace, and has proven to be easy enough to clean with a damp cloth. The experience has been overall very good.Where it lacks is durability of the cloth skin on the mat. The right hand side (see pic) shows noticeable wear after less than a year of use. This was a disappointment, because if not for that fact I would have given this a no-fault review. A less important nitpick: The single channel EL strip, vs a multi-channel zone strip like what the Firefly uses to produce the wave effect. A mat this large would show off greatly if the EL strip could handle it, IMO.Pictures show a.) the spot on the mat where it's taken notable wear and tear, discoloring and fraying the fabric skin of the mat; and b.) a snapshot of my Goliathus workspace: From left to right: The Razer Charging Pad Chroma, the Blackwidow Chroma v2; the Mouse Dock Chroma; and the Naga Pro. (I like pretty lights.)

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2021
review.title: I hope you have big hands.
review.review: This mouse is definitely *not* for people who have hands on the smaller side of average. I don't have tiny hands by any means, but this mouse is extremely awkward for me to use without accidentally hitting the first row of keys on the side. My hand simply doesn't wrap around enough of the bulk of this thing to get a good grip on only the non-button portions of the mouse. This leads to firing off skills or macros that I absolutely do not intend to use yet while just moving the mouse around; I've had to disable the first row of keys entirely to avoid this.Another problem the size presents is that it won't consistently hold down the LMB if I want to click and drag; it'll often let go prematurely because my fingertips apparently don't reach far enough forward to get the leverage it needs to keep the sensors in contact.Years ago, I had a Naga that had plates you could swap out to adjust the size appropriate to your needs, but they apparently don't make them anymore, and are going with a "one (large) size fits all" approach. This is a major shame, because it's excluding a fairly significant portion of the gaming population.If you have big ol' hands, then I bet this mouse would work great for you. It's lightweight (almost too lightweight) and pretty responsive.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2021
review.title: The only premium wireless mmo mouse. needs some competition
review.review: The only MMO mouse that is wireless, from a name brand company.Features: comes with PTFE mouse feet which is very generous and not common, usually you buy these aftermarket.fairly light considering all the hardware on it. another big plus.comes with 3 side plates. one with 12 buttons, one with 2, and one with I think 6? very cool and convenient, and easy to swap out.no perceivable latency, however I originally bought this mouse used. it would lose connection for several seconds, which is unusable for gaming and just annoying in any other application, especially at this price.I returned it and bought a new one, which has the same issue but only loses connectivity very briefly, enough for me to just ignore. I dont play shooters or 1st person games with it so whatever.the razer software has automatic profile switching. you can set up specific keybinds for any program (even ones that arent games) and when you switch to a different program the keybinds automatically swap. this is insanely useful for video editing, music production, MMOs, all kinds of things.battery life is great. naturally, the lights suck a lot of it up but you should turn them off if you want it to last long.I like the ergonomics a lot, I think it feels great in my hand. it's meant to be held with your fingers laid on it and your palm mostly lifted off of it. it feels very comfortable but I'd like it slightly lighter for easier movement.if it werent for the disconnection this would be 5/5 stars. it has zero ccompetition, is feature packed and is good at what it does.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review.title: Mid-Range Quality
review.review: Don't get me wrong, this is a good headset and works great, but it's not incredible. If you're looking for a good headset that'll get the job done and is comfortable, this is a good option. Mic quality is meh, but is so much better than an earbud set mic. I wear glasses with wide frames and it wasn't very comfortable at first, but I got used to it after a couple weeks. Audio playback quality is pretty good and they don't let much outside sound in which is a plus. Good headset, gave it four stars because there are better options for a higher price, but it's still completely worth it.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review.title: Good, but...
review.review: This is a fantastic headset for gaming, or just listening to music. However the range is terrible. If I have to leave the room for anything, I start having issues about 20 feet away. I have other wireless headsets that still function while I'm downstairs getting stuff out of my vehicle in the driveway. I mostly use this for gaming so it's not that big of a deal to me, but for the price, you should get more range than that, especially since it comes with its own plug in transmitter.

review.review: Worked very well out of the box for 2-3 months. All of a sudden it stopped working via bluetooth or the dongle. I have tried multiple batteries. Have tried updating drivers both via Windows and Razer's firmware updater. Have installed Razer's ridiculous software which requires you to create an account just to open the software. NOTHING WILL FIX IT. I looked around different boards and it seems many people have had this issue and there is no solution.I feel like I bought a piece of trash that is now useless. Would not recommend buying. I have always had Logitech mice and am going back to them. The close to 20 years i have been using Logitech mice I have not had to fool with them trying to make the combined mice work like i have with this single Razer mouse.

review.review: Im honestly surprised. Ive had issues with razer in the past, and have been slowly gravitating away from their products. I really like the g502, but the scroll wheel thing is dumb and kind of useless. I use that button for remapping, and its kind of important for my muscle memory.The battery life is great, i havent had it die once and i have rgb on, using it for about a week. RND is great on it, good quality, smooth clicks on both main actuators. It fits really nicely in my hand (mostly claw grip, but i rest my palm on the back, medium hands). The pads on the bottom are literal butter. It glides with 0 friction, even on my admittedly worn mouse mat.Honestly a great mouse.

review.review: I have a smaller mouse mat that I used to use and I kept falling off of it with my mouse, so I got this beast, the largest one they offer and it definitely does not disappoint. The quality is really good, it came rolled up, I unrolled it out onto my desk and it works perfectly. Just having this cover nearly my hold desk is great. My palms used to get sore from allowing them to rest ontop of my desk while doing things. No longer an issue. I love the lighting this puts off, I've just left it on its default, I find the subtle light makes for a fantastic night light. (It's in my bedroom) buy one, it's worth it. Can see this lasting me a very long time. Keep it clean and it'll last for many years.

review.title: Click away
review.review: Perhaps one of nicest mouse clicking sounds and feeling I have ever heard with hardly any delay between clicks.However a major nitpick I have is when you use the mouse for the first time on a pc it opens up a download prompt for the software which is convenient but distracting when using it on a different pc for the first time (haven't tested it just hypothetically speaking)To use certain features i.e macros you need the software to be installed AND be in the background but overall mouse control you dont need the software.After you figure our your button bindings delete the software then have your pc forget the mouse then reconnect the mouse and close out the download prompt (after you do it once it won't reappear unless you make your pc forget it) This solved the issue I had with it skipping abruptly both in-game and browsing.After these changes its a very solid mouse and felt right at home using it without needing to make any adjustments.Only nitpick I have is that you can't get custom shells individually in the official website or other websites.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review.title: Manufacturing Flaw
review.review: So when I first opened it, it was all sorts of warped. I figured just like any other mousepad either lay books on it to keep it flat or leave it out in the sun so the heat can loosen it up and flatten it. Tried both and neither worked. Googled the issue and came across a YouTube video that explained that it could be the clear tube lining around the edges that is the issue. Basically what I ended up having to do was unscrew the led base and pull out the tube form the lights, I pulled it more snug and tight and fiddled with it for an hour to get it just right. A friend of mine bought one and had no issues so I’m sure it was just a fluke but my god was it a pain in the ass..it’s still not perfect but it’ll do

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2021
review.title: Like a slightly more control QCK pad
review.review: At the moment, this is my favorite mousepad. And I have a closet full of pads including Corsair pads, other Razer pads, Artisan Zero and hien, x-ray pads, odin infinity pads, e-sports tiger, etc... At the moment this pad has the smooth surface I'm looking for, with just a little more control than a QCK which is closer to a speed pad, and for me feels like a really good balance. And you can't really complain about the price. $15 for the large is more than fair. The only thing that this is missing is stitched edges. I think that if this had the stitched edges that the strider has, it would be a perfect entry. As it is, it's still excellent though and I recommend it if you're looking for something similar to a QCK with a tad more control.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2021
review.title: Adds the Right RGB Flare
review.review: If you’re looking for an RGB gaming pad to work with all your other Razer pieces, this is the one.Note: as with almost all other Razer devices, Mac RGB functionality is quite limited (though there is a way to get around this with a slightly-hacked Razer app for Mac that can be found on GitHub). Works like a charm with PC though.Only complaint is that the grey one is pretty prone to spots, and it’s insanely difficult to clean and get spot-free. Even with water, it leaves odd splotches in places. In hindsight, I should’ve just went for the black one to avoid this headache altogether.TL;DR: it’s great, just as long as you buy the black one.
product.title: Razer Goliathus Chroma Soft Gaming Mouse Mat Powered by Razer Chroma Black

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Good, but came broken.
review.review: I received this item and immediately plugged it in and set it up on my desk.It works, it does the basic function it is designed to do (big pad for your mouse and keyboard).I noticed a brighter light just to the left of the plastic piece that says Razer on the pad (see pictures).So I unplugged it and looked at that section.Well, it is broken/torn.Not sure what the deal is with this, I assumed Razer was higher quality, which is why I bought this item instead of other brands.I am glad I had points I was able to use to make this less expensive since it is obviously cheap.I figure I either received a returned item, this is just poor build quality, or poor handling/packaging that caused this to break (or a combination of all the above).Either way, I would not buy it again, and I do not recommend this to anyone.Quality assurance at this company is apparently not something they are concerned with.Additionally, the stitching that holds the LED tube to the mat is very annoying on my skin.not sure how this passed any sort of user testing.After my recent experience with a few of their other products and this item, I clearly will never buy Razer products again.
product.title: Razer Goliathus Chroma Soft Gaming Mouse Mat Powered by Razer Chroma Black

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2021
review.title: Solid Product, great design.
review.review: Love this mousepad. I have several of these. I just started a new job and decided to take the Mercury (silvery white) mat to my office and got this black one for home. The Mercury one obviously shows more dirt due to the lighter color. The mats are not the easiest to clean because you have to be gentle to not disturb the fabric too much. You have to clean with the grain of the fabric and use a very mild detergent or just slightly warm water.
product.title: Razer Goliathus Chroma Soft Gaming Mouse Mat Powered by Razer Chroma Black

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2021
review.title: A very fair mat solution, but wears quickly
review.review: So, I was turned off by all the reports of warping of the EL strips along its sides, but I took the leap and went for it. Happily, in the 9 months of ownership I've had, I can report no warping of the mat: It's as flat as it came on the first day. (...it came rolled up, but.. you know)I like the Extended model for desk coverage. It adds a nice touch to your workspace, and has proven to be easy enough to clean with a damp cloth. The experience has been overall very good.Where it lacks is durability of the cloth skin on the mat. The right hand side (see pic) shows noticeable wear after less than a year of use. This was a disappointment, because if not for that fact I would have given this a no-fault review. A less important nitpick: The single channel EL strip, vs a multi-channel zone strip like what the Firefly uses to produce the wave effect. A mat this large would show off greatly if the EL strip could handle it, IMO.Pictures show a.) the spot on the mat where it's taken notable wear and tear, discoloring and fraying the fabric skin of the mat; and b.) a snapshot of my Goliathus workspace: From left to right: The Razer Charging Pad Chroma, the Blackwidow Chroma v2; the Mouse Dock Chroma; and the Naga Pro. (I like pretty lights.)

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2021
review.title: Low profile high performance mouse surface
review.review: I bought this to replace an 8-year-old Razer Sphex skin, which was almost identical other than the size and design. The Sphex was being used on the tiny computer desk in our family room. I like having a low profile mouse pad on that desk which doesn't stick out. The Sphex did well considering how much use it got, and how my daughter liked to lift up the edges and crease them with her nails during online class until tiny pieces eventually tore up bit by bit.I like the design of these pads. The Sphex was accurately called a desktop skin, which is what it is. This new one's called 'thin mouse pad', which can be misleading. It's basically a piece of plastic that's smooth and tacky on one side (to stay in place), and textured on the other side to give good mouse performance. This new version has a cloth 'tag' that you can use to pull it up and reposition it. These are very easy to reposition, but only as long as you keep the tacky side off the table as little as possible so it doesn't collect dust, and make sure any surface you move it to is cleaned thoroughly. You also have to be careful not to crease it, since any crease on this material is permanent and will always show. For all these reasons, this is NOT appropriate as a travel mouse pad.I was initially worried that the design on this would be too bright, but the actual mousepad has more muted colors than in the pictures. Overall I highly recommend it.
product.title: Razer Sphex V2 - Mini - Ultra-Thin Form Factor - Durable polycarbonate finish

review.review: The mouse pad is not 455mm x 455mm, up against my 450mm long mouse pad this is actually shorter at roughly 445mm x 445mm in size from stitched edge to stitched edge which reduces the usable space even more because the stitching is a couple mm thick, you are really using about 440mm x 440mm worth of mouse pad.The logo is raised rubber so if you were to put your mouse over the top of the logo it would stop moving and stick, which makes an entire corner of the mouse pad unusable. I recommend turning the logo into a corner that your mouse will never travel into. When I pulled the mouse pad out of the box it came out with dust and dirt all over it. review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2021
review.title: Its good, depends on your sen.
review.review: I used to use the HyperX FuryS, both are good for different reasons. I would say if you need large amounts of room for flicking I would go for the hyperX mat, but if you have a higher sen I would recommend this one as it has a few advantages. It's thinner so when you move your arm It's not as noticeable, and because its smaller, it is easier to clean in the tub or sink, and the edge of the mat feels less intrusive as well.But comparing both surfaces of each mat, the hyperx feels slightly more stretchy but softer to the touch, and the G-SR feels a bit more rough. This in practice doesn't seem to affect my aim or comfort at all over time.You should also consider value as the G-SR is also more expensive than the hyperx even though it is more expensive.The only con so far with the G-SR is that when I play Osu or FPS games that require fast arm motions, it slips on the table about 2-3 inches from time to time.

review.review: Everything is perfect for my needs. Not an obviously flashy RGB trashy mousepad, but sleek and clean appearing. Price is phenomenal 10 bucks, feels like it should be worth double. The size is perfect, not a small square but has width to it to glide around, and it's not an obnoxiously big rag. I love the color, have had black mousepads my entire life that have faded and picked up the white dust. Haven't had long but seems clean and hard to see ugly dust speckles. I would avoid eating over mousepad however. Just a 10/10 Mousepad and it's a refreshing update on the plain square black or RGB mousepads coming out these days.

review.review_data: Reviewed in Italy on October 14, 2021
review.title: Razer Sphex V2: antiscivolo e super veloce!
review.review: Your browser does not support HTML5 video. ✔️ È antiscivolo!Inizio da qui perché ero titubante sull'acquisto leggendo le altre recensioni. Il tappetino arriva con una pellicola super sottile e super trasparente applicata sul retro. Sembra che non ci sia! Per notarla e rimuoverla correttamente, bisogna guardare attentamente nel punto che ho indicato nella foto: vicino la linguetta Razer. Se non rimuoverete la pellicola che protegge lo strato antiscivolo, ovviamente il tappetino non sarà antiscivolo.Una volta rimossa, basterà pulire bene la superficie della scrivania, posare il tappetino e questo non si schioderà più (come si può vedere in video, dove scuoto la scrivania ma il tappetino non cede di 1mm!). Naturalmente è possibile sollevarlo intenzionalmente, sempre attraverso la linguetta Razer (non è adesivo!).✔️ Super veloce!A me piacciono i micro movimenti. Sono abituato da tanti anni a usare la massima sensibilità sui mouse proprio per muovere il meno possibile il polso. Per lo stesso motivo sono abituatissimo ai mini tappetini. La texture di questo tappetino è straordinaria. Sembra di poter far scorrere il mouse semplicemente soffiando.❗ Occhio ai piedini!La scorrevolezza dei tappetini duri si paga con un consumo più rapido dei piedini del mouse.Se giocate a sparatutto e, in generale, a titoli che richiedono precisione, vi serve attrito e quindi un tappetino morbido. Personalmente alterno i rigidi ai morbidi, a seconda delle necessità.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on October 5, 2021
review.title: Does what it says on the tin
review.review: I haven't used a mouse mat for 20 years but now working from home on a pine desk from a well-known Swedish furniture shifter, I found the optical mouse did not track well across the horizontal grain.Up and down was OK, but left and right was pretty jagged and inconsistent.It might not be a big deal if you are a casual user on social media but if you are working in infrastructure and dragging a lot of files from A to B, one false move could be disastrous.This mat is fairly-priced and works a charm.Super-thin and in no way reminiscent of the old foamy ones you used to get at work that were best used for underlay.Cannot quote on it's durability after just a couple of days, nor its suitability for gaming (it's a work laptop) but very happy with this so far.

review.title: Gillette ProGlide Raxor Blades
review.review: There are 3 stellar aspects to this review. First of all the ProGlide blades are by far the sharpest, smoothest shaving blades I have ever experienced and I have been shaving for decades. Secondly, you cannot find 12 packages in regular stores, which leads to the third point which is Amazon's price is much more economical.You could pay in a typical drug store 22-23 dollars just for 4 blades while it was just 40.00 dollars for 12 in the Amazon retail section.All in all I give them my highest recommendation.

review.title: Do not buy!!! Not original Gillette ProGlide Razor!
review.review: I purchased this 8 pack of Gillette ProGlide Razor blade back in June. I just started using one of these new packs and noticed immediately that this razor is not even close to being as sharp as the one I purchased at the local store. I thought, ok maybe it's one bad razor so I opened another pack and found out to be the same as the first one. I've been using Gillette ProGlide for years now and I don't mind paying extra for the best quality. I specifically love the yellow razor blades but unfortunately, I was not able to find them in the local store at the time and now I regret purchasing it online.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2021
review.title: Low profile high performance mouse surface
review.review: I bought this to replace an 8-year-old Razer Sphex skin, which was almost identical other than the size and design. The Sphex was being used on the tiny computer desk in our family room. I like having a low profile mouse pad on that desk which doesn't stick out. The Sphex did well considering how much use it got, and how my daughter liked to lift up the edges and crease them with her nails during online class until tiny pieces eventually tore up bit by bit.I like the design of these pads. The Sphex was accurately called a desktop skin, which is what it is. This new one's called 'thin mouse pad', which can be misleading. It's basically a piece of plastic that's smooth and tacky on one side (to stay in place), and textured on the other side to give good mouse performance. This new version has a cloth 'tag' that you can use to pull it up and reposition it. These are very easy to reposition, but only as long as you keep the tacky side off the table as little as possible so it doesn't collect dust, and make sure any surface you move it to is cleaned thoroughly. You also have to be careful not to crease it, since any crease on this material is permanent and will always show. For all these reasons, this is NOT appropriate as a travel mouse pad.I was initially worried that the design on this would be too bright, but the actual mousepad has more muted colors than in the pictures. Overall I highly recommend it.
product.title: Razer Sphex V2 - Mini - Ultra-Thin Form Factor - Durable polycarbonate finish

review.review_data: Reviewed in Italy on October 14, 2021
review.title: Razer Sphex V2: antiscivolo e super veloce!
review.review: Your browser does not support HTML5 video. ✔️ È antiscivolo!Inizio da qui perché ero titubante sull'acquisto leggendo le altre recensioni. Il tappetino arriva con una pellicola super sottile e super trasparente applicata sul retro. Sembra che non ci sia! Per notarla e rimuoverla correttamente, bisogna guardare attentamente nel punto che ho indicato nella foto: vicino la linguetta Razer. Se non rimuoverete la pellicola che protegge lo strato antiscivolo, ovviamente il tappetino non sarà antiscivolo.Una volta rimossa, basterà pulire bene la superficie della scrivania, posare il tappetino e questo non si schioderà più (come si può vedere in video, dove scuoto la scrivania ma il tappetino non cede di 1mm!). Naturalmente è possibile sollevarlo intenzionalmente, sempre attraverso la linguetta Razer (non è adesivo!).✔️ Super veloce!A me piacciono i micro movimenti. Sono abituato da tanti anni a usare la massima sensibilità sui mouse proprio per muovere il meno possibile il polso. Per lo stesso motivo sono abituatissimo ai mini tappetini. La texture di questo tappetino è straordinaria. Sembra di poter far scorrere il mouse semplicemente soffiando.❗ Occhio ai piedini!La scorrevolezza dei tappetini duri si paga con un consumo più rapido dei piedini del mouse.Se giocate a sparatutto e, in generale, a titoli che richiedono precisione, vi serve attrito e quindi un tappetino morbido. Personalmente alterno i rigidi ai morbidi, a seconda delle necessità.

review.review: I haven't used a mouse mat for 20 years but now working from home on a pine desk from a well-known Swedish furniture shifter, I found the optical mouse did not track well across the horizontal grain.Up and down was OK, but left and right was pretty jagged and inconsistent.It might not be a big deal if you are a casual user on social media but if you are working in infrastructure and dragging a lot of files from A to B, one false move could be disastrous.This mat is fairly-priced and works a charm.Super-thin and in no way reminiscent of the old foamy ones you used to get at work that were best used for underlay.Cannot quote on it's durability after just a couple of days, nor its suitability for gaming (it's a work laptop) but very happy with this so far.

review.title: Not really as great as I thought it would be.
review.review: The mouse itself is a very comfortable mouse to hold. It looks great with it's RGB color changing lights and it has some nice accessories that come with it. Unfortunately it's not as great as it seems. Got this mouse about two months back and it's left mouse button is already wearing down. Whenever I try to hold something in a game (Let's say People Playground for example) it's unable to hold it. When I try to browse the web, I'd click something once and it would register a double click instead, making it annoying on websites like Twitter. I have used this mouse about every day, but I never raged on it, nor have I been rough on it. For a 100$ mouse, it's rather disappointing to see.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2021
review.title: Cool RGB mouse, don't care about other features though
review.review: First of all the RGB on this mouse is slick.I has the DeathAdder Chroma (which was old, and the RGB didn't work with Synapse 3), but I loved the feel of it.This mouse had that similar feel, I actually may like this mouse's feel more than the DeathAdder and I'm happy with my decision for this mouse over the DeathAdder 2.I normally stick with what is familiar, and glad I broke out of my comfort zone.It glides easily across my desk and the DPI adjustable thing which I rarely ever use is still nice to have in case I ever need it.I do like you can reprogram the buttons (and those thumb buttons I have surprisingly found good uses for).One thing I'll say is the right mouse button sometimes gets accidentally pressed.Could be my long Diablo 3 constant clicking that my hand just hits the mouse button on accident frequently, but resting my hand on the mouse I don't feel it should be that easy that accidentally clicking occurs.So would have been 5 star, but subtracted half a star for those weird accidental mouse clicks.Subtracted another half only because it's not wireless for this price!

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2021
review.title: Left-Click Stopped Working After A Few Months
review.review: I purchased this mouse for light gaming and typical web browsing. Within 6 months, I noticed the left-click was not holding down correctly. Physically it felt fine, but it was basically unplayable in games. I tried every solution and the problem only got worse over time so I figured it was a hardware problem rather than a software issue. I took great care of the mouse and used it VERY lightly yet it still gave out quickly. Not to mention the Razer Synapse program is terrible. Unfortunately for me, the company that sold me the product through Amazon, "TECHLOBBY", is not an authorized seller of Razer products so the 2 year manufacturers warranty did NOT cover this issue. On Razer's website, Amazon is an authorized seller of Razer products but many of the companies that sell through Amazon are not so it is very misleading. This mouse is no longer manufactured by Razer so don't even bother buying it. For $50, this mouse became useless after a few months of light use, DO NOT RECOMEND.
product.title: Razer Mamba Wireless Gaming Mouse: 16,000 DPI Optical Sensor - Chroma RGB Lighting - 7 Programmable Buttons - Mechanical S...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2021
review.title: Adds the Right RGB Flare
review.review: If you’re looking for an RGB gaming pad to work with all your other Razer pieces, this is the one.Note: as with almost all other Razer devices, Mac RGB functionality is quite limited (though there is a way to get around this with a slightly-hacked Razer app for Mac that can be found on GitHub). Works like a charm with PC though.Only complaint is that the grey one is pretty prone to spots, and it’s insanely difficult to clean and get spot-free. Even with water, it leaves odd splotches in places. In hindsight, I should’ve just went for the black one to avoid this headache altogether.TL;DR: it’s great, just as long as you buy the black one.
product.title: Razer Goliathus Chroma Soft Gaming Mouse Mat Powered by Razer Chroma Black

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Good, but came broken.
review.review: I received this item and immediately plugged it in and set it up on my desk.It works, it does the basic function it is designed to do (big pad for your mouse and keyboard).I noticed a brighter light just to the left of the plastic piece that says Razer on the pad (see pictures).So I unplugged it and looked at that section.Well, it is broken/torn.Not sure what the deal is with this, I assumed Razer was higher quality, which is why I bought this item instead of other brands.I am glad I had points I was able to use to make this less expensive since it is obviously cheap.I figure I either received a returned item, this is just poor build quality, or poor handling/packaging that caused this to break (or a combination of all the above).Either way, I would not buy it again, and I do not recommend this to anyone.Quality assurance at this company is apparently not something they are concerned with.Additionally, the stitching that holds the LED tube to the mat is very annoying on my skin.not sure how this passed any sort of user testing.After my recent experience with a few of their other products and this item, I clearly will never buy Razer products again.
product.title: Razer Goliathus Chroma Soft Gaming Mouse Mat Powered by Razer Chroma Black

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2021
review.title: A very fair mat solution, but wears quickly
review.review: So, I was turned off by all the reports of warping of the EL strips along its sides, but I took the leap and went for it. Happily, in the 9 months of ownership I've had, I can report no warping of the mat: It's as flat as it came on the first day. (...it came rolled up, but.. you know)I like the Extended model for desk coverage. It adds a nice touch to your workspace, and has proven to be easy enough to clean with a damp cloth. The experience has been overall very good.Where it lacks is durability of the cloth skin on the mat. The right hand side (see pic) shows noticeable wear after less than a year of use. This was a disappointment, because if not for that fact I would have given this a no-fault review. A less important nitpick: The single channel EL strip, vs a multi-channel zone strip like what the Firefly uses to produce the wave effect. A mat this large would show off greatly if the EL strip could handle it, IMO.Pictures show a.) the spot on the mat where it's taken notable wear and tear, discoloring and fraying the fabric skin of the mat; and b.) a snapshot of my Goliathus workspace: From left to right: The Razer Charging Pad Chroma, the Blackwidow Chroma v2; the Mouse Dock Chroma; and the Naga Pro. (I like pretty lights.)
product.title: Razer Goliathus Chroma Soft Gaming Mouse Mat Powered by Razer Chroma Black

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: TERRIBLE. Scroll Wheel WILL Start to Squeak and Fail After 3 Months.
review.review: For the first few months, it was good. Everything worked as it should. The cord was not a problem and extended long enough to reach my tower. I enjoyed having two buttons on the side for gaming purposes. The mouse fits nicely in your hand. The scroll wheel and the design light up a pretty white hue. Aesthetically pleasing and matches my white set-up.BUT. After 3 months, just this past September, the scroll wheel started to make this OBNOXIOUS screeching sound every time I scrolled. I didn't realize how much I scroll until this started to happen. It was ear aching and I looked up how to fix it, saw that MANY others with this mouse had a similar problem, and the fix requires you to dissemble the whole thing to oil it. I am not savvy with that so I left it alone in hopes that it would just go away with time.Well the squeaking has reduced but now everytime I attempt to scroll, it causes my window to jitter and scroll back the OPPOSITE way. So here I am battling with my mouse to scroll smoothly for just a couple inches. It's the most frustrating thing I've experienced with a mouse and I've finally given up and am purchasing a different one. I never had a mouse that couldn't even last a single year... this is a poor product in my opinion.
