review.title: Don't Get Too Excited....
review.review: If you think you're gonna be crushin' with this mouse, think again. The ergonomics of this mouse has you holding it downward to hold on to it. The thumb/side buttons are SOOOOO close, you'll eventually hit both when your intentions are to only hit one, thusly accidently using that feature if you've mapped anything to them. It's very, very lightweight which didn't instill confidence in playing a character for which you had to keep moving. Yes, I am spoiled by my OLD Logitech G302 and after using this Razer DeatchAdder Essenetial for the past 2 weeks, it's going back.*IF* you're starting out and looking for a DECENT Gaming Mouse, then this might be for you, considering the price, but I've lost far too many battles because of the side/thumb buttons being too close together.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2021
review.title: Like a slightly more control QCK pad
review.review: At the moment, this is my favorite mousepad. And I have a closet full of pads including Corsair pads, other Razer pads, Artisan Zero and hien, x-ray pads, odin infinity pads, e-sports tiger, etc... At the moment this pad has the smooth surface I'm looking for, with just a little more control than a QCK which is closer to a speed pad, and for me feels like a really good balance. And you can't really complain about the price. $15 for the large is more than fair. The only thing that this is missing is stitched edges. I think that if this had the stitched edges that the strider has, it would be a perfect entry. As it is, it's still excellent though and I recommend it if you're looking for something similar to a QCK with a tad more control.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2021
review.title: Low profile high performance mouse surface
review.review: I bought this to replace an 8-year-old Razer Sphex skin, which was almost identical other than the size and design. The Sphex was being used on the tiny computer desk in our family room. I like having a low profile mouse pad on that desk which doesn't stick out. The Sphex did well considering how much use it got, and how my daughter liked to lift up the edges and crease them with her nails during online class until tiny pieces eventually tore up bit by bit.I like the design of these pads. The Sphex was accurately called a desktop skin, which is what it is. This new one's called 'thin mouse pad', which can be misleading. It's basically a piece of plastic that's smooth and tacky on one side (to stay in place), and textured on the other side to give good mouse performance. This new version has a cloth 'tag' that you can use to pull it up and reposition it. These are very easy to reposition, but only as long as you keep the tacky side off the table as little as possible so it doesn't collect dust, and make sure any surface you move it to is cleaned thoroughly. You also have to be careful not to crease it, since any crease on this material is permanent and will always show. For all these reasons, this is NOT appropriate as a travel mouse pad.I was initially worried that the design on this would be too bright, but the actual mousepad has more muted colors than in the pictures. Overall I highly recommend it.
product.title: Razer Sphex V2 Gaming Mouse Pad: Ultra-Thin Form Factor - Optimized Gaming Surface - Polycarbonate Finish

review.review_data: Reviewed in Italy on October 14, 2021
review.title: Razer Sphex V2: antiscivolo e super veloce!
review.review: Your browser does not support HTML5 video. ✔️ È antiscivolo!Inizio da qui perché ero titubante sull'acquisto leggendo le altre recensioni. Il tappetino arriva con una pellicola super sottile e super trasparente applicata sul retro. Sembra che non ci sia! Per notarla e rimuoverla correttamente, bisogna guardare attentamente nel punto che ho indicato nella foto: vicino la linguetta Razer. Se non rimuoverete la pellicola che protegge lo strato antiscivolo, ovviamente il tappetino non sarà antiscivolo.Una volta rimossa, basterà pulire bene la superficie della scrivania, posare il tappetino e questo non si schioderà più (come si può vedere in video, dove scuoto la scrivania ma il tappetino non cede di 1mm!). Naturalmente è possibile sollevarlo intenzionalmente, sempre attraverso la linguetta Razer (non è adesivo!).✔️ Super veloce!A me piacciono i micro movimenti. Sono abituato da tanti anni a usare la massima sensibilità sui mouse proprio per muovere il meno possibile il polso. Per lo stesso motivo sono abituatissimo ai mini tappetini. La texture di questo tappetino è straordinaria. Sembra di poter far scorrere il mouse semplicemente soffiando.❗ Occhio ai piedini!La scorrevolezza dei tappetini duri si paga con un consumo più rapido dei piedini del mouse.Se giocate a sparatutto e, in generale, a titoli che richiedono precisione, vi serve attrito e quindi un tappetino morbido. Personalmente alterno i rigidi ai morbidi, a seconda delle necessità.
product.title: Razer Sphex V2 Mini - Gaming Mouse Mat - Frml Packaging

review.title: One of the Best Mousepads
review.review: Everything is perfect for my needs. Not an obviously flashy RGB trashy mousepad, but sleek and clean appearing. Price is phenomenal 10 bucks, feels like it should be worth double. The size is perfect, not a small square but has width to it to glide around, and it's not an obnoxiously big rag. I love the color, have had black mousepads my entire life that have faded and picked up the white dust. Haven't had long but seems clean and hard to see ugly dust speckles. I would avoid eating over mousepad however. Just a 10/10 Mousepad and it's a refreshing update on the plain square black or RGB mousepads coming out these days.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2021
review.title: Like a slightly more control QCK pad
review.review: At the moment, this is my favorite mousepad. And I have a closet full of pads including Corsair pads, other Razer pads, Artisan Zero and hien, x-ray pads, odin infinity pads, e-sports tiger, etc... At the moment this pad has the smooth surface I'm looking for, with just a little more control than a QCK which is closer to a speed pad, and for me feels like a really good balance. And you can't really complain about the price. $15 for the large is more than fair. The only thing that this is missing is stitched edges. I think that if this had the stitched edges that the strider has, it would be a perfect entry. As it is, it's still excellent though and I recommend it if you're looking for something similar to a QCK with a tad more control.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2021
review.title: Adds the Right RGB Flare
review.review: If you’re looking for an RGB gaming pad to work with all your other Razer pieces, this is the one.Note: as with almost all other Razer devices, Mac RGB functionality is quite limited (though there is a way to get around this with a slightly-hacked Razer app for Mac that can be found on GitHub). Works like a charm with PC though.Only complaint is that the grey one is pretty prone to spots, and it’s insanely difficult to clean and get spot-free. Even with water, it leaves odd splotches in places. In hindsight, I should’ve just went for the black one to avoid this headache altogether.TL;DR: it’s great, just as long as you buy the black one.
product.title: Razer Goliathus Extended Chroma Gaming Mouse Mat - Balanced Control - Black

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Good, but came broken.
review.review: I received this item and immediately plugged it in and set it up on my desk.It works, it does the basic function it is designed to do (big pad for your mouse and keyboard).I noticed a brighter light just to the left of the plastic piece that says Razer on the pad (see pictures).So I unplugged it and looked at that section.Well, it is broken/torn.Not sure what the deal is with this, I assumed Razer was higher quality, which is why I bought this item instead of other brands.I am glad I had points I was able to use to make this less expensive since it is obviously cheap.I figure I either received a returned item, this is just poor build quality, or poor handling/packaging that caused this to break (or a combination of all the above).Either way, I would not buy it again, and I do not recommend this to anyone.Quality assurance at this company is apparently not something they are concerned with.Additionally, the stitching that holds the LED tube to the mat is very annoying on my skin.not sure how this passed any sort of user testing.After my recent experience with a few of their other products and this item, I clearly will never buy Razer products again.
product.title: Razer Goliathus Extended Chroma Gaming Mouse Mat - Balanced Control - Black

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2021
review.title: A very fair mat solution, but wears quickly
review.review: So, I was turned off by all the reports of warping of the EL strips along its sides, but I took the leap and went for it. Happily, in the 9 months of ownership I've had, I can report no warping of the mat: It's as flat as it came on the first day. (...it came rolled up, but.. you know)I like the Extended model for desk coverage. It adds a nice touch to your workspace, and has proven to be easy enough to clean with a damp cloth. The experience has been overall very good.Where it lacks is durability of the cloth skin on the mat. The right hand side (see pic) shows noticeable wear after less than a year of use. This was a disappointment, because if not for that fact I would have given this a no-fault review. A less important nitpick: The single channel EL strip, vs a multi-channel zone strip like what the Firefly uses to produce the wave effect. A mat this large would show off greatly if the EL strip could handle it, IMO.Pictures show a.) the spot on the mat where it's taken notable wear and tear, discoloring and fraying the fabric skin of the mat; and b.) a snapshot of my Goliathus workspace: From left to right: The Razer Charging Pad Chroma, the Blackwidow Chroma v2; the Mouse Dock Chroma; and the Naga Pro. (I like pretty lights.)
product.title: Razer Goliathus Extended Chroma Gaming Mouse Mat - Balanced Control - Black

review.title: Medicore Gaming Mouse Pad
review.review: The mouse pad is not 455mm x 455mm, up against my 450mm long mouse pad this is actually shorter at roughly 445mm x 445mm in size from stitched edge to stitched edge which reduces the usable space even more because the stitching is a couple mm thick, you are really using about 440mm x 440mm worth of mouse pad.The logo is raised rubber so if you were to put your mouse over the top of the logo it would stop moving and stick, which makes an entire corner of the mouse pad unusable. I recommend turning the logo into a corner that your mouse will never travel into. When I pulled the mouse pad out of the box it came out with dust and dirt all over it. Luckily I had a link roller handy and had to clean up the mouse pad surface. This is my second Razar mouse pad and both came out of the box dirty and needed a link roller across them to clean them up prior to use.

review.review_data: Reviewed in Germany on February 3, 2021
review.title: Razer bekommt die Abnutzung nicht in den Griff
review.review: Inzwischen ist das bereits meine vierte Razer-Maus und alle, wirklich alle hatten nach einiger Zeit in Benutzung Maustasten die Prellen. Aber diese Abysseus Version ist irgendwie der Gipfel. Ich habe die Maus am 10.11.2020 gekauft und jetzt stand heute hat sie bereits eine prellende Maustaste, das ist schon irgendwie witzlos wenn eine Maus gerade mal nach knapp drei Monaten Defekte aufweist.Leider kann ich aber keine andere Gaming-Maus für mich benutzen. Da ich eine körperliche Behinderung habe kann ich nicht einfach jede Maus bedienen wie ich gerne möchte. Die Abysseus Mäuse haben aber für mich genau die richtige Form, Gewicht und Größe die ich brauche, ich bin also fast gezwungen jedesmal die gleiche bzw. ähnliche Version von Razer zu kaufen.So oder so ist das ziemlich enttäuschend. Ich kann verstehen wenn heutige Mäuse nicht mehr allzu lange defektfrei laufen. Ich habe sogar das ständige Prellen der Razer-Mäuse irgendwie akzeptiert, aber nach dreimonatiger Benutzung ist das ein Witz. Sorry aber anders kann ich es nicht ausdrücken.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2020
review.title: Great mouse pad with caveats
review.review: This is an excellent hard mouse pad. I love the changeable surface texture, and I love the nice hefty base. It even comes with a case, which is hilarious. There are a few of caveats to this mouse pad:1) The big aluminum backing plate interferes with wireless. I moved my wireless receiver to the USB port on the side of my monitor so it's basically line of sight, but before that I had it in the back of my tower (where it worked with a simple plastic mouse pad) and experienced very inconsistent behavior.2) Hard plastic grabs mouse skate material - you will need to replace your skates from time to time. This also means cleaning your mouse pad regularly.3) I cannot find an OEM replacement for the plastic, and I'm already wearing smooth spots on it. I'm sure I can source a 3rd party sheet of plastic and cut a bunch out on the water jet at work, but that's not practical for most users. For a mouse pad this expensive the removable friction surface should have an OEM replacement available.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review.title: Manufacturing Flaw
review.review: So when I first opened it, it was all sorts of warped. I figured just like any other mousepad either lay books on it to keep it flat or leave it out in the sun so the heat can loosen it up and flatten it. Tried both and neither worked. Googled the issue and came across a YouTube video that explained that it could be the clear tube lining around the edges that is the issue. Basically what I ended up having to do was unscrew the led base and pull out the tube form the lights, I pulled it more snug and tight and fiddled with it for an hour to get it just right. A friend of mine bought one and had no issues so I’m sure it was just a fluke but my god was it a pain in the ass..it’s still not perfect but it’ll do

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2021
review.title: Better get one now. Here's why.
review.review: High-quality aluminum mats are the slickest, they glide like no other pad/mat every made. The only two (high-quality) aluminum mats ever made were this one and the Steelseries SX. BOTH are long out of production. You won't find a NIB Steelseries SX anywhere on Earth; personally I liked it more than the Manticor … but again, they are techno-history now.So here you are. This is the last of the new old stock for these Manticors. So grab one while you still can.Ok, it (and the SX) at $50, that's pretty pricey. Especially when you see $15 no-name aluminum mats all over Amazon. But if you read the reviews for all those no-names, you will see a lot of complaints – they don't last long, the finish is paint instead of anodized, they are rough-ridin' and so on. That's was never true about the SX or the Manticor. My SX only gave up the slick, taking on some chips and with a serious loss of finish, after about 14 years. And I have one Manticor that is six years old; it's taken one barely visible 3mm water stain and still rides 110% slick. So, on a cost-per-year basis, you come out sweet on the Manticor.So again, if you want the quickest, slickest ride for your mouse, better get one of (the last of) these while you can.Disclaimer: To get all the slick & quick I can, I also put strips ofCS Hyde Teflon Mouse Tape (click here)over my mice feet … and I also spritz & wipe the Manticor with a bit ofDuPont Silicone Teflon Lubricant Aerosol Spray (click here).
product.title: Razer Manticor: Optimized Tracking Surface - Aircraft Grade Aluminum Material - Microscopic Texture - Gaming Mouse Pad

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on March 13, 2020
review.title: Smooth surface and a reliable material
review.review: This is overpriced by a long shot, as is the Razer way, but it's one of the few things they make that has 0 mechanical or electronic complexity, meaning it's one of the only items they sell that doesn't break within a few months anymore. I was hoping to find something like my 13 year old Razer ExactMat's "speed" side, which is still going strong after daily use that entire time. This manticore is as close as it gets, and is just as nice if not better of a surface. It isn't made of layered hard plastics like most of the other brands, which start to come apart and peel after a year or so. Honestly, again, shocked that Razer didn't find a way to screw this up, but they didn't.It's worth getting even at the stupidly high price because it will last just fine indefinitely as long as you don't lose it, and it isn't hard to clean, it's polished metal.Knocking a star off because they'd be making a nice profit at half the price, and again, to reiterate, under normal circumstances I avoid new-school Razer like the plague, because they make cheap garbage... except for this.
product.title: Razer Manticor: Optimized Tracking Surface - Aircraft Grade Aluminum Material - Microscopic Texture - Gaming Mouse Pad

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on May 12, 2018
review.title: High Quality, One Thing to Keep in Mind
review.review: Extremely high quality aluminum mouse pad, that I am yet to find any flaws in. It has a nice padded bottom that stops it from sliding around and potentially scratching the surface its on. The aluminum itself is extremely strong and does not show ware or scratches either. I have found that it is by far my favorite mouse pad to use with my Apple Magic Mouse.The one thing that I will point out that might seem obvious, but I digress; there is no cushion saving your wrist from wresting on the hard aluminum. They say that its "ergonomically more comfortable" but its just hard metal, and your wrist will get sore if your rest it on the pad while using for extended periods of time. Just something to keep in mind.

review.title: Great mouse, did research before buying
review.review: I did my research directly on Razer's website to find the mouse that fit my needs best. I was having issues with my previous Razer mouse, only to find that my mousepad was the cause. I actually put away my Mamba Wireless for this mouse because I prefer the soft cord and typically don't gravitate toward wireless for gaming. If you are looking for a wireless mouse, I would recommend the Mamba wireless. For wired, any of Razer's Speedflex models, including this one. I ultimately chose this one and buying here for price and dpi, as I typically game at 9,000 dpi, but like to change that a bit for different games/gameplay types.Overall, would buy again and recommend as a wired mouse. The pink is a nice color to spice up my rig.
product.title: Razer Viper 8KHz Ultralight Ambidextrous Wired Gaming Mouse: Fastest Gaming Switches - 20K DPI Optical Sensor - Chroma RGB...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Lost Connections, bad lag, poor performance
review.review: I had been looking at this mouse for a while and finally convinced myself to buy one.I was very excited for the new mouse.My somewhat new computer has the RGB fans and lighting, so I was excited to add to my setup with this mouse and mouse dock.Add to this the fact that this is a Razer product (supposedly top tier), I thought I was getting something good.I bought this mouse, received it two days latter, returned it the next day.I let the mouse fully charge before using (per the instructions).Once it was fully charged I started using it for the last part of my work day.I was presenting on a Teams meeting and twice in the hour meeting it lost connection.Luckily I still had my other mouse connected so I was able to use it the second time to finish the meeting.Several other times through the remaining part of the day/evening the mouse would lose connection with the computer, usually requiring me to turn it off then back on again for it to start working.Other times it would lag behind very bad and I would have to wait for it to catch up to what I was trying to do.If this is "hyperspeed" technology, I would hate to see how a normal speed mouse works from Razer.I could not imagine anyone using this for gaming, it is horrible.Finally, I tried to customize the buttons on the mouse through Razer Synapse.I would set the buttons, save the setup, and if I left Razer Synapse open, the buttons would work with no issues.As soon as I closed the Razer application, it is as if the mouse would reset to factory defaults and loose all the settings I had just saved.I tried this multiple times with the same results.I even checked other sites for instructions on how to customize the mouse settings to make sure I was not missing a step, no luck.So, in addition to the loss of connection, and horrible lagging; if I were to keep them mouse I would have to open Razer Synapse every morning, setup the mouse again how I wanted it to be, then leave the application open all day just to make sure it worked as designed.I am new to Razer products like this but not new to computers.I have been working in the IS field for over a decade, and I know how to use, and troubleshoot issues with these devices.This mouse just is not a good mouse and not worth the money at all.Please don't waste your money on this overpriced, underperforming mouse.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2021
review.title: You get what you pay for
review.review: Where does all your money go and why is it so much? That's the $150 question for everybody. The TLDR is that it's incredibly well built, fully wireless, responsive, and the lightest mouse on the market. And it's pearly white.I don't know what other relevant details I can give. This mouse has been stress-tested by the best in the tech. industry and Logitech weren't lying, this mouse is FAST. It has incredibly low latency, very good battery life (I mean...there's zero RGB lighting), and is quite possibly the safest shape a mouse can come in. If you don't consider your hands much larger or smaller than most people, it will probably be comfortable holding this mouse.The visual design is intelligent. It has this elegance that isn't the embarrassing "gamer" stylings of other products but isn't so minimalistic that you wouldn't immediately recognize this mouse at first glance. Anybody who's ever used this mouse knows exactly what this feels and looks like.Is this mouse necessary? Absolutely not. I think the only thing more over-the-top than this mouse is the amount of R&D and feedback Logitech went through to create one of the best mice in PC gaming. I do prefer the Razer Viper Ultimate over this because I prefer the texture and shape. I am also bothered that a $150 computer mouse looks almost too simple. Also, in my opinion, the Viper Ultimate doesn't feel that much heavier than this. I wanted to note that, in case anybody wanted a cheaper alternative.Overall, this mouse is a flex, or for anybody who wants to go out of their way to spend time and money on their gaming hobby (gaming career maybe?). I considered buying this since it launched and was not disappointed. Here's to hoping I get my $150 out of this mouse.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2021
review.title: Great quality mouse, but not for everyone
review.review: I believe this mouse is made out of great quality. No creaking in the frame, mouse feet are very smooth, is very light for being wireless, and the sensor is great! But there are two things that really bother me about this mouse that has made me sell this mouse and buy another mouse. First, the switches are terrible. They are cheap Omron switches that do not feel as good as other switches (i.e Razer Viper Mini, which is ironic because it costs $30). If you are going to buy this mouse, learn soldering skills and switch these out for some Kailh 4.0 or 8.0 switches. Second (and biggest issue for me), the shape. When you first grip this mouse, you feel like you are gripping a potato. I have medium sized hands (17 x 9.5 CM or 6 3/4" x 3 1/4" IN) and I prefer to claw grip my mice, which I cannot comfortably claw grip this mouse because it is too long and too tall for my hands. If you have medium sized hands in length, fingertip or palm grip this mouse but don't claw grip this mouse. If you have large hands (especially in length), I highly recommend this mouse because you can claw and fingertip this mouse comfortably, and maybe even palm grip. If you have small hands, there are better sized mice for you guys.

review.title: Best mouse I've ever used!
review.review: I was skeptical at first and even getting it, I was impressed with the weight but wasn't sure the value was there. After using it for several hours, I realized how great of a mouse it is. I love the non-RGB "feature" too! Dialing back RGB makes everything look better. The slides are great, the optional grips are amazing, its just a very solid mouse.With the battery, it charges extremely fast and so far after about 7 hours of use, it's gone down 1%!The last thing I'll say is its amazing the weight without having to resort to honeycomb where they literally make the actual shell itself porous which is simply a bad idea all around. You get the extreme light weight (which I actually love!) mixed with durability and protection.There is nothing I can say about this mouse thats bad so far.. I really am more impressed with it than I thought I would be.Would recommend 10/10

review.title: Seriously, the software is not compatible with MacOS?
review.review: It's 2021 so can someone please tell me why Razer is making software (for one of their more popular mice) which is not compatible with MacOS? Let me clarify, you'll be told to download Synapse 2, which is Mac compatible, but Synapse 2 is not compatible with the Razer Basilisk V2 – only Synapse 3 is compatible with this mouse. However, Synapse 3 is not compatible with Mac OS, so basically you cannot take advantage of all the mouse has to offer. You may as well be using a $10 USB mouse from Walgreens because without the software it offers the same level of customization.Arrrrrggggg!

It's just not designed for a comfortable fit. If you're looking for a gaming mouse you want to replace every year or so, it's fine, but please don't waste your money if you're an artist or someone that spends a lot of time on the mouse.

review.title: Has Optical Switches
review.review: I'm not a gamer but I use a DAW a lot and there are many settings and adjustments to make on plug-ins, etc. It doesn't take long to wear out a mouse with contact switches. Regular contact switches bounce from day one and the bounce increases with wear until you get double-clicks and multiple clicks which cause errors and results other than what you want. I just wanted this mouse for the optical switch, which has no bounce. However, to get the driver, you have to install bloatwear and nagwear.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2021
review.title: I hope you have big hands.
review.review: This mouse is definitely *not* for people who have hands on the smaller side of average. I don't have tiny hands by any means, but this mouse is extremely awkward for me to use without accidentally hitting the first row of keys on the side. My hand simply doesn't wrap around enough of the bulk of this thing to get a good grip on only the non-button portions of the mouse. This leads to firing off skills or macros that I absolutely do not intend to use yet while just moving the mouse around; I've had to disable the first row of keys entirely to avoid this.Another problem the size presents is that it won't consistently hold down the LMB if I want to click and drag; it'll often let go prematurely because my fingertips apparently don't reach far enough forward to get the leverage it needs to keep the sensors in contact.Years ago, I had a Naga that had plates you could swap out to adjust the size appropriate to your needs, but they apparently don't make them anymore, and are going with a "one (large) size fits all" approach. This is a major shame, because it's excluding a fairly significant portion of the gaming population.If you have big ol' hands, then I bet this mouse would work great for you. It's lightweight (almost too lightweight) and pretty responsive.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2021
review.title: The only premium wireless mmo mouse. needs some competition
review.review: The only MMO mouse that is wireless, from a name brand company.Features: comes with PTFE mouse feet which is very generous and not common, usually you buy these aftermarket.fairly light considering all the hardware on it. another big plus.comes with 3 side plates. one with 12 buttons, one with 2, and one with I think 6? very cool and convenient, and easy to swap out.no perceivable latency, however I originally bought this mouse used. it would lose connection for several seconds, which is unusable for gaming and just annoying in any other application, especially at this price.I returned it and bought a new one, which has the same issue but only loses connectivity very briefly, enough for me to just ignore. I dont play shooters or 1st person games with it so whatever.the razer software has automatic profile switching. you can set up specific keybinds for any program (even ones that arent games) and when you switch to a different program the keybinds automatically swap. this is insanely useful for video editing, music production, MMOs, all kinds of things.battery life is great. naturally, the lights suck a lot of it up but you should turn them off if you want it to last long.I like the ergonomics a lot, I think it feels great in my hand. it's meant to be held with your fingers laid on it and your palm mostly lifted off of it. it feels very comfortable but I'd like it slightly lighter for easier movement.if it werent for the disconnection this would be 5/5 stars. it has zero ccompetition, is feature packed and is good at what it does.

review.title: Left-Click Stopped Working After A Few Months
review.review: I purchased this mouse for light gaming and typical web browsing. Within 6 months, I noticed the left-click was not holding down correctly. Physically it felt fine, but it was basically unplayable in games. I tried every solution and the problem only got worse over time so I figured it was a hardware problem rather than a software issue. I took great care of the mouse and used it VERY lightly yet it still gave out quickly. Not to mention the Razer Synapse program is terrible. Unfortunately for me, the company that sold me the product through Amazon, "TECHLOBBY", is not an authorized seller of Razer products so the 2 year manufacturers warranty did NOT cover this issue. On Razer's website, Amazon is an authorized seller of Razer products but many of the companies that sell through Amazon are not so it is very misleading. This mouse is no longer manufactured by Razer so don't even bother buying it. For $50, this mouse became useless after a few months of light use, DO NOT RECOMEND.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2021
review.title: Its weight is the only stand-out feature.
review.review: The mouse 1 and 2 touch when fully depressed simultaneously. Scroll wheel isn't the most comfortable, but there's nothing wrong with it. Side buttons are very thin. Stock feet are basic black teflon. Those are the shortcomings of this mouse. I personally got used to the scroll wheel and side buttons quickly and aimed confidently with this mouse. The side buttons have good clicks and decent travel. So their ridiculously thin shape alone really doesn't make them unusable. Cable is a decent paracord. Aftermarket ones are better, but this one's fine. Replaced the feet before I even used it. It uses G203/G305 skates without the sensor ring, which makes it easy to find skates. The main reason you should get it is the weight. Under 45g stock is NUTS. This combined with the narrow egg shape makes for an extremely nimble mouse. This is a mouse you get strictly for fingertip grip in shooter games. There's really no other reason to get it considering its shortcomings. I've owned like 15 or so gaming mice and would not get this for anything else. Not general use. Not other types of games. Not productivity. Absolutely a niche product.Edit, after trying more mice, I no longer believe the extreme low weight is as advantageous as what I once thought. The feet and side buttons on this mouse also don't warrant a positive review. I have dropped this to 3 stars from 4. I wouldn't use this mouse for anything other than aim trainers honestly. The only thing it has going for it is its weight.
product.title: Teamwolf Ultra Lightweight 45g only Optical Pro Gaming Mouse Speedflex Cable 16000 DPI Optical Sensor Lurker Mk-01

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2021
review.title: Amazing for this price
review.review: literally best sensor out there one of the lightest mouse ever. perfect og Logitech style shell. Just replace the feet and you'regood to go because the feet are from g203 and it's not that good. you can get ceramic ones from here. also you can replace the Paracord without having to take out the pcb. the switches are great if you want to adjust tension there are two screws inside the top shell. scroll wheel is just very basic. dpi button is very stiff like I said just adjust those tension screws inside. another mod you can do is 3d print a even smaller shell and take the sensor and the cord from this mouse. also painting it is very easy everything comes apart nicely! this is an all around a good mouse for claw style or fingertips style. side buttons are average as well. they're platic soldered on if you want to paint them they'd come apart if you press a little hard enough. And they're still nicely held back on the shell even if you do that. overall I'd say a good mouse coming from a glorious o- user. oh and the software doesn't do polling rate just basic things you can download that from their webpage it's bare bones stuff. if you can code I'm sure you can come up with something to adjust that based on either this or the Cox cm600 software.
product.title: Teamwolf Ultra Lightweight 45g only Optical Pro Gaming Mouse Speedflex Cable 16000 DPI Optical Sensor Lurker Mk-01

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: TERRIBLE. Scroll Wheel WILL Start to Squeak and Fail After 3 Months.
review.review: For the first few months, it was good. Everything worked as it should. The cord was not a problem and extended long enough to reach my tower. I enjoyed having two buttons on the side for gaming purposes. The mouse fits nicely in your hand. The scroll wheel and the design light up a pretty white hue. Aesthetically pleasing and matches my white set-up.BUT. After 3 months, just this past September, the scroll wheel started to make this OBNOXIOUS screeching sound every time I scrolled. I didn't realize how much I scroll until this started to happen. It was ear aching and I looked up how to fix it, saw that MANY others with this mouse had a similar problem, and the fix requires you to dissemble the whole thing to oil it. I am not savvy with that so I left it alone in hopes that it would just go away with time.Well the squeaking has reduced but now everytime I attempt to scroll, it causes my window to jitter and scroll back the OPPOSITE way. So here I am battling with my mouse to scroll smoothly for just a couple inches. It's the most frustrating thing I've experienced with a mouse and I've finally given up and am purchasing a different one. I never had a mouse that couldn't even last a single year... this is a poor product in my opinion.

review.review: lightweight, yes.LED functionality, yes.change the colors, yes.USB-A to USB-C connection, yes.Steel Series gaming program functionality, yes.adjust the DPI, yes.in usual Steel Series fashion, you get a mouse that does what it says it will, lets you have colors that can breathe or stay solid in zones, and with adjustable sensitivity.i still find Steel Series to be a better deal than RAZR products and since my laptop automatically comes with a Steel Series keyboard, my devices can be synced together.i went with the wired because not only is it cheaper, i have a tendency to lose the mouse when it's wireless.this cable does disconnect from the mouse when you're transporting it.I'll likely leave it on otherwise because it's easier to keep track of. at $35, pretty happy.my only concern would be for the future.because if the design to make it lightweight by cutting out a geometric pattern, the inner circuitry is visible.it says water resistant which i'm guessing also applies to sweat resistant.i'm not a heavy hand sweater, but to anyone that is, i could see this being a problem in the future.i haven't had it long enough to determine for sure how much of a problem it would be.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2021
review.title: Best Mid-grade optical gaming mouse
review.review: Sometimes you don't want a mouse with a bazillion buttons. You want it for work and gaming without spending a stupid amount of money. Enter the Steelseries Prime FPS gaming mouse....not too fancy, built well and is a real delight to use. Sturdy, rugged and accurate for gaming. This mouse is a great buy for the money and proves you don't need to spend $ hundreds on a mouse with 42 buttons. If you like your mice, simple and sturdy/well built, this is the mouse for you. I replaced my razer mouse because it was starting to double-click in gaming.
product.title: SteelSeries Aerox 3 Wireless - Super Light Gaming Mouse - 18,000 CPI TrueMove Air Optical Sensor - Ultra-lightweight Water...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2021
review.title: Working well
review.review: Mice are like shoes, so it's difficult to say what works well for everyone. I use a mouse 14+ h/day for long days at work and then what time I can have saving the universe. I've owned about every brand, both wired and wireless. My latest venture with the SteelSeries was based off a YT vid review that just happened to play. I'd been using a Razer Viper Mini for the past year and while it was a good mouse, it's just a bit too mini for me (average size hands).I've been pleased so far with this mouse. The weight is lighter than most, which I've increasingly grown to appreciate. I don't care much for wireless mice, so this wired one was my preference. The cable is ok - no kinks and with my setup, no drag/pull as I'm moving around. I already had a SteelSeries keyboard, so the software worked without issue picking up the mouse and adjusting settings. I've never had issue with SteelSeries software before, so that's been a non-issue as well.The mouse feels pretty good and has no plastic stuck on the sides like some of SteelSeries other mice. Those glued on pieces are nothing short of a mess over time as they goop out and get on your desk/hands/mouse. This mouse is all solid and is comfortable for long usage times. Clickers work well andthe wheel was surprisingly better than I feared - not exactly smoot, not horribly bumpy.Overall, I like this mouse and for the money, feel like I got a good product for the cost. I generally go through mice every 1 to 3 years, depending on how they hold up. I'm hoping this holds up to the task.

review.title: Great mouse, did research before buying
review.review: I did my research directly on Razer's website to find the mouse that fit my needs best. I was having issues with my previous Razer mouse, only to find that my mousepad was the cause. I actually put away my Mamba Wireless for this mouse because I prefer the soft cord and typically don't gravitate toward wireless for gaming. If you are looking for a wireless mouse, I would recommend the Mamba wireless. For wired, any of Razer's Speedflex models, including this one. I ultimately chose this one and buying here for price and dpi, as I typically game at 9,000 dpi, but like to change that a bit for different games/gameplay types.Overall, would buy again and recommend as a wired mouse. The pink is a nice color to spice up my rig.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Lost Connections, bad lag, poor performance
review.review: I had been looking at this mouse for a while and finally convinced myself to buy one.I was very excited for the new mouse.My somewhat new computer has the RGB fans and lighting, so I was excited to add to my setup with this mouse and mouse dock.Add to this the fact that this is a Razer product (supposedly top tier), I thought I was getting something good.I bought this mouse, received it two days latter, returned it the next day.I let the mouse fully charge before using (per the instructions).Once it was fully charged I started using it for the last part of my work day.I was presenting on a Teams meeting and twice in the hour meeting it lost connection.Luckily I still had my other mouse connected so I was able to use it the second time to finish the meeting.Several other times through the remaining part of the day/evening the mouse would lose connection with the computer, usually requiring me to turn it off then back on again for it to start working.Other times it would lag behind very bad and I would have to wait for it to catch up to what I was trying to do.If this is "hyperspeed" technology, I would hate to see how a normal speed mouse works from Razer.I could not imagine anyone using this for gaming, it is horrible.Finally, I tried to customize the buttons on the mouse through Razer Synapse.I would set the buttons, save the setup, and if I left Razer Synapse open, the buttons would work with no issues.As soon as I closed the Razer application, it is as if the mouse would reset to factory defaults and loose all the settings I had just saved.I tried this multiple times with the same results.I even checked other sites for instructions on how to customize the mouse settings to make sure I was not missing a step, no luck.So, in addition to the loss of connection, and horrible lagging; if I were to keep them mouse I would have to open Razer Synapse every morning, setup the mouse again how I wanted it to be, then leave the application open all day just to make sure it worked as designed.I am new to Razer products like this but not new to computers.I have been working in the IS field for over a decade, and I know how to use, and troubleshoot issues with these devices.This mouse just is not a good mouse and not worth the money at all.Please don't waste your money on this overpriced, underperforming mouse.
product.title: Razer Viper Mini Ultralight Gaming Mouse: Fastest Gaming Switches - 8500 DPI Optical Sensor - Chroma RGB Underglow Lightin...

review.title: Has Optical Switches
review.review: I'm not a gamer but I use a DAW a lot and there are many settings and adjustments to make on plug-ins, etc. It doesn't take long to wear out a mouse with contact switches. Regular contact switches bounce from day one and the bounce increases with wear until you get double-clicks and multiple clicks which cause errors and results other than what you want. I just wanted this mouse for the optical switch, which has no bounce. However, to get the driver, you have to install bloatwear and nagwear.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review.title: Click away
review.review: Perhaps one of nicest mouse clicking sounds and feeling I have ever heard with hardly any delay between clicks.However a major nitpick I have is when you use the mouse for the first time on a pc it opens up a download prompt for the software which is convenient but distracting when using it on a different pc for the first time (haven't tested it just hypothetically speaking)To use certain features i.e macros you need the software to be installed AND be in the background but overall mouse control you dont need the software.After you figure our your button bindings delete the software then have your pc forget the mouse then reconnect the mouse and close out the download prompt (after you do it once it won't reappear unless you make your pc forget it) This solved the issue I had with it skipping abruptly both in-game and browsing.After these changes its a very solid mouse and felt right at home using it without needing to make any adjustments.Only nitpick I have is that you can't get custom shells individually in the official website or other websites.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2021
review.title: You get what you pay for
review.review: Where does all your money go and why is it so much? That's the $150 question for everybody. The TLDR is that it's incredibly well built, fully wireless, responsive, and the lightest mouse on the market. And it's pearly white.I don't know what other relevant details I can give. This mouse has been stress-tested by the best in the tech. industry and Logitech weren't lying, this mouse is FAST. It has incredibly low latency, very good battery life (I mean...there's zero RGB lighting), and is quite possibly the safest shape a mouse can come in. If you don't consider your hands much larger or smaller than most people, it will probably be comfortable holding this mouse.The visual design is intelligent. It has this elegance that isn't the embarrassing "gamer" stylings of other products but isn't so minimalistic that you wouldn't immediately recognize this mouse at first glance. Anybody who's ever used this mouse knows exactly what this feels and looks like.Is this mouse necessary? Absolutely not. I think the only thing more over-the-top than this mouse is the amount of R&D and feedback Logitech went through to create one of the best mice in PC gaming. I do prefer the Razer Viper Ultimate over this because I prefer the texture and shape. I am also bothered that a $150 computer mouse looks almost too simple. Also, in my opinion, the Viper Ultimate doesn't feel that much heavier than this. I wanted to note that, in case anybody wanted a cheaper alternative.Overall, this mouse is a flex, or for anybody who wants to go out of their way to spend time and money on their gaming hobby (gaming career maybe?). I considered buying this since it launched and was not disappointed. Here's to hoping I get my $150 out of this mouse.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2021
review.title: Great quality mouse, but not for everyone
review.review: I believe this mouse is made out of great quality. No creaking in the frame, mouse feet are very smooth, is very light for being wireless, and the sensor is great! But there are two things that really bother me about this mouse that has made me sell this mouse and buy another mouse. First, the switches are terrible. They are cheap Omron switches that do not feel as good as other switches (i.e Razer Viper Mini, which is ironic because it costs $30). If you are going to buy this mouse, learn soldering skills and switch these out for some Kailh 4.0 or 8.0 switches. Second (and biggest issue for me), the shape. When you first grip this mouse, you feel like you are gripping a potato. I have medium sized hands (17 x 9.5 CM or 6 3/4" x 3 1/4" IN) and I prefer to claw grip my mice, which I cannot comfortably claw grip this mouse because it is too long and too tall for my hands. If you have medium sized hands in length, fingertip or palm grip this mouse but don't claw grip this mouse. If you have large hands (especially in length), I highly recommend this mouse because you can claw and fingertip this mouse comfortably, and maybe even palm grip. If you have small hands, there are better sized mice for you guys.

review.title: Best mouse I've ever used!
review.review: I was skeptical at first and even getting it, I was impressed with the weight but wasn't sure the value was there. After using it for several hours, I realized how great of a mouse it is. I love the non-RGB "feature" too! Dialing back RGB makes everything look better. The slides are great, the optional grips are amazing, its just a very solid mouse.With the battery, it charges extremely fast and so far after about 7 hours of use, it's gone down 1%!The last thing I'll say is its amazing the weight without having to resort to honeycomb where they literally make the actual shell itself porous which is simply a bad idea all around. You get the extreme light weight (which I actually love!) mixed with durability and protection.There is nothing I can say about this mouse thats bad so far.. I really am more impressed with it than I thought I would be.Would recommend 10/10

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2021
review.title: Side-grade to the V2. Great if you never owned the V2 / Razer Basilisk Ultimate.
review.review: When compared to the V2 / Razer Basilisk Ultimate , after 1 week of use:TLDR - Scroll wheel and LED upgrades are good.But... the +/- resistance option for the scroll wheel on the underside of the mouse is now gone. I'm not a fan of the changes to the button internal switches and how they feel or sound.Pros: I like the changes to the scroll wheel. No complaints there. I like that they finally copied one of the features I loved about older Logitech mice. The LED zones on the bottom of the mouse are sweet for you RGB fans (which you probably area if you are buying this).Cons: (It's hard to know if these are little defects with the specific mouse I got, or all V3s are like this). I'm not a huge fan of these upgraded switches for the buttons. I liked the way the V2 felt and sounded better. These are louder and require more force to press. The thumb buttons for forward/back or buttons 3 and 4, feel and sound different from each other. It really annoys me. And the new version of the button 5 or the sniper button, feels worse than the V2 for sure. The button has farther travel distance, feels more mushy, and does not press smoothly. Pressing it feels like the bottom side of the button angles down more than the top. I also hoped this button would be closer to your thumb than it was with V2, which for me always felt too far away and I would need to adjust my whole hang to press it. With the V3, for better or worse, its in the same exact place as the V2.I'm actually debating buying another one to see if the switches feel or sound any better, and then return the worse of the two.The +/- resistance option for the scroll wheel on the underside of the mouse is now gone. No way to adjust resistance. I really wish they had kept that feature.Some people wont like the change to the weight, but I wont mind it.With all that said, if you never owned the V2 / Razer Basilisk Ultimate, you'll be happy with this mouse.
product.title: Razer Basilisk V3 Customizable Ergonomic Gaming Mouse: Fastest Gaming Mouse Switch - Chroma RGB Lighting - 26K DPI Optical...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2021
review.title: A better wired V2, but with some slight setbacks
review.review: The infinite scroll wheel is awesome to have especially for someone like me who's switching over from a Logitech MX Master. The Basilisk's shape isn't as comfortable for my hands as that mouse, mainly because it's lacking a little in size compared to the MX. This mouse is much nicer for gaming though as there are more DPI options, and honestly the clicks seem a little more responsive for gaming.The software control for this mouse is good, but I feel it's not as responsive as the wired Basilisk V2 that I had was. This is mainly with regards to Razer's Chroma software. I tried to have the bottom portion of LEDs disabled, but it can be pretty laggy or buggy as an effect. The main reason why I tried to turn off the bottom portion of RGB lights is because it can be pretty distracting. The lighting around that area looks totally badass, but the reflection it makes against the surface looks kind of ugly. Honestly, I think V2 looks a little bit more classy because it's not leaving an RGB shadow behind by default.Still I think the V3 is overall a better upgrade over the V2 because of the infinite scroll wheel. If you don't mind the flashier RGB, this will give you the same comfort as the V2, but with more versatile functionality.

Looking past the defects that I have experienced I still hate that it weighs heavier than the V2. You can debate if having an infinite scroll wheel is useful enough to an extra 10+ grams. review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: TERRIBLE. Scroll Wheel WILL Start to Squeak and Fail After 3 Months.
review.review: For the first few months, it was good. Everything worked as it should. The cord was not a problem and extended long enough to reach my tower. I enjoyed having two buttons on the side for gaming purposes. The mouse fits nicely in your hand. The scroll wheel and the design light up a pretty white hue. Aesthetically pleasing and matches my white set-up.BUT. After 3 months, just this past September, the scroll wheel started to make this OBNOXIOUS screeching sound every time I scrolled. I didn't realize how much I scroll until this started to happen. It was ear aching and I looked up how to fix it, saw that MANY others with this mouse had a similar problem, and the fix requires you to dissemble the whole thing to oil it. I am not savvy with that so I left it alone in hopes that it would just go away with time.Well the squeaking has reduced but now everytime I attempt to scroll, it causes my window to jitter and scroll back the OPPOSITE way. So here I am battling with my mouse to scroll smoothly for just a couple inches. It's the most frustrating thing I've experienced with a mouse and I've finally given up and am purchasing a different one. I never had a mouse that couldn't even last a single year... this is a poor product in my opinion.

The thumb/side buttons are SOOOOO close, you'll eventually hit both when your intentions are to only hit one, thusly accidently using that feature if you've mapped anything to them. It's very, very lightweight which didn't instill confidence in playing a character for which you had to keep moving. Yes, I am spoiled by my OLD Logitech G302 and after using this Razer DeatchAdder Essenetial for the past 2 weeks, it's going back.*IF* you're starting out and looking for a DECENT Gaming Mouse, then this might be for you, considering the price, but I've lost far too many battles because of the side/thumb buttons being too close together.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: Completely useless for my target purpose (gaming)
review.review: I've had a SteelSeries Rival 310 for a couple of years now and am perfectly happy with it, but then I found out about this model which seemed like a straight upgrade to me after watching and reading a couple of reviews. After getting it out of the box, I was excited to test it out in my favorite game, DOTA 2. Very quickly however I found out that unlike the two side buttons of the Rival 310, which are extremely easy and super natural to press, all 5 of the side buttons of the Rival 5 were exceedingly difficult and unnatural to press, and also led to mouse movement due to the force required to press the buttons. Also, my thumb had to be in a very weird and cramped position to be able to press the side buttons at all. The big forward side button was basically impossible to press, and the up/down rocker was very difficult to press as well. From the natural thumb resting position, it requires a significant movement to be able to press even the closest two ("back/forward") buttons, unlike with the Rival 310 where those buttons are basically instant-press as soon as you think about them. Therefore, this mouse is completely unusable for playing Dota 2, and I would guess any other game.I have medium to slightly large sized hands, and I would imagine someone with very large hands / long fingers, or some specific grip style might be able to use the side buttons (I am using a standard grip), but for me they are completely unusable. Again, the Rival 310 side buttons are perfectly usable so I'm unsure why they decided to move them way out of reach.The other features of the mouse are fine, as is the build quality, although I heavily dislike the default-on lighting, and the fact that the RGB lighting settings are NOT stored on the mouse itself, so if you use it with a different PC or laptop on which you don't have the SteelSeries software installed, you are forced to have your mouse glow super bright in random colors. The cable is OK too.I hope they make a "real" upgraded version of the Rival 310, with more side buttons, that are natural to reach, like the two existing ones, and not this "apparent" upgrade which is really a huge downgrade.
product.title: SteelSeries Rival 3 Gaming Mouse - 8,500 CPI TrueMove Core Optical Sensor - 6 Programmable Buttons - Split Trigger Buttons...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2021
review.title: Unacceptable Battery Life
review.review: I would have thought battery life would be great considering how quickly the mouse goes to sleep, but what would otherwise be a solid mouse for the price is ruined by terrible battery life. I am having to replace the AAAs in my mouse what feels like every 1-2 weeks.There is a power saving setting in the Steelseries software, but it is locked at 150hz polling rate which makes even browsing the web clunky and unresponsive. I especially notice it in the scroll wheel, which feels like it drops roughly every other click.I would recommend this mouse only if you have a battery charging station within reach of your desk and can live with the inconvenience. I will be replacing mine with a Logitech G305, and I guess this will be a fine emergency backup as it is past the return period.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review.title: Probably good, but mine wasn't.
review.review: Right off the bat, it's a comfortable mouse. Feels good for my hands, but your mileage may vary. That's basically where the good experiences end for me though.After a day of using it, the signal would cut out for seconds at a time. Tried a different usb port, tried a different machine entirely, it's either the dongle or the hardware in the mouse itself. Ok no problem, switched it to bluetooth and it worked for a bit but also would cut out occasionally though not as often as over the dongle.Ok, so I began troubleshooting. I downloaded the software and updated the firmware, which didn't help anything really, the mouse still had signal issues. Also of note is that the steelseries pc software is one of the more buggier third party apps I've experienced. At a certain point I needed to jump through hoops to get the mouse to update the DPI profiles properly like rapidly switching back and forth between bluetooth and radio in order to get the software to finally push the updated config to the mouse.So where does that leave you? Well, it's a crapshoot like 9 out of 10 modern "gaming" products. These companies cut corners somewhere, and usually a safe bet for them is to skimp on quality control. Despite this, people seem happy with the mouse, so buy it with free returns only just in case.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2021
review.title: Low profile high performance mouse surface
review.review: I bought this to replace an 8-year-old Razer Sphex skin, which was almost identical other than the size and design. The Sphex was being used on the tiny computer desk in our family room. I like having a low profile mouse pad on that desk which doesn't stick out. The Sphex did well considering how much use it got, and how my daughter liked to lift up the edges and crease them with her nails during online class until tiny pieces eventually tore up bit by bit.I like the design of these pads. The Sphex was accurately called a desktop skin, which is what it is. This new one's called 'thin mouse pad', which can be misleading. It's basically a piece of plastic that's smooth and tacky on one side (to stay in place), and textured on the other side to give good mouse performance. This new version has a cloth 'tag' that you can use to pull it up and reposition it. These are very easy to reposition, but only as long as you keep the tacky side off the table as little as possible so it doesn't collect dust, and make sure any surface you move it to is cleaned thoroughly. You also have to be careful not to crease it, since any crease on this material is permanent and will always show. For all these reasons, this is NOT appropriate as a travel mouse pad.I was initially worried that the design on this would be too bright, but the actual mousepad has more muted colors than in the pictures. Overall I highly recommend it.
product.title: Razer Sphex V2 - Mini - Ultra-Thin Form Factor - Durable polycarbonate finish

I actually put away my Mamba Wireless for this mouse because I prefer the soft cord and typically don't gravitate toward wireless for gaming. If you are looking for a wireless mouse, I would recommend the Mamba wireless. For wired, any of Razer's Speedflex models, including this one. I ultimately chose this one and buying here for price and dpi, as I typically game at 9,000 dpi, but like to change that a bit for different games/gameplay types.Overall, would buy again and recommend as a wired mouse. review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2021
review.title: Lost Connections, bad lag, poor performance
review.review: I had been looking at this mouse for a while and finally convinced myself to buy one.I was very excited for the new mouse.My somewhat new computer has the RGB fans and lighting, so I was excited to add to my setup with this mouse and mouse dock.Add to this the fact that this is a Razer product (supposedly top tier), I thought I was getting something good.I bought this mouse, received it two days latter, returned it the next day.I let the mouse fully charge before using (per the instructions).Once it was fully charged I started using it for the last part of my work day.I was presenting on a Teams meeting and twice in the hour meeting it lost connection.Luckily I still had my other mouse connected so I was able to use it the second time to finish the meeting.Several other times through the remaining part of the day/evening the mouse would lose connection with the computer, usually requiring me to turn it off then back on again for it to start working.Other times it would lag behind very bad and I would have to wait for it to catch up to what I was trying to do.If this is "hyperspeed" technology, I would hate to see how a normal speed mouse works from Razer.I could not imagine anyone using this for gaming, it is horrible.Finally, I tried to customize the buttons on the mouse through Razer Synapse.I would set the buttons, save the setup, and if I left Razer Synapse open, the buttons would work with no issues.As soon as I closed the Razer application, it is as if the mouse would reset to factory defaults and loose all the settings I had just saved.I tried this multiple times with the same results.I even checked other sites for instructions on how to customize the mouse settings to make sure I was not missing a step, no luck.So, in addition to the loss of connection, and horrible lagging; if I were to keep them mouse I would have to open Razer Synapse every morning, setup the mouse again how I wanted it to be, then leave the application open all day just to make sure it worked as designed.I am new to Razer products like this but not new to computers.I have been working in the IS field for over a decade, and I know how to use, and troubleshoot issues with these devices.This mouse just is not a good mouse and not worth the money at all.Please don't waste your money on this overpriced, underperforming mouse.
product.title: Razer Viper Ultimate Hyperspeed Lightest Wireless Gaming Mouse & RGB Charging Dock: Fastest Gaming Mouse Switch - 20K DPI ...

review.review: I've been a razer member for over 2 years and have been impressed with every product I've gotten, but this one out of them all, was easily the best. It's both cost effective and has amazing lighting features, not to mention a ton of programmable buttons. It's got 2 buttons to both lower and raise the dpi settings, 3 side buttons that are programmable, along with hyperkeys. What that is is the ability to combine 2 or more buttons to make 1 programmable action and u can make a ton of them. I'd personally recommend this mouse to anyone who loves long lasting products, but also amazing RGB. Also will look great in ANY setup. #teamrazer

review.title: My favorite mouse of all time

review.title: Quality and lifespan is a fraction of what Razer used to be
review.review: This is my 3rd DeathAdder mouse. The first two I used for about 4 years each before having to upgrade to a new version due to wear and tear. I am 10 months in to using this version and there is already a tear forming in the thumbgrip. Razer has denied a warranty claim saying it is "customer induced". I guess their product lifespan has dropped so much that they will no longer honor a warranty claim inside the 1-year period they advertise.I'd recommend looking at other brands. Razer quality has degraded compared to the previous models.

review.title: Customer Service is Awful
review.review: Didn’t work right out of the box. It was a gift for my son so I ordered it early and by the time he used it, it was too late to return it thru Amazon (which is stupid for products that are clearly never used but I digress..) I had to deal with Razer support which is excessively painful. The switch on the bottom won’t move and they want VIDEO of the switch not moving?!?! It also turns itself off when he’s gaming and they want someone to stand there and video him gaming until it shuts off. Really? I would happily send it back to exchange it, but they want all this other time wasting crap first. Not happy. It’s a high end piece of garbage. If you buy it, pray you don’t have to deal with their customer service. I’d give them zero stars if I could.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2021
review.title: Click away
review.review: Perhaps one of nicest mouse clicking sounds and feeling I have ever heard with hardly any delay between clicks.However a major nitpick I have is when you use the mouse for the first time on a pc it opens up a download prompt for the software which is convenient but distracting when using it on a different pc for the first time (haven't tested it just hypothetically speaking)To use certain features i.e macros you need the software to be installed AND be in the background but overall mouse control you dont need the software.After you figure our your button bindings delete the software then have your pc forget the mouse then reconnect the mouse and close out the download prompt (after you do it once it won't reappear unless you make your pc forget it) This solved the issue I had with it skipping abruptly both in-game and browsing.After these changes its a very solid mouse and felt right at home using it without needing to make any adjustments.Only nitpick I have is that you can't get custom shells individually in the official website or other websites.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2021
review.title: I hope you have big hands.
review.review: This mouse is definitely *not* for people who have hands on the smaller side of average. I don't have tiny hands by any means, but this mouse is extremely awkward for me to use without accidentally hitting the first row of keys on the side. My hand simply doesn't wrap around enough of the bulk of this thing to get a good grip on only the non-button portions of the mouse. This leads to firing off skills or macros that I absolutely do not intend to use yet while just moving the mouse around; I've had to disable the first row of keys entirely to avoid this.Another problem the size presents is that it won't consistently hold down the LMB if I want to click and drag; it'll often let go prematurely because my fingertips apparently don't reach far enough forward to get the leverage it needs to keep the sensors in contact.Years ago, I had a Naga that had plates you could swap out to adjust the size appropriate to your needs, but they apparently don't make them anymore, and are going with a "one (large) size fits all" approach. This is a major shame, because it's excluding a fairly significant portion of the gaming population.If you have big ol' hands, then I bet this mouse would work great for you. It's lightweight (almost too lightweight) and pretty responsive.
product.title: Razer Naga Trinity Gaming Mouse: 16,000 DPI Optical Sensor - Chroma RGB Lighting - Interchangeable Side Plate w/ 2, 7, 12 ...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2021
review.title: The only premium wireless mmo mouse. needs some competition
review.review: The only MMO mouse that is wireless, from a name brand company.Features: comes with PTFE mouse feet which is very generous and not common, usually you buy these aftermarket.fairly light considering all the hardware on it. another big plus.comes with 3 side plates. one with 12 buttons, one with 2, and one with I think 6? very cool and convenient, and easy to swap out.no perceivable latency, however I originally bought this mouse used. it would lose connection for several seconds, which is unusable for gaming and just annoying in any other application, especially at this price.I returned it and bought a new one, which has the same issue but only loses connectivity very briefly, enough for me to just ignore. I dont play shooters or 1st person games with it so whatever.the razer software has automatic profile switching. you can set up specific keybinds for any program (even ones that arent games) and when you switch to a different program the keybinds automatically swap. this is insanely useful for video editing, music production, MMOs, all kinds of things.battery life is great. naturally, the lights suck a lot of it up but you should turn them off if you want it to last long.I like the ergonomics a lot, I think it feels great in my hand. it's meant to be held with your fingers laid on it and your palm mostly lifted off of it. it feels very comfortable but I'd like it slightly lighter for easier movement.if it werent for the disconnection this would be 5/5 stars. it has zero ccompetition, is feature packed and is good at what it does.

review.title: Great Shape, Insane Quality, but the clicks sound hollow AF.
review.review: I have had this mouse for about a month or two now and I have a couple of things to say. First off, the shape is absolutely AMAZING. review.title: Got a XM1R with a bad encoder for the scroll wheel - have heard of others having the same issue.
review.review: The scroll wheel showed issues right out of the box and took about a week or so before becoming completely useless. Randomly scrolls up 2-3 pages which makes for a very annoying web browsing experience. I also randomly get small movements in the opposite direction which makes it unusable in most games. Probably just going to try and solder a new encoder on it rather than waste weeks on a return.The mouse seems fine outside of the scroll wheel issues. My hands are on the bigger size and I've always used palm grip and I've had to adjust my grip a little bit to keep my fingertips from dragging. The stock mouse feet are very slow on hard pads, so you should consider the cost of new mouse feet if you're into speed because they outright aren't going to cut it. The cord is pretty nice for the price point.

review.title: Cool RGB mouse, don't care about other features though
review.review: First of all the RGB on this mouse is slick.I has the DeathAdder Chroma (which was old, and the RGB didn't work with Synapse 3), but I loved the feel of it.This mouse had that similar feel, I actually may like this mouse's feel more than the DeathAdder and I'm happy with my decision for this mouse over the DeathAdder 2.I normally stick with what is familiar, and glad I broke out of my comfort zone.It glides easily across my desk and the DPI adjustable thing which I rarely ever use is still nice to have in case I ever need it.I do like you can reprogram the buttons (and those thumb buttons I have surprisingly found good uses for).One thing I'll say is the right mouse button sometimes gets accidentally pressed.Could be my long Diablo 3 constant clicking that my hand just hits the mouse button on accident frequently, but resting my hand on the mouse I don't feel it should be that easy that accidentally clicking occurs.So would have been 5 star, but subtracted half a star for those weird accidental mouse clicks.Subtracted another half only because it's not wireless for this price!

review.title: Left-Click Stopped Working After A Few Months
review.review: I purchased this mouse for light gaming and typical web browsing. Within 6 months, I noticed the left-click was not holding down correctly. Physically it felt fine, but it was basically unplayable in games. I tried every solution and the problem only got worse over time so I figured it was a hardware problem rather than a software issue. I took great care of the mouse and used it VERY lightly yet it still gave out quickly. Not to mention the Razer Synapse program is terrible. Unfortunately for me, the company that sold me the product through Amazon, "TECHLOBBY", is not an authorized seller of Razer products so the 2 year manufacturers warranty did NOT cover this issue. On Razer's website, Amazon is an authorized seller of Razer products but many of the companies that sell through Amazon are not so it is very misleading. This mouse is no longer manufactured by Razer so don't even bother buying it. For $50, this mouse became useless after a few months of light use, DO NOT RECOMEND.

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2021
review.title: Side-grade to the V2. Great if you never owned the V2 / Razer Basilisk Ultimate.
review.review: When compared to the V2 / Razer Basilisk Ultimate , after 1 week of use:TLDR - Scroll wheel and LED upgrades are good.But... the +/- resistance option for the scroll wheel on the underside of the mouse is now gone. I'm not a fan of the changes to the button internal switches and how they feel or sound.Pros: I like the changes to the scroll wheel. No complaints there. I like that they finally copied one of the features I loved about older Logitech mice. The LED zones on the bottom of the mouse are sweet for you RGB fans (which you probably area if you are buying this).Cons: (It's hard to know if these are little defects with the specific mouse I got, or all V3s are like this). I'm not a huge fan of these upgraded switches for the buttons. I liked the way the V2 felt and sounded better. These are louder and require more force to press. The thumb buttons for forward/back or buttons 3 and 4, feel and sound different from each other. It really annoys me. And the new version of the button 5 or the sniper button, feels worse than the V2 for sure. The button has farther travel distance, feels more mushy, and does not press smoothly. Pressing it feels like the bottom side of the button angles down more than the top. I also hoped this button would be closer to your thumb than it was with V2, which for me always felt too far away and I would need to adjust my whole hang to press it. With the V3, for better or worse, its in the same exact place as the V2.I'm actually debating buying another one to see if the switches feel or sound any better, and then return the worse of the two.The +/- resistance option for the scroll wheel on the underside of the mouse is now gone. No way to adjust resistance. I really wish they had kept that feature.Some people wont like the change to the weight, but I wont mind it.With all that said, if you never owned the V2 / Razer Basilisk Ultimate, you'll be happy with this mouse.
product.title: Razer Basilisk V3 Customizable Ergonomic Gaming Mouse: Fastest Gaming Mouse Switch - Chroma RGB Lighting - 26K DPI Optical...

review.review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 13, 2021
review.title: A better wired V2, but with some slight setbacks
review.review: The infinite scroll wheel is awesome to have especially for someone like me who's switching over from a Logitech MX Master. The Basilisk's shape isn't as comfortable for my hands as that mouse, mainly because it's lacking a little in size compared to the MX. This mouse is much nicer for gaming though as there are more DPI options, and honestly the clicks seem a little more responsive for gaming.The software control for this mouse is good, but I feel it's not as responsive as the wired Basilisk V2 that I had was. This is mainly with regards to Razer's Chroma software. I tried to have the bottom portion of LEDs disabled, but it can be pretty laggy or buggy as an effect. The main reason why I tried to turn off the bottom portion of RGB lights is because it can be pretty distracting. The lighting around that area looks totally badass, but the reflection it makes against the surface looks kind of ugly. Honestly, I think V2 looks a little bit more classy because it's not leaving an RGB shadow behind by default.Still I think the V3 is overall a better upgrade over the V2 because of the infinite scroll wheel. If you don't mind the flashier RGB, this will give you the same comfort as the V2, but with more versatile functionality.

review.title: Adds the Right RGB Flare
review.review: If you’re looking for an RGB gaming pad to work with all your other Razer pieces, this is the one.Note: as with almost all other Razer devices, Mac RGB functionality is quite limited (though there is a way to get around this with a slightly-hacked Razer app for Mac that can be found on GitHub). Works like a charm with PC though.Only complaint is that the grey one is pretty prone to spots, and it’s insanely difficult to clean and get spot-free. Even with water, it leaves odd splotches in places. In hindsight, I should’ve just went for the black one to avoid this headache altogether.TL;DR: it’s great, just as long as you buy the black one.
